(Aug 2015)", "1-Altitude offers a dazzling view of the city\u2019s skyline. With a wide menu of food and drinks, 1-Altitude provides diners with a mesmerising wine and dine experience right in the heart of Singapore.\r\n\r\nThe best place to be during sundown, visit 1-Altitude for post-work shenanigans. Kickstart your meal with a delicious plate of Creamy Fish Laksa Pasta. Rich and tasty, the pasta combines the well-loved classic carbonara sauce with the local spicy broth, packing a punch of flavour in every mouthful. Another interesting rendition of sweet and savoury flavours is the Bak Kwa Carbonara Pasta.\r\n\r\nSharing options at 1-Altitude are also aplenty with their array of food platters. The Satay Platter is a hot favourite, with marinated beef, pork and chicken skewers served with warm rice cakes.\r\n\r\nAs the night progresses, expect rounds of great classic cocktails and alcoholic spirits as well as delectable bar bites while the live band serenades you. (Jul 2020)", "The Restaurant\r\nLocated on Sentosa island, 1-V:U promises a dining experience like no other. A four-minute walk from the Wings of Time show and accessible via Imbiah station along the Sentosa Monorail, 1-V:U is the crown jewel of The Outpost Hotel. Open for breakfast, brunch, lunch and dinner, the 60-seater luxe-casual dining room offers front-row access to the live culinary theatrics through an open kitchen by the team of chefs, led by Ace Tan.\r\nThe Communal Menu is interestingly themed \u201cTerra\u201d (land), and \u201cAqua\u201d (sea), to put the spotlight on their meats and seafood dishes respectively.\r\n\r\nStandouts include the refreshing Grilled Tiger Prawns, served in a chilled lemongrass galangal prawn broth, along with avocado and glass noodles. If you prefer red meat, be sure to try the Beef Tartare with Confit Yolk, drizzled with smoked sesame dressing, and served with scallions and nashi pear. (Feb 2020)\nThe Day Club\r\n1-V:U is an exquisite oasis for sun-seekers seeking an escape from the city bustle. With daily DJ sessions on deck bringing Deep House and Soulful beats all the way from day to night, 1-V:U is where it\u2019s at for the endless summer vibes. Cool off with our signature cocktails in hand, dig into our dayclub bites and groove to poolside beats as you take in the unparalleled panorama of the island. (May 2015)", "13% Wine Bistro was founded on a shared love of fine wine, great food, and the unpretentious atmosphere of vineyards across Europe.\r\n\r\nSnugly nestled on the second floor, simple furniture and walls loaded with frames fade into the background as the enormous chalkboard panel listing specials and recommendations draws your attention. Warm bulbs and aqua lights tracking along the 8-metre mosaic bar set a cosy scene whilst diners peruse the special Iberico and cheese counter, or take their seats and eagerly await the delicious parade of contemporary European cuisine and international wines to come.\r\n\r\nWhether you're an expert or just starting out, 13% Gastro Wine\u2019s drink list will take you on a pleasant wine-tasting journey as you dig into delicacies like Tatins, grilled Black Iberico \"la Pluma\" marinated with cured Iberico ham, or the Coca Iberico (featuring Coca bread topped with Comt\u00e9 cheese, Iberico Ham, Portobello, roasted tomato & garlic sauce and fresh herbs). Sharing boards are also available to stave off hunger pangs between tipples - an absolute necessity! It's all the pleasures of vineyard wine tasting without the high prices and stuffy snootiness. (Apr 2018)", "Chef Alvin Leung might have earned himself international fame with his famous \u2018Sex on the Beach\u2019 dish, but you don\u2019t have to worry about konjac-based \u2018condoms\u2019 filled with ham jus on the menu here. Instead, Leung takes things down a notch and puts his focus on turning out charcoal-grilled items and interesting sauces. You\u2019ll want to order the Singapore-style Laksa, Leung\u2019s tribute to our little red dot. The slippery noodles are dipped in a rich gravy made from a generous amount of prawn shells and coconut milk, with tea-smoked quail eggs and tempura tiger prawns that elevate this humble dish. The Whole Boston Lobster in Thai Dressing is another dish that shows off a creative sauce \u2014 this time, made from fish sauce, lime and chilli, and diced mangosteens and tomatoes. For lighter, more refreshing fare, try the Sashimi of Hamachi. The fleshy slices are plumped up with a zesty calamansi gel, ponzu sauce, and a smattering of slightly bitter and crunchy garlic chips. Come for the creative cooking without gimmicks. (Jan 2019)", "History breathes beneath the floorboards and inside the walls of this beautiful bar at the Sofitel smack in the middle of the Central Business District. As a nod to the rich maritime history of the area around the hotel, this luxe bar was named 1864 after the year the historic Tanjong Pagar Dock Company was founded, and it evokes equal parts modern luxury and old-world glamour.\nIn the day, it is a breakfast and tea lounge, serving up eggs, Viennoiseries, coffee, and high-tea platters. At lunchtime, treat yourself to tapas with a French-Asian profile, think spicy Scallop Brochette, ikura-studded Salmon Crostini, and smoky Kurobuta Pork Yakitori served up with cold soba noodles. By the night-time, all the good vibes come together to turn the space into a sexy wine and cocktail bar, serving hotel guests alongside the city\u2019s swanky barflies, turning out barrel-aged cocktails and premium wines faster than you can say \u201cmartini\u201d. The signatures here include a regal Cognac Old Fashioned, the Martinez, a forgotten classic made with gin and cherry liqueur, and a cheeky Coconut Negroni that puts a Singapore spin on the international favourite. Luxury, elegance, and a quiet spot to while away the day: they don\u2019t often make hotels like this anymore, steeped in old-world charm and flawless hospitality. (Aug 2018)", "2D1N Soju Bang is the sister restaurant to the popular Korean BBQ joint Ssikkek, located just upstairs. \r\n\r\nAt 2D1N, the focus is on authentic, homely Korean cuisine. The Ginseng Chicken Soup, for instance, is a comforting dish featuring a plump, tender chicken simmered in a nourishing broth infused with slices of spiced ginger and spring onions. \r\n\r\nMeat lovers will also love the Korean steamed spicy chicken. A healthier alternative to the deep-fried version, the meat here is tossed with the same sweet spicy sauce, and steamed until tender. Potatoes, carrots, and onions are accompaniments that turn this dish into a hearty stew. \r\n\r\nOf course, the Kimchi Pancake is another not-to-be-missed classic. The crisp edges of the fried pancakes are perfect to nibble on, while the tangy slivers of kimchi nestled in the fluffy pancake help to cut through the richness of the dish. Wash it all down with a glass or two of sweet Makgeolli. It is recognised for its fusion style meals with a slight twist of local flavour. \n\n49 Seats, the pioneer of Tom Yum Pasta as well as Fish and Chips with Tom Yum Sauce in Singapore, is our go-to for foods full of spicy and savoury flavours. (Feb 2019)", "", "Following the philosophy that good food can also be affordably priced, 5 Senses Bistro serves up comfort dishes, reminiscent of mama\u2019s cooking. The kitchen team takes pride in the food they cook, as seen from the attention to detail \u2014 Carbonara, for instance, is a favourite pasta dish with slivers of juicy bacon and a precise 62\u00b0C Poached Egg. The restaurant\u2019s signature dish, a Semi-House Smoked Chicken Breast Linguine, is also a delight to tuck into. The slippery, al dente pasta is made fresh daily, as is the tangy tomato sauce enveloping this dish. The chicken is lightly-smoked, juicy, and flavourful. For a heartier main course, try the 150 Days Grain-Fed Angus Braised Beef Cheek. The beef is cooked sous vide for hours, so that the meat is meltingly soft and fork-tender, suffused with a rich, heady flavour from the gravy. Be sure to save some space for dessert. Classics like the Apple Crumble and a delicious, warm Chocolate Lava Cake are sweet comforts to indulge in at the end of the meal. (Dec 2018)", "Korean BBQ is all about the meat, but at some barbecue joints, you end up scarfing down generic slabs of meat with little to no character or flavour. Not at Eight Korean BBQ, a sleek, industrial-chic barbecue joint at swanky Shaw Centre that prides itself on its meat know-how. Here, the focus is on exquisite cuts from premium varieties of beef and pork. They\u2019ve sourced super-rare Mangalitza pork that has a rich meatiness and beautiful, flavourful fat, as well as Toriyama Wagyu beef, the \u201crolls royce\u201d of high-end Japanese beef known for its buttery texture and flavour.\nIn true Korean style, you can have your meats seared unadorned, coated in a punchy marinade, or served up in a nourishing stew. The restaurant\u2019s name is drawn from its signature dish, the Eight Colours Set, which brings eight portions of pork belly, each a different colour, from pink and unseasoned to a spicy, fiery red that signals its heavy gochujang flavour. Premium choices abound, a kind of choose-your-own-adventure Korean BBQ experience. Stop by for funky Korean BBQ and experience some of the best meat the world has to offer! (Aug 2018)", "My oh my do we love some Korean grilled meats. Our latest craze? None other than E!GHT Korean BBQ, located at The Central at Clarke Quay. The exclamation mark in lieu for the letter \u2018i\u2019 is warranted at E!GHT Korean BBQ, as any food lover would get understandably hyped up over its tantalising array of impeccable BBQ meats. \n\nPork features front and centre here, and we encourage guests to go whole hog. Grab a few friends and partake in the signature 8 Colours Set, where thick strips of pork belly are marinated eight different ways, with wine, ginseng, garlic, miso, and red pepper paste. If you were wondering why the pork here is so rich and tender, it\u2019s because the establishment only uses the famous Mangalitsa pork from Hungary, better known as the \u2018Kobe beef of pork\u2019. Searching for something comforting? Then why not order up one of E!GHT\u2019s many stews? Top picks include Beef Kimchi Stew, Seafood Bean Paste Stew, and the Army Stew. Finally, complete your meal with some grog, whether it be Korean Hite Beer or Korean Raspberry Wine. \n\nPrepare to feast like kings in this industrial chic Korean grill, where you won\u2019t even have to lift a finger as the attentive service staff do all the cooking right in front of your eyes. (Jun 2017)", "", "Offering a fine selection of Japanese and Australian wagyu, Aburi-EN specialises in \u201caburi\u201d, partially grilled meat. The pride and joy of the restaurant, its A4/A5 Miyazaki wagyu has consecutively clinched Japan\u2019s \u201cNational Wagyu Award\u201d three times.\r\n\r\nHarvested from carefully selected pigs which enjoy a natural diet of chestnuts and other nutritious food, the restaurant\u2019s Buta Don bowls feature hearty servings of tender juicy meat with a sweet nuance. Pop by during lunch to enjoy a bowl of Premium Buta Don with a mini bowl of asari miso soup and pickles. Alternatively, choose to add on a healthy bowl of greens or an Okinawa Onsen Egg to compliment your meal!\r\n\r\nSatisfy your carnivorous cravings with the Wagyu Stamina Don. For those who prefer a steaming warm bowl of noodles to satiate your cravings for authentic Japanese food, the Kyushu Tonkotsu Karamiso Ramen and Wagyu Niku Udon comes highly recommended. (Feb 2021)", "Offering a fine selection of Japanese and Australian wagyu, Aburi-EN specialises in \u201caburi\u201d, partially grilled meat. The pride and joy of the restaurant, its A4/A5 Miyazaki wagyu has consecutively clinched Japan\u2019s \u201cNational Wagyu Award\u201d three times.\r\n\r\nHarvested from carefully selected pigs which enjoy a natural diet of chestnuts and other nutritious food, the restaurant\u2019s Buta Don bowls feature hearty servings of tender juicy meat with a sweet nuance. Pop by during lunch to enjoy a bowl of Premium Buta Don with a mini bowl of asari miso soup and pickles. Alternatively, choose to add on a healthy bowl of greens or an Okinawa Onsen Egg to compliment your meal!\r\n\r\nSatisfy your carnivorous cravings with the Wagyu Stamina Don. Topped with a beautiful Okinawa egg, this don is a tasty mix of grilled miyazaki, Australian wagyu and mixed vegetables. Other mouthwatering rice bowls here include the Chicken Nanban Don, Unagi Jyu and Aburi Salmon don. For those who prefer a steaming warm bowl of noodles to satiate your cravings for authentic Japanese food, the Kyushu Tonkotsu Karamiso Ramen and Wagyu Niku Udon comes highly recommended. A mix of wagyu short rib, wagyu loin, pork belly, pork cheek and sausage, this generous platter is accompanied by egg soup, assorted kimchi, vegetables and more for a satisfying meal. (Nov 2020)", "If you\u2019re on the prowl for truly authentic Italian food, look no further than Acqua e Farina. This charming, tastefully decorated restaurant will welcome diners with warm, positive vibes from the moment they step in (think lots of wood and brick in the interiors). Lovely d\u00e9cor wouldn\u2019t mean very much without great grub, though, and we\u2019re happy to say that Acqua e Farina\u2019s mouthwatering list of Italian treats, made from produce mostly imported from Italy, is an absolute delight.\nLuxuriate in Italian culinary heaven with dishes like the signature Pizza Acqua e Farina, with its delectable toppings of salami, tomato, mozzarella, ricotta cheese, and saut\u00e9ed spinach. Each bite will unleash a delicious medley of flavours, and before you know it you\u2019ll be chowing down with unexpected enthusiasm and speed! The pastas aren\u2019t to be sneezed at either \u2013 the Spaghetti ai Gamberi is bound to impress with its helpings of oh-so-fresh prawns and a spiciness that gives it extra \u2018kick\u2019. Finally, few meals are complete without a dessert to round things off \u2013 and if you\u2019re unsure of what to get, why not try the Piatto di Dolci? This platter contains mini portions of Cr\u00e8me Br\u00fbl\u00e9e, Lava Cake, Panna Cotta, and Tiramisu, providing you with a very well-rounded coda to your meal. There are many other dishes on the restaurant\u2019s hefty menu that aren\u2019t mentioned here, so why not nip down and check it out sometime soon? You won\u2019t regret it, we promise! (Feb 2017)", "Get ready to embark on a sensational culinary experience at ADDA as the best dishes from India take on a fun, contemporary twist. Relax and soak up the ambience in the restaurant\u2019s comprehensive concept of a restaurant, bar and lounge, all rolled into one. \r\n\r\nA fun take on the popular Indian street food, the Pani Puri is a plateful of sweet and savoury fried puff pastry balls filled with spiced mashed potato. Made for the discerning palate, this dish is a must try here at ADDA. Topped with caramelised cottage cheese and spiced salsa queso, the Adda Nachos features crunchy and thick homemade gram flour nachos loved by all. Served with a side of avocado salsa, the Prata Quesadillas comes stuffed with peppers and cheese for the vegetarians. A non-vegetarian option is also available on the menu. \r\n\r\nPair your meal with a heady cocktail mix artfully crafted by the restaurant\u2019s master mixologist, or opt for The Spice Adda experience with a melange of signature ADDA cocktails and a carefully curated wine list of over 50 options. (Feb 2021)", "If there's one relatively underrated cuisine on the Singapore dining scene, it's raw vegan fare. Vegetarianism's stauncher cousin has gained itself a reputation for not being the tastiest stuff in the world, often relegated to the classification of rabbit food. Afterglow, the hip outpost in the Keong Saik area, aims to change that perception with intriguing, creative raw fare that defies expectations.\nAfterglow has hippie chic intentions that go well beyond its inventive decor. The concept was born out of local ingredient sourcing and improving the lifestyles of city dwellers with wholesome, natural fare. Evolving the industrial look with a vintage, trinket-filled aura, the communal space is used to showcase on-theme books, accessories and even wines. This is your first indication that the approach here is not all pious, with additional edge given by artisanal cold brew, small-batch coffee, and craft beer to suit the lively neighborhood after dark.\nRegardless of your familiarity with raw vegan dishes, the menu at Afterglow aims to please. To start, the Raw vegan nut 'cheese' platter with crackers uses cultured cashews, soaked and pureed to recreate the smooth texture of a cheesy dip, miraculously sans any actual dairy. The accompanying crackers made of whole seeds and grains deliver a satisfying crunch, and the dip is so tasty that you'd never know it has added probiotic benefits. The sushi-like Afterglow kimchi nori rolls uses faux rice made with almonds and homemade Kimchi that has been stewing in zingy marinades for 7 days. Venturing into Mexican territory, the Raw taco bowl substitutes the seasoned beef for chunky walnuts spiced with a blend of salsas and crunchy purple cabbage, for a refreshing take on usually belt-busting burritos. For a more Italian spin, the Raw lasagne smartly deceives the tongue with zucchini as the pasta sheets, and macerated tomatoes as the sauce.\nThe Drag-pom salad is ideal for raw-vegan newbies and naysayers alike, featuring an undeniably good combination of dragonfruit with pomegranate, avocado, and macadamia. Also sure to please any palate is the Raw chocolate salted caramel fudge, featuring raw avocado and cacao, layered with sesame-based tahini cream, and a vanilla-medjool sweetened crust for a delightfully guilt-free treat. And really, doesn't that make it all the sweeter? (Dec 2014)", "", "A member of Marriott Bonvoy, dine in a menu of bold culinary offerings grounded in highly-lauded chef Akira Back\u2019s signature philosophies.\r\nDelight in an unexpected and exploratory culinary style of modern Japanese cuisine as chef reinvents the traditional Japanese playbook of dining with a menu where elegant melding of cultures inspires the evolution of culinary tradition.\r\nSignatures include Tuna Pizza, thinly-sliced fresh Tuna by pairing it with an umami aioli with a sprinkle of truffle oil atop the delicate crust. The classic Korean dish of Yukhoe is elevated with Tajima wagyu striploin served with nashi pear and sesame soy, topped with a quail egg yolk and seaweed caviar.Discover Akira Back\u2019s signature flavours, where the show is not just in the mouth. (Feb 2021)", "In our minds, a culinary gem hidden in plain sight would be the best way to describe Al Borgo @ Alocassia Apartments. Synonymous with its Italian name, 'the Village', this unpretentious Italian Trattoria situated along Bukit Timah is known by its fans for its warm service and rustic Italian fare.\nDespite its modest interior of dark wood floors and tiled bricks, the food at Al Borgo @ Alocassia Apartments is second to none. It should come as no surprise though, judging by Chef Mimmo's insistence on using only the freshest ingredients and making most of the dishes from scratch!\nDiners are in for a real treat as Chef Mimmo brings his Italian roots to the plate with a range of classic Napoleon dishes such as Parma, Quattro Formaggi and Bufala Pizza - a thin crusted tomato based pizza baked to perfection and topped with arugula, slices of fresh bufala mozzarella and cherry tomatoes.\nFancy some light evening breeze while sipping on a glass of Bordeaux? Al Borgo @ Alocassia Apartments' al fresco dining area is a hit with its regulars, and it's easy to see why. Imagine enjoying some great Italian food with a glass of wine in hand, while the sun sets in the background. I guess that's what the Italians mean by 'La Dolce Vita'. (Sept 2017)", "A sunny retreat that has been an East Coast staple for 20 years, Al Forno really knows what it's doing when it comes to fresh Italian favourites.\nWith all the Italian options in Singapore, it's no wonder the competition is stiff enough to see many a restaurant come and go, but Al Forno has stood the test of time and tastiness with a beautifully simple philosophy. Take the freshest Italian ingredients, make dishes that people know and love, and the diners will come. And while it's now a common claim to source ingredients like vine ripened whole tomatoes and peppery parmigiana directly from Italy, Al Forno was the first to do so, with exclusive imports since 1995. That means the dishes here have been tasted, tweaked and perfected so that you can't go wrong with anything on the diligently genuine, yet approachable menu.\nThe Linguine All' Aragosta, more commonly known as Lobster Linguine, is a house favourite, featuring salty capers and olives punctuating a naturally sweet red sauce made from cherry tomatoes. Succulent chunks of lobster tail and thick noodles of linguine soak up the sauce perfectly. For more of that divine signature sauce, go for the Spaghetti Cartoccio, which is studded with a mix of shelled seafood and baked up in a decadent foil package for two. From the pizzas, the Pizza Con Carne is a knockout, with all forms of meaty deliciousness arranged neatly atop the authentic foldable crust. The Pizza Rollo is a great starter or family pick, featuring a melt of ricotta, spinach and ham all rolled up. Looking quite charming atop their trademark checkered tablecloths, all the dishes taste as good as they look! (Mar 2015)", "With all the Italian options in Singapore, it's no wonder the competition is stiff enough to see many a restaurant come and go, but Al Forno has stood the test of time and tastiness with a beautifully simple philosophy. (Aug 2018)", "If you aren\u2019t in the know, the dim and unassuming interiors or covered doorways of the eateries along Amoy might baffle and leave you wondering if there really are plenty of food options here \u2013 perhaps one of the reasons why the bright spaces of ALATI will inevitably catch your eye. From the invitingly open arched doors to the signature blues and whites of the Mediterranean coating the interiors, everything, including the food, will transport you to Greece.\n\nFor full authenticity, the produce is brought here, fresh from the Aegean Sea, and items on the menu are crafted by hand, which might explain the depth of flavour in dips like Taramosalata (fish-roe cream) and Melitzanosalata (smoked eggplants with walnuts). Of course, there\u2019s more than pita and dips on the menu. Fill up on amazing Salt-Baked Fresh Fish, grilled gems like the Octopus and Squid \u2013 simply named but complex on the tongue \u2013 and mains like Kotopoulo Souvlaki (grilled chicken with fried potatoes and yoghurt) as well as Mousaka (minced beef, eggplant, potatoes and b\u00e9chamel sauce). Even their drinks menu boasts Greek tipples like Mastiha and Ouzo, an uncommon sight in Singapore.\n\nBring on the influx of Japanese and American diners to our shores, we\u2019re not complaining, but it\u2019s nice to see more unusual cuisines, that prove deliciously authentic, opening up in the heart of the city! (Feb 2016)", "Alaturka Mediterranean & Turkish Restaurant prides itself on being the purveyor of fine Mediterranean, Turkish, and Middle Eastern dining. With indoor dining as well as alfresco seating in historic Kampong Glam, be treated to impeccable Turkish hospitality while you feast on dishes that are meticulously prepared from only the best ingredients.\r\n\r\nThe menu is extensive, featuring hot and cold appetisers, pide, kebabs, mains, desserts, and more. The Meze Tabagi is a great introduction to the cuisine, with an assortment of popular mezes and a side of hot Turkish Lavas Bread.\r\n\r\nFor mains, specialities include the Adana Kebab, a grilled skewer of marinated minced chicken, the Kuzu Pirzola, grilled lamb chops with homemade gravy, and the classic Moussaka. Choose from the wide range of Turkish breads to go along with the protein-heavy dishes too, from classic sourdough to ones topped with melted cheese.\r\n\r\nThe desserts are equally tempting and will definitely satisfy anyone with a sweet tooth. If we had to choose a favourite, it would be the Kunefe, a thin vermicelli pastry baked in soft cheese and soaked in syrup. Wash all the goodness down with a comforting pot of traditional apple tea. (Dec 2019)", "alittle tashi \u2013 meaning \u2018blessings\u2019 and \u2018welcome\u2019 by the Himalayans, serves modern Asian comfort food thoughtfully crafted for a communal dining experience. Conceived from flavour memories recollected from different moments and experiences in life, the sharing plates at alittle tashi are comfort food refined and elevated with modern cooking techniques and quality ingredients. (Sep 2020)", "A cocktail bar tucked between two heritage Peranakan shophouses along Emerald Hill, Alley Bar is an architectural gem that seamlessly weaves old world charm with contemporary design for a cosy and inviting atmosphere.\r\n\r\nServing up a mix of stellar cocktails and non-boozy drinks, Alley Bar\u2019s photo-worthy cocktails will definitely have you reaching out for more. Perfect for after work socials or gatherings with friends, the bar has a wide variety of happy hour classics and cocktails for all. A unique twist on the Pina Colada, The Ghosted Colada is a heady mix of Plantation 3 stars rum and house-made pandan syrup, pineapple juice, fresh lime and coconut. Tinged with fruity notes, this tropical paradise drink is a great option to zest up your night. \r\n\r\nFor those who rather stick to local favourites, The Invisible Sling is Alley Bar\u2019s cheeky take on the usual Singapore Sling. This concoction features a combination of Widges Gin, Dom Benedictine, cherry brandy and triple sec with kaffir lime leaf-infused pineapple juice, angostura bitters, fresh lime juice, and house-made hibiscus syrup. \r\n\r\nOffering equally exciting non-alcoholic options on it\u2019s extensive menu, those who prefer to steer clear of alcohol can also get in on the action with Alley Bar\u2019s exciting cordials. (Dec 2020)", "", "If you believe that the essence of dining is all about indulging in the finest cuisine with your closest companions, you will love Alma by Juan Amador. Here, a casual atmosphere and astonishing creations reveal the culinary brilliance of the highly-acclaimed three-Michelin star chef, Juan Amador. Situated on the leafy grounds of Singapore\u2019s Goodwood Park Hotel on Scotts Road, the menu at Alma by Juan Amador reads like a roster of contemporary European dishes heavy with Asian influence. Places tend to fill up quickly at this Michelin one-star restaurant in Orchard, so wait no more and reserve a table today!\nFor Asian-influenced modern European cuisine in the Orchard district of Singapore, look no further than Alma by Juan Amador \u2013 the brainchild of the eponymous Spanish-German chef with three Michelin stars to his name. Helmed by executive chef Haikal Johari, whose illustrious career saw him establish the renowned Water Library restaurants in Bangkok, Thailand, Alma (which means \u201csoul\u201d in Spanish) takes you to the heart of dining with extraordinary, masterful creations like the signature monkfish cheek with saffron, mussel and artichoke.\nYou\u2019ll find this Michelin one-star restaurant on the tranquil premises of the Goodwood Park Hotel, a heritage building on Scotts Road in Singapore\u2019s commercial heart of Orchard. Over 300 wine labels, including several from Robert Parker\u2019s 100-Point list, will spoil wine lovers with a penchant for European-Asian fare at Alma by Juan Amador, so don\u2019t hesitate to approach its amiable crew if you need a recommendation. Additionally, drinks and snacks are available at Bar@Alma and if you\u2019re coming in a group, you might want to request the private room. (May 2017)", "Almost Famous Craft Beer Bar is a minimalist beer bar tucked away in CHIJMES. Also known as the \"Apple store\" of craft beer bars, you can expect a warm ambience and Instagram-worthy food and decor.\r\n\r\nWith 16 rotational beers on tap, you\u2019ll be spoiled by choice as you try beers from all over the world like Singapore\u2019s Brewlander & Co., Australia\u2019s Pirate Life Brewing, and Vietnam\u2019s Pasteur Street Brewing Company. What\u2019s a round of beer without some wings? Try Almost Famous Craft Beer Bar\u2019s chicken wings, which come with a light spicy and tangy butter sriracha sauce, a yuzu soy garlic sauce, and more. Our favourite\u2019s has to be the Har Cheong Gai version, where the wings are marinated for 48 hours in a shrimp paste blend.\r\n\r\nOther highlights include its East-meets-West pasta dishes, like the Creamy Tiger Prawns Laksa Linguine, and the Chili Crab Shrooms Linguine. Besides beers, specialty Gin & Toni cocktails are also available along with non-alcoholic options such as Seedlips Spice and Tonic. (Mar 2020)", "Here\u2019s a spot that will liven up your Instagram feed. From the folks behind A Poke Theory, Alter Ego is the evil twin of the beloved healthy eating joint on Boon Tat street. Serving Poke Bowls till evening, and indulgent grub with booze afterward, everything on the menu screams #foodporn.\n\nThe brunch menu is a sight to behold - featuring everything from decadent desserts to brunch staples with a twist. Artfully created thickshakes are available in a range of flavours - from peanut butter to matcha. The Matcha Maniac is particularly noteworthy for its lush green colour and generous serving of rich chantilly cream. If sugar isn\u2019t your thing, the Pokecado Toast comes in the same lovely green shade, with velvety smashed avocado on sourdough topped with spiced roasted cashews and crispy tempura batter.\n\nPrefer some bubbly? The bar bites are as indulgent as poke is healthy. From Southern Fried Chicken Skin to local favourite Har Cheong Kai starting from just $4, you could be forgiven for wanting to try them all in one sitting. Their Happy Hour deals are pretty darn great as well - an array of $6 bottled beers and cold pints going from $10 and up. In a place like this where both food and drinks appease those at either ends of the clean or indulgent eating spectrum, you'll find solace in knowing it'll hit all the right spots. (Apr 2018)", "Nestled in the corner of Namly Place, Amano is a vibrant Italian restaurant serving up delicious pizzas and pastas, handmade with love. \r\n\r\nStart your meal on a high note with a wide selection of antipasto and salads. The Arugula Salad is a refreshing combination of nutty leafy greens, tomatoes, and slivers of prosciutto tossed in a zesty lemon dressing. The Italian Meatballs are good for sharing, with juicy beef meatballs in a tangy tomato sauce.\r\n\r\nOrdering a pizza is a must here, as each pie is lovingly handmade with fresh ingredients. The Pepperoni is a classic favourite, while adventurous palates will favour creative pizzas such as the Burrata, with fresh cheese, sweet tomatoes and pesto, or the Prawn & Bacon with an interesting Surf & Turf spin topped with juicy tiger prawns and crispy bacon. \r\n\r\nThere\u2019s also a good selection of pastas and grilled meats to choose from. The Mushroom Risotto is a top hit amongst vegetarians, while meat-lovers will enjoy grilled US Duroc Pork Chop and Ribeye Steak with mushroom sauce. Save some space for dessert \u2014 the warm Chocolate Lava Cake boasts a molten center that is not to be missed. (Dec 2020)", "For a name that conjures up images of covert military or law enforcement stake-outs, Ambush has a decidedly gentle ambience. Its ambitious menu, however, is nothing short of fierce.\nGiant platters of sausage (the Oktoberfest Platter) sit comfortably next to fragrant Spanish Paella, and the Signature Fish and Truffle Chips are mentioned in the same breath as Risotto with Pancetta & Foie Gras. If you have ever wanted to eat everything that Europe has to offer in one sitting, this is the place to be.\nIn the words of its founder, Stanley Ng, Ambush offers a \u201cwhistle-stop tour of all the best that European food has to offer...Start in France, continue through Spain, then relax with a moreish dessert and coffee in Italy \u2013 and be home in time to plan your next gastronomic adventure!\u201d\nShort of teleporting from one European city to another, Ambush is really your best bet for an eating tour of Europe in a single meal. (Aug 2016)", "Located at Hong Leong Building, Ameising Tapas & Bar is situated in the middle of the CBD. Offering a full menu of Japanese tapas, sashimi, rice and soba bowls, as well as bar snacks, it\u2019s a great place for lunch, dinner, and post-work drinks with colleagues. \r\n\r\nWhile it\u2019s a casual place, they\u2019re serious about their food. The main highlights are their kushiyaki selections, with grilled skewers that include Shiitake Truffle Yaki and Ebi Mentaiko Yaki for those who want to up their ante. Mains include the Unagi Kebayaki and Garlic Fried Rice, the latter a staple of any good teppanyaki joint. And yes, their teppanyaki selection heats things up with Surumeika Teppanyaki, with squid and butter soyu. \r\n\r\nEven if you\u2019re just here for drinks, you\u2019ll be tempted by their selection of bar snacks on offer. Have the best of everything with the Ameising Platter, consisting of Amaebi, Tako, Popcorn Chicken, Kawa Karaage, and Curry Samosa. For something lighter, opt for the Sashimi Platter instead.\r\n\r\nLunch includes wallet-friendly options such as the set lunch of grilled selections or sashimi, which comes with salad, miso soup, rice, and pickles. If you prefer a fuss-free alternative, their rice, noodle, and grain bowls pack a punch \u2014 we recommend their Poke Bowl Soba, Quinoa Bowl, and Ribeye Soba. \r\n\r\nTheir fully stocked sake collection even has a helpful sake meter value to help you narrow your choices from sweet to dry. Ameising Tapas & Bar\u2019s Cocktail Diary Series features different cocktails on Wednesdays, so look out for it! (Apr 2021)", "Bringing you drinks from around the world spanning the disco era of the 70s and 80s, coupled with mouth-watering delights from the iconic Yellow Pot, Anouska\u2019s Bar showcases top shelf spirits, premium wines, local craft beers, artisanal Chinese teas and cocktails expertly injected with nostalgic Eastern influence. You are in for an eccentric, elegant surprise as you enter the bar, which includes large golden fans and strong hues of black, gold and yellow, layered with Oriental screens and calligraphy wallpaper from Anouska\u2019s personal collection. Bask in old-world charm while enjoying craft cocktails and an abundance of delightful Chinese fare with an innovative twist.\r\n\r\nInfusing house-made chrysanthemum cordial with Tanqueray London dry gin for hints of flowery notes, the bar\u2019s trademark cocktail, Escape to Kaifeng, is a must-try. Inspired by the flower of Kaifeng in China, this intoxicating mix is refreshingly delicious.\r\n\r\nOn Her Majesty\u2019s Secret Service is a playful tribute to designer Anouska Hempel \u2014 a former Bond Girl from the 1969 namesake film \u2014 in the form of a dry gin martini tipped with yuzu and green tea bitters. Fans of the iconic martini can also try three unique variations of the Bond-approved classic with Martini Triad, a tasting flight of the bar\u2019s signature martinis \u2014 including a dirty martini clouded with house-made pickled green chilli and brine.\r\n\r\nThe Hong Long Choc is a seductive swirl of whisky, chocolate liqueur, aromatic bitters and Lapsang Souchong \u2014 perfect for chocolate lovers to satisfy their cocoa cravings.\r\n\r\nBringing the creativity and style from the adjoining Singapore Chinese Icon, Yellow Pot, Chef Sebastian has created an ingenious offering of Chinese fare made for both intimate gatherings and larger groups. Favourites include Fried Prawns with Bonito Aioli or the highly addictive Sichuan-style Popcorn Chicken \u2014 all paired perfectly with Anouska\u2019s favourite drinks from around the world. For something sweeter, the Apple Tea is a cold and fruity drink that helps to dispel the relentless heat of Singapore. Wrap up your meal with a traditional dessert like Baklava for an authentic Turkish experience. (Dec 2020)", "Hidden away from the rip-roaring CHIJMES lies Ashino, a cosy ten-seater restaurant that successfully recreates the experience of dining in a bespoke sushi restaurant in Tokyo. And no details have been spared here, from the decor that features a sushi counter fashioned from a 180-year-old block of hinoki cypress wood to the imported ingredients flown in from Japan. \n\nHeading this restaurant is none other than Taku Ashino, whose precision and meticulousness help elevate the delicate ingredients them spectacular. Having trained in various sushi restaurants in Tokyo for over a decade, Ashino pays careful attention to making the ingredients sing, grilling his fish over a binchotan grill instead of a gas torch, as well as cooking a blend of Hokkaido and Niigata rice in a traditional iron rice pot with Mount Fuji water to achieve the perfect texture of rice. \n\nWhether you choose a set or omakase menu for lunch, rest assured that you\u2019ll be in good hands. Signature sushi classics make an appearance, from the delectable melt-in-your-mouth Fatty Tuna to the Fresh Salmon Roe that provide bursts of flavour when you bite down on it, leaving you with nothing but a smile on your face. \n\nEschewing ostentatiousness and swankiness, Ashino is a culinary gem that delivers up delectable sushi not to be found anywhere else in this city. (Sep 2020)", "Awadh brings the best cuisine of Northern India right to your doorstep. Eat like Awadhi royalty as you indulge in dishes cooked in the \u201cDum Pukht\u201d style, in which ingredients in dough-sealed containers are slowly-cooked over a low flame. This process allows each individual component to gradually release their flavours, creating dishes that are not only flavorful and potent, but also connected to cultural history and tradition.\r\n\r\nLocated in The Centrepoint, Awadh is the perfect destination for gastronomes from all walks of life, serving a wide array of meat, seafood and vegetarian dishes. Be sure to try the Paya. These trotters are seasoned with a diverse mix of spices and left to cook overnight over a slow fire, creating a flavourful and tender bite. Awadh also has vegan options such as the \u201cImpossible\u201d kebabs or curries. Committed to showcasing the culinary heights of Northern India, the menu at Awadh changes with each season, and is unique to the festivals that mark the month. Thus, Awadh promises each and every diner and new and wholly unique experience. (Jan 2020)", "", "Savour the magic of Middle Eastern cuisine at this quaint little spot on Bussorah street. Tucked away amongst the plethora of haunts serving up kebabs and koftas, you might easily miss this gem despite its bright turquoise interior. Modelled after the souks of Arabia, there are some the best dishes Andalusia has to offer here. From rich kebabs to light sweet teas, you can be assured to get them all under one roof. Diners looking to get a taste of Moroccan cuisine are sure to love Deli Moroccan for its generous portions, warm service, and pocket-friendly prices. \r\n\r\nThe Beef Kofta Tagine is one of their most popular dishes. Made with ground beef, spices, and some apricot for a sweet twist, this unique dish is best savoured with some fragrant basmati rice. Carnivores are sure to enjoy the Andalusia Mixed Meat Platter. The indulgent platter consists of a generous assortment of meats like lamb, chicken, and beef accompanied by hummus and french fries -- best for sharing. Be sure to wash down your meal with some Moroccan Mint Tea, a refreshing drink made with black tea, sugar syrup, and fresh mint leaves that will invigorate your senses. (March 2019)", "", "", "Baba Chews is a restaurant inspired by our vibrant neighbourhood - Katong. The name \u201cBaba Chews\u201d pays homage to Mr. Chew Joo Chiat (1857\u20131926), a wealthy local Chinese landowner and philanthropist, known as the \u2018King of Katong\u2019 for his contributions to the local community. Our restaurant sits on the site of the former Joo Chiat Police Station (1928 \u2013 1987), built by the British in the late 1920's when Singapore was still a British Colony, which was granted conservation status by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) of Singapore for its architectural & heritage value. \r\nBaba Chews serves a diverse menu of Mod-Sin (Modern Singaporean) dishes, local favourites, and Western comfort dishes along with quality brews from Common Man Coffee Roasters & TWG tea, beers and alcoholic beverages.\r\nPopular items include our 'Kopi C' Flavoured Bbq Pork Spareribs, Chicken Rendang Lasagne & Ondeh Ondeh cake. (Sep 2020)", "Situated in the hip and buzzy Tiong Bahru neighbourhood, this charming restaurant and taverna draws upon the rich culinary history of the Eastern Mediterranean basin to conjure up scrumptious dishes that will leave you wanting more. Authenticity is the foundation of BAKALAKI's cooking, and the eatery prides itself on importing traditional ingredients from the motherland to incorporate into their meals.\nStart your meal with any one of the restaurant's mouthwatering dips. The classic Tzatziki is one of our favourites, featuring cucumbers, garlic, and olive oil folded into a refreshing light Greek yoghurt. Other winning appetisers include the Kalamari Tiganito, where a straightforward dish of crispy fried squid is enhanced with a dash of lemon juice. Indecisive diners should opt for the Mixed Grilled Meat Platter, available for sharing between two to four diners. Here, you get to sample all the best grilled meats, which include beef and kebab skewers, chicken yiros, lamb chops, meatballs, and beef sausages.\nLove what you ate? Why not take home a slice of Greek heritage and culture from the adjoining deli? The array of delicacies up for sale include cheeses, olives, honey, pulses, sauces, herbs, traditional sweets, and Greek wines. When done well, Greek cuisine can be downright phenomenal. So expect nothing less when you dine at BAKALAKI Greek Taverna - you have our word for it. (Jun 2017)", "Where \u2018Thai-riffic\u2019 meets \u2018Indo-licious\u2019, Bali Thai is the perfect combination of Thai and Indonesian cuisines in one place! A halal-certified restaurant chain in Singapore known for serving authentic delights in a family-friendly setting, it\u2019s a great place for a hearty meal.  \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\nWhet your appetite with one of their many starters. A dish that comes highly recommended, the Appetiser Platter comes with prawns cakes, chicken satay and crispy chicken, making it a tasty spread for sharing. Wrapped in fragrant pandan leaf, the Pandan Chicken is also another traditional delight that consists of juicy scented coriander chicken. Move on to the signature Phad Thai with Satay. A Thai staple not to be missed, this delicious mix of stir-fried noodles with eggs, vegetables and tofu is tossed in a delectable blend of spices for that extra kick of flavour. The skewered sticks of succulent meat complements the dish by adding different layers of texture and flavour.  \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\nOther mouthwatering dishes include the Mee Goreng with Satay, Fried Kway Teow and Nasi Goreng Istemewa. Conclude your meal with the restaurant\u2019s refreshing bowl of Sago Gula Melaka for a genuine fusion dining experience. A halal-certified restaurant chain in Singapore known for serving authentic delights in a family-friendly setting, it\u2019s a great place for a hearty meal.  \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\nWhet your appetite with one of their many starters. A dish that comes highly recommended, the Appetiser Platter comes with prawns cakes, chicken satay and crispy chicken, making it a tasty spread for sharing. Wrapped in fragrant pandan leaf, the Pandan Chicken is also another traditional delight that consists of juicy scented coriander chicken. Move on to the signature Phad Thai with Satay. A Thai staple not to be missed, this delicious mix of stir-fried noodles with eggs, vegetables and tofu is tossed in a delectable blend of spices for that extra kick of flavour. The skewered sticks of succulent meat complements the dish by adding different layers of texture and flavour.  \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\nOther mouthwatering dishes include the Mee Goreng with Satay, Fried Kway Teow and Nasi Goreng Istemewa. Conclude your meal with the restaurant\u2019s refreshing bowl of Sago Gula Melaka for a genuine fusion dining experience. (Sep 2020)", "We weren't certain it could be done, but BAM! has updated the staid tapas trend back to its former glory, with loud Japanese flavours turning up the volume on dishes that have been there, and done that a few times over. With a hip culture tailor-made for Tras Street, BAM! hits all the high notes.\nMerging two cuisines is hardly groundbreaking, however BAM!'s inspired blending of Spanish tapas with small plates that are meant to be shared, and a Japanese sake-flowing izakaya, is spot on. The category is a bit hazy - is it a tapakaya? sakapas? - but whatever you choose to call it, the dining experience here is nothing short of uproarious.\nThe digs are adequately cool kid-chic, with the requisite hipster trimmings of concrete and not much else. Nude bulbs and the underbelly of the dining room's wiring are starkly exposed. Despite the naked decor, BAM! is not blushing at all with a boldly confident gastronomic vision and spot-on flavours. The vibe draws on the hearty camaraderie of Spanish bars with the real world grit of izakayas, for a pitch-perfect air of laidback dining.\nThe menu reads like a daily market billboard, hailing the freshest and peak-season ingredients. There are some mainstays though that have earned their permanent placement. The Pasta a la Plancha with Prawn and Sake Butter is next-level umami, with just enough acidity from the wine. And sake doesn't just make a one-time appearance, with a glassed-in cooler of both popular and hard-to-find brands. The resident sake sensei will not only pair your dishes with ample pours, but will show you how to really make the most of it, encouraging you to drizzle the wine into the luscious Kampong Egg with crispy squid and punchy chorizo, another menu regular.\nAs its name suggests, BAM! is loud and proud of its excellent fusion angle. The hip setting, top-notch food, and unique sake spin, make it deserving of its exclamation point. (Aug 2014)", "Thai cuisine has long been a firm favourite with many Singaporeans, and Bangkok Jam goes a good way towards satiating the nation\u2019s cravings. Offering up a smorgasbord of delectables that are sure to make your mouth water, this restaurant expertly tempers classic Thai spices and cooking techniques with a modern sensibility for a combination that works.\r\nHave an appetising serving of the restaurant\u2019s Tod Mun Pla, and savour the explosion of flavours with every bite you take \u2013  you won\u2019t be forgetting these fish cakes in a hurry, that\u2019s for sure - or dip your spoon into a delightfully spicy bowl of Tom Yum Goong, which comes with helpings of sweet and juicy prawns to add on to the sour tang. If you\u2019re a dessert person, then the Tap Tim Krob, or red rubies topped with coconut ice cream, will be a perfect, refreshing way to end your meal. You won\u2019t regret having the crowd-pleasers either, like the heavenly Khao Neaw Ma Muang (mango sticky rice), with its pleasantly chewy and fragrant rice.\r\nAlthough it\u2019s perfectly understandable if all your attention is focused on trying not to stuff your face with the goodies on offer at Bangkok Jam, or if you\u2019re actually doing the deed and completely disregarding your surroundings (we get it), do take some time to soak in the ambience. With its casual d\u00e9cor reminiscent of a crowded street in the Thai capital, it\u2019s hard not to be charmed. So make a booking at Bangkok Jam soon \u2013 you won\u2019t regret it! Both the French Free Range Chicken and Australian Pork knuckle have won rave reviews, and we could definitely understand why. But don't fixate on just those items though, because while the rotisserie may be the heart, Chef Stephane's deft touch and heartfelt recipes are the soul of what's on offer. There's a soft harmony to the design that maintains an elegant poise, a perfect mirror to the generous food served by Chef Stephane paired with the impeccable service directed by manager Kori Millar. It's a restaurant born of dreams, love, and togetherness, and their motto, \"Love on the Plate\" couldn't be any more apt. Here, the stir-fried noodle dish is redolent with a smoky char, tossed with a generous helping of plump prawns, fresh seafood, or chicken. (Dec 2018)", "For a heaping serving of Southern charm in Singapore, there's no place like The Beast off Arab Street. Featuring artisan Bourbon flights and stick-to-your-ribs soul food, it's sure to tame your beast of an appetite.\n\nWrapped around a corner of Jalan Klapa, The Beast is a pint-sized space with gallons of flavour. Kick-started by local entrepreneur Jamie Koh of The Chupitos Bar fame, the barn-like eatery is an ode to her college days in Atlanta, Georgia. And some fun times those must have been, judging by the heavy influence of Kentucky-sourced bourbon whisky, including their signature and self-explanatory Baconator shot. The narrow ground floor area is raw and rustic, save for a trendy marquee sign along the inner wall. You could also opt for a roomier dining area upstairs, or for an alfresco barrel-topped table along the walking path.\n\nWhile it's a space built for fun times and honky-tonk, the food takes its tradition of Southern hospitality very seriously. You'd be hard-pressed to find such true-blue Southern specialties as fluffy buttermilk biscuits with sausage gravy and Cajun-spiced shrimp and grits anywhere else in the city, let alone such superb versions. Though the reputation for Southern fare starts with fried chicken and ends with extra butter (Paula Deen-style), The Beast features a complete array of the diverse flavours for which the region is so popular for. If you haven't tried these dishes before, consider this your warning that this stuff is habit-forming, and though not diet-friendly, definitely worth the splurge.\n\nGo for their new brunch menu, when those fresh-from-the-oven biscuits are on display, stuffed with drool-worthy fillings like crispy battered chicken and slow cooked pulled pork. Also noteworthy are the classic Chicken & Waffles, the Mac & Cheese Burger and savoury Cornbread. Washed down with icy Sweet Tea, or all you can drink Mimosas at $30, that's some really good eatin' y'all! (Mar 2017)", "Swing by for the ultimate night out with cocktails and fine wines paired with delicious bar bites grilled over bincho-tan at Beats Bites & Cocktail. Dedicated to the eclectic 80s music icon, this meticulously crafted drink is a heady mix of Widges Gin infused with hibiscus and butterfly pea. \r\n\r\n\r\nLooking for your favourite local flavours in a glass? Try the Ice Kacang. A visual spectacle of shaved ice, grilled pineapple spiced syrup and cranberry tea, this innovative combination definitely makes a worthy tribute to our beloved local dessert. (Feb 2017)", "The Boiler brings the concept of the American seafood boil to its second outlet at the Esplanade, complete with all the traditional spices, side dishes and cracking crustaceans and a stroke of culinary genius called the Lobsicle.\r\n\r\nThere's casual, and then there's Boiler-style casual. The kind of casual that lets you get down and dirty, in the tastiest way possible, with your meal. The Boiler features a laidback set up, allowing you to choose your fresh seafood to be boiled to order. You can go a la carte, but the Bombdiggity Bag with Dungeness crab, prawns, mussels, sausages and corns offers tons of bang for your buck. Next, choose a sauce ranging from slightly piquant to can't-feel-your-lips spicy. Your sack of goodies is prepared and then poured directly onto the paper-topped table. Formality is tossed aside along with the shells as you dig in to get to every nook and cranny of the succulent seafood, taking the phrase \"finger-licking good\" very literally. Bibs and phone covers are included.\r\nLocated near the tourist attractions like the Singapore Flyer and Merlion, The Boiler is a real find for lunch, when the usual seafood feast is fine-tuned to the mid-day meal. Tidy but still decadent dishes like Signature Fish & Chips, the Ultimate Burger with caramelized onions and Crispy Prawn Pasta Prawn Pasta Soup are great options. Any-time Sides like Salt & Pepper Crispy Chicken, the succulent fried Lobsicle on a stick, Sweet Potato Fries, and Momma's Scoop with an indulgently creamy cheesy dip are all worth the calorie splurge. After all, it's not every day that you get to go elbow deep into amazing Louisiana-style seafood. So head on down and live it up! (Feb 2020)", "The Boiler brings the concept of the American seafood boil to its second outlet at the Esplanade, complete with all the traditional spices, side dishes and cracking crustaceans and a stroke of culinary genius called the Lobsicle.\r\n\r\nThere's casual, and then there's Boiler-style casual. The kind of casual that lets you get down and dirty, in the tastiest way possible, with your meal. The Boiler features a laidback set up, allowing you to choose your fresh seafood to be boiled to order. You can go a la carte, but the Bombdiggity Bag with Dungeness crab, prawns, mussels, sausages and corns offers tons of bang for your buck. Next, choose a sauce ranging from slightly piquant to can't-feel-your-lips spicy. Your sack of goodies is prepared and then poured directly onto the paper-topped table. Formality is tossed aside along with the shells as you dig in to get to every nook and cranny of the succulent seafood, taking the phrase \"finger-licking good\" very literally. Bibs and phone covers are included.\r\nLocated near the tourist attractions like the Singapore Flyer and Merlion, The Boiler is a real find for lunch, when the usual seafood feast is fine-tuned to the mid-day meal. (Dec 2018)", "The brainchild of Chef Paik Jong Won, one of Korea\u2019s most successful and renowned celebrity chefs, BORNGA has anchored itself as a popular household favourite! (Dec 2020)", "", "", "", "", "", "Since its inception in 2006, Brotzeit has emerged as a culinary force to be reckoned with. Loved for spinning up authentic German meals and ice-cold beers, Brotzeit can often be seem packed with the food-loving, beer-guzzling crowd at all hours of the day.\n \nThere\u2019s nothing more German than huge swirling hunks of sausage. So there\u2019s little surprise to see Brotzeit featuring a wide array of such sausages, the showstopper being the Thuringer Pork Sausage, which comes with a generous heaping of mashed potatoes, sauerkraut, and sweet onion sauce. But the Sausage Platter, another fan fave, serves all the top hits from the kitchen, from grilled pork, spicy chicken, to the garlic pork sausages. \n \nWant something other than sausages? Then have your pick of hearty dishes that include the traditional Goulash Soup, so authentic any German grandmother would approve of it. Featuring generous chunks of tender beef in a herb-tinged soup, this soup is perfect on a rainy night. And the Crispy Oven Roasted Pork Knuckle is another must-try. A Brotzeit staple, this pork shank is oven-roasted until it achieves its fork-tender perfection with a crispy layer of crackling skin to boot. And wash your meal down with a beer or two, and you have all the ingredients for what is just about to be your next perfect meal. (Nov 2019)", "", "Mention to Singapore foodie friends that you have found a tiny down-to-earth place where, for the past 16 years, the owners themselves have put their own Asian twist on mind-blowingly amazing Italian food, and it\u2019s likely that the name Buko Nero will pop up. One-of-a-kind in terms of its compact dynamism, Buko Nero prides itself on serving food that they themselves would want to eat, if they were the customer. The wife, Tracy, who is Singaporean, handles the front of the restaurant, while the husband, Oscar, an Italian, is the chef. Together, they have created something that is semi-legendary in the Singapore dining scene because of the quality of food and the waiting list for this restaurant. \n\nTop of the list of recommendations for this unique establishment is the Buko Nero Tau Kwa Tower with sauteed vegetables and Asian dressing, which was created as a stacked dish consisting of vegetables such as parsley, carrots, and enoki mushrooms layered atop a big piece of tau kwa (firm tofu). Kecap manis (Indonesian sweet soya sauce) is drizzled over it, giving the entire concoction an extra oomph. Deceptively simple, this dish has won fans because of its unique flavour combination and freshness of vegetables used. The Baked Fillet of Cod, which is presented with a crust made of olives and a sweet bell pepper coulis, has also won praise for its simple yet effective use of basic ingredients. For cosy Italian fare in the heart of Singapore, it is hard to find a more intimate, homely dining experience than this well-loved restaurant that serves food straight from the heart. (Jul 2020)", "Restaurant critics generally give new restaurants 3 to 4 months to \"hit their stride\". Well at Burlamacco Ristorante, there's none of that. Opened in November 2012, this new Italian favourite has been making waves from day one, and already has a legion of fans, an endless list of favourable reviews, and quite frankly, an entire menu of delectable Italian delights.\nChef Gabriele Piegaia is an old hand at the Singapore restaurant scene, honing his skills in Michelin-starred kitchens across Italy, then learning the nuances of the Singaporean palate at Senso, Hotel Michael, and most recently, as the executive chef of Alkaff Mansion. Adhering to the golden rule of \"what you see on the menu is what you see on the plate\", the signature dishes are authentic, direct, and robust. Ingredients are allowed to shine, and there has been no compromise on quality and execution. (Jan 2020)", "Tucked away in The Flow mall along East Coast Road, Butter & Spice dishes out authentic North-Indian fare at wallet-friendly prices. From the glowing belly of the tandoori comes a delicious spiced grilled chicken, enjoyed in half or full portions if you\u2019re hungry. Make sure to share the Fish Tikka, a sumptuous treat of charred fish cubes that have been marinated in tandoori spices for that hint of heat. Love seafood? The Prawn Chatpata is a popular favourite, with juicy prawns cooked with black pepper, onions, and green chilli, and a dash of lime juice for that refreshing citrusy kick. Sop up the rich gravy with a selection of tandoori-grilled naan, available in classic flavours like cheese, garlic, and butter. Try the Kashmiri Naan if you have an adventurous palate \u2014 the flatbread with dry fruits is a sweet savoury treat that goes well with the thick curries here. Butter & Spice is also one of the few Northern-Indian restaurants to serve set menus. Each set meal comes with a side of basmati rice and naan, perfect for the days when you\u2019re looking for a quick fix. (Jan 2019)", "Busy Bussorah Street plays host to a bunch of Middle Eastern restaurants, and Byblos Grill is one of the true hidden gems amongst them. Helmed by Chef Mohamad Salim, who brings true craft and authenticity to his Lebanese cuisine, made with imported Lebanese ingredients and spices, and served up in a truly homey style. In the tradition of a true mezza, begin with a sharing platter of some of the most beautiful hummus in town: topped with a party of pine nuts, herbs, minced lamb, and olive oil, this creamy hummus, eaten with crisp pita, is heaven on earth. Alongside that, a mezze platter of Babaganoush, Labneh, Moussaka, and Arabic Salad, gives you extra pita-dipping options, and all this before the main course of grilled meats. From fragrant, smoky Lamb Kofta to tender Shish Taouk (chicken breast in a zesty marinade), nothing speaks of the Middle East quite like its stunning array of grilled, marinated meats. But it\u2019s the charcoal-grilled Lamb Chops, paired with spicy harissa, grilled vegetables, and rice that makes for a truly climactic moment: the smoky, meaty flavours are brought out perfectly by the zingy harissa, and the meat comes off the bone in chewy, tender bites. A vibrant meal in one of the most vibrant parts of Singapore, Middle Eastern fare is making a comeback: come see why! (Jun 2017)", "b\u00e9ni, a French term which translates to \"blessing\", offers one of the most exclusive epicurean experiences available in Singapore, showcasing fine authentic French cuisine with a Japanese touch. Helmed by Executive Chef Kenji Yamanaka, who has built up a formidable gamut of experience with a portfolio that includes stints at three-star Michelin restaurants Georges Blanc in Vonnas, France, and L\u2019Osier in Ginza, Tokyo, this charming eatery has earned several accolades including the prestigious 1-Michelin Star.\n\nChef Kenji's thoughtfully crafted discovery menus feature fresh produce, with meats and fish sourced and flown in from artisanal producers in Japan, and seasonal fresh vegetables from France. Highlights include Kenji's signature Amadai dish. The Amadai fish from Kyoto Prefecture is cooked in the traditional \"Matsukasayaki\" style where the scales are left on the fish and fried to a crisp resembling pine cones. This gives the fish a very unique combination of crispy and tender textures. While the cooking method remains the same, Chef Kenji comes up with new flavours to pair the Amadai with, based on the season, a reflection of his dedication to the craft. They\u2019re famous for their well-endowed margaritas, including their house favourites that come in sweet and tart flavours like peach, lime, and Soursop, though more premium numbers, mixed up with top-shelf tequilas, are also available if you\u2019re looking for something complex to nurse through the night. Think soft corn tacos filled with tender red snapper, fatty pork carnitas, or shredded steak, perfect with a dash of salsa and pico de gallo. If you\u2019re looking for something heftier, full plates are available too, featuring chow like a Mulato Rib Eye, a chargrilled cut of Australian beef that\u2019s intensified with Mexican spices and a fiery chili sauce, served alongside beans and rice. The house specialty is the Green Chile Stew, made with pork in a rich broth of chile verde, served with tortillas and rice, for a hearty, spicy centrepiece that\u2019s perfect for sharing. Take down the heat with an icy margarita, or a smoky Mezcal cocktail, and soak up the riverside vibes: the night is only beginning. And with dessert just as light and perfect as the rest of the meal, we were left wishing it did not have to end. Every single dumpling is filled with the right amount of filling and is fried to crisp perfection without a hint of greasiness.\n\nThe gyoza here are stuffed with a variety of fillings and topped with everything from cheese to citrus sauce. We never thought a restaurant would be called this, ever. But ask any Singaporean and he or she will tell you that the chao ta, or \u201cburnt\u201d part of a meat dish is usually the best. There\u2019s just something irresistible about the crispy black crust and smoky flavour. That nostalgic flavour is what the folks at this homely eatery aim to showcase in its array of chargrilled mains.\r\n\r\nTheir signature dish is the Pork Ribs, with grilled prime ribs that are crisp on the outside, yet tender and juicy on the inside. To add another dimension of flavour to the dish, it\u2019s served with a homemade spicy dipping sauce and a wedge of lime. Another specialty is the Chaota Fu, an umami dish of deep-fried tofu topped with aburi mentaiko sauce, tobiko, and bonito flakes. Wash the goodness down with an ice-cold glass of their house-concocted Sake Mojito.\r\n\r\nThe desserts, which bring back old school flavours with a twist, are not to be missed either. Fried chicken in Korea is often accompanied by alcohol beverages but those not looking to take advantage of the restaurant's beer and soju offerings can easily content themselves with a traditional bingsu dessert instead. (Nov 2015)", "", "", "Nothing is as you\u2019ll expect when you come for a meal at Chinoiserie. Instead, you\u2019ll find your \u2018dim sum\u2019 presented as a light, fluffy scallop mousse, piped onto a hotate shell with a layer of crab bisque. There\u2019s something new to discover each time you have dinner at Chinoiserie. Chef Justin Quek is no stranger to fine dining cooking, and he\u2019s taken his knowledge of French techniques and married it with his penchant for Asian flavours. \r\n\r\nMenus here are prix fixe or a la carte, and you\u2019ll find seasonal ingredients like French Challan ducks and Manjimup black truffles. Vegetables like artichokes and asparagus are stir-fried Asian-style, rather than served as a Western salad. \r\n\r\nPopular favourites here include a wild coral cod fillet, seared till the scales are crispy and served in a sweet-sour sauce, as well as French poussin stuffed with claypot rice. The structure is a sight to behold: through an ancient Chinese gateway with giant roaring lions guarding either side of its doors lies the Chui Huay Lim Club. Founded in 1845 as a place for prominent Teochew families to meet, you wouldn't guess the site's 166-year history from the brand new building that just opened in October.\nThe home of Singapore's oldest Teochew community club, you can be sure that dining at Chui Huay Lim Teochew Cuisine restaurant is one of the most authentic Teochew experiences possible. Run by the JUMBO Group of Restaurants, the food here has been refined to perfection by the keen eyes of generations of critical Teochew matriarchs. Classic dishes range from Cold Crab to Braised Duck, but for variety you'll also find some familiar favourites like Boiled Live Prawns and Chilli Crab. The seafood comes from tanks lining the restaurant, and was some of the best steamed pomfret the Chope Team has ever had. The house specialty though is clearly the Teochew Style Roasted Suckling Pig, which multi-generations seem to flock to the restaurant for day after day.\nChui Huay Lim Teochew Cuisine offers traditional cuisine in a comfortable and tasteful setting - a must-try dining experience for your entire family, and you don't even need to be a member of the club! Located on level 4 of One Raffles Place, this is the hot pot restaurant to go to after work when you\u2019re craving for something comforting and soupy.\n\nThe soup bases here are extensive, from Herbal Chicken to Tomato and Korean Kimchi flavours. Most interesting is the fish soup with milk, a soup base not commonly found in many hotpot restaurants in town. Order this creamy rich broth and get plenty of seafood to swish in it, such as plump juicy scallops, fresh fish fillets and prawns, homemade prawn paste and clams.\n\nIf you\u2019re a meat lover, City Hot Pot offers quality meats at great value. Tuck into beautifully marbled cuts like wagyu chuck eye roll and Angus short ribs, and savour the meats as the melt easily in your mouth. (Aug 2018)", "Clan Cafe brings the essentials of good living into one ethereal space. The all-day menu delivers nourishing fare that comforts both the palate and the soul with its selection of brunch favourites and East-Asian inspired plates.\r\n\r\n\r\nStart the day off right with a healthy homemade granola, or nosh on brunch staples like smashed avocado toast to a good classic fry-up \u2013 eggs any way you like \u2013 to stay energised throughout the day. Beyond the usual brunch fare, expect hearty offerings with distinctive Asian inflections. Indulge in an irresistible bowl of mussels in an aromatic coconut curry with crusty garlic bread \u2013 perfectly paired with a crisp white wine, tuck into a wholesome miso-roasted salmon brown rice bowl with seaweed and pickled lotus root, or settle for a crowd-pleasing pastrami sandwich with crispy shoestring fries. \r\n\r\n\r\nEnjoy a moment of calm from the daily grind with a slice of your favourite chocolate cake or kueh salat, complemented with a cup of coffee by Papa Palheta or invigorating tea blends by A.muse Projects. Recharge with a variety of locally-brewed kombuchas and cold pressed juices, or relax and unwind with an elegant selection of wines, craft cocktails and premium gin & tonics.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA tropical respite in the heart of the Chinatown precinct, the cafe is here to host your daily breakfast conversations, lunch meetings, and gatherings all throughout the day. The cafe extends to a tropical floral concierge by This Humid House \u2013 set against a whimsical botanical mural by Ripple Root. (Jun 2020)", "At the Cliff, every visit is a fresh experience for the palate, and the mood is fun, yet elegant. A\r\nfreshly-evolved elevated casual dining establishment, the Cliff presents authentic and\r\ncomforting flavours of Italy paired with the heartwarming hospitality. (Nov 2020)", "Glocal is a poor man\u2019s portmanteau for the glamourous local gastronomy presented at The Clifford Pier at The Fullerton Bay Hotel. How else to describe the dizzyingly gorgeous lobby, fluttering with hushed, 5-star service? You\u2019d never know this spot once harboured one of the city\u2019s original bustling ports of call for maritime trade. Since 1933, ships would be warmly greeted with savoury local specialties dished out by floating hawkers. Honouring that charming bit of history, The Clifford Pier acts as a showstopping backdrop for all-day Southeast Asian nibbles.It\u2019s hard to imagine the glittery shores of Marina Bay hosting anything other than the sleek luxuries it's known for, The Fullerton Bay Hotel being its crown jewel. As such, it\u2019s a lovely thought that The Clifford Pier pays respects to the rich tradition of the Bay\u2019s enterprising currents, showcasing the best that Old Singapore has to offer then and now. And The Clifford Pier isn\u2019t paying tribute with just a local-tinted menu, but rather a fully educated selection including rich Laksa, Soup Kambing, The Pier's Lobster Roll, Heritage Bites and Wagyu Rendang.However the homey cuisine doesn\u2019t collide with the frothy aesthetic of the cavernous dining room. As if plucked from the set of a Baz Luhrmann film, the lushly appointed space is swathed in nautical hues of mineral blues, sandy buffs and rich textures. Under ivory arches with a view of the bay, the familiar cuisine at The Clifford Pier is just the opulence you\u2019d expect from The Fullerton Bay Hotel. (Oct 2016)", "The first global outpost of the famous New York institution, Singapore's Clinton Street Baking Company is like a cleaned-up, swisher version of the slightly weathered original that, over almost three decades, has won ceaseless crowds over with its comforting brunch options and charming East Village bonhomie. Already a popular favourite amongst in-the-know brunch crowds here, the Singapore outlet at quiet Purvis Street offers an understated variation of the bustling New York experience.\nAll the classics from its savoury-sweet Southern-style brunch menu are here in Singapore: crispy-skinned and tender Buttermilk Fried Chicken served on maple-kissed waffles, and fluffy hotcakes slicked with warm maple butter then paired with your choice of tangy blueberry compote, chocolate chunks, or banana walnut.\nWhat's brunch without some eggy indulgence? Other New York staples include the ubiquitous Eggs Benedict, here served over a crumbly Southern buttermilk biscuit, and hearty Huevos Rancheros - fried eggs in a party of Mexican beans, guacamole, sour cream, and tomato salsa, all topped with a heap of Monterey Jack, then broiled to cheesy perfection. The unspoken crowning glory here is the brunch cocktails you can get round the clock for that real \"Sex and the City\" touch of weekend revelry; Mimosas, Bellinis and Whisky Sours paired with your carby breakfast keep Brunch O' Clock going before you sensibly sober up with a bracing black coffee and hit the town. (Nov 2016)", "Nestled in the Bukit Pasoh conservation area, Clos Pasoh is a chic reimagining of the French brasserie for today's urbane food and wine lover. Both its menu and wine list reflect current tastes for seriously good things sourced with intent and expertise presented in an unpretentious, casually sophisticated style.Hidden away on the second floor of a heritage building built in the early shophouse style circa 1840, it is named for the clos (meaning a \"walled vineyard\" in French) and the pasoh (a nod to its location and the Malay name for earthen pots used to store water and rice). Every space - from the Dining Room to the Terrace, Wine & Cheese Room and Chef's Table - cradles guests in effortless luxury that is designed to take you from t\u00eate-\u00e0-t\u00eates and power lunches to lazy weekend brunches and lively nights on the town. (Feb 2021)", "", "Look no further than Clove for comfort food with a gourmet touch! Boasting an exciting casual concept, the restaurant impresses with a wide variety of handcrafted burgers that are sustainably sourced alongside healthy salads, irresistible drinks and decadent sweet treats. Great for families, Clove also has a specially curated kids menu to cater to the little ones! \r\n\r\nQuench your thirst at Clove with one of their six boozy milkshakes. A coffee-inspired rendition, the Kopi Cane is infused with a shot of plantation original dark for a strong yet refreshing kick. Known as Singapore\u2019s biggest burger, The Big Devil Burger is a must-order dish that draws in handsome crowds daily. Presented with three signature fries, a portion of this gigantic burger serves up to six pax and consists of braised pulled pork, seared foie gras, cheddar cheese, streaky bacon and a host of other mouthwatering ingredients you simply can\u2019t miss out on trying. \r\n\r\nOther delightful burger and shakers options await you at Clove. This breezy beach bar serves premium beers, house pour spirits, and hearty beach food. It has been a popular spot for families with young children precisely for the kid-friendly food as well as for couples on romantic dates and beach bums who would enjoy the stretch of lovely warm sand. Coastes is the perfect place to chill while indulging in good ol\u2019 comfort food, so tuck into the generous servings of mouthwatering burgers, pizzas, pastas, and delicious fresh seafood, and soak in the resort island-feel and carefree vibe. The meals here are soul-warming and homely, so with the sun, the sand, and the sea, we can't think of a better island getaway less than an hour away from the heart of the city. (Aug 2020)", "An award-winning and dynamic specialty coffee concept from Hong Kong, The Coffee Academ\u00efcs is pioneering a new wave of coffee concepts \u2013 where boundaries are pushed, blends are perfected and beans are brought to flavourful life, all within the most stylish and social of caf\u00e9 backdrops. Sourcing world-class coffee beans with a score of 92 to 94 points by the World Coffee Review \u2013 a \u201cRobert Parker\u2019s Wine Advocate\u201d of the coffee world \u2013 their beans have achieved the distinct honour of being ranked highest in Asia and top three in the world. Launched in 2015, The Coffee Academ\u00efcs is pioneering a new wave of coffee stores in Singapore\u2013 where guests can experience a whole new level of dining with an intricate cup of coffee alongside globally-inspired menu offerings.\r\n\r\nThe smell of freshly roasted coffee hits you as soon as you step into this swish spot, but that\u2019s not the only reason you should come here - their menu is just as enticing as their beverages. Try the Academics Breakfast - it includes every component of a classic American breakfast, but better. Think Maple Bacon, Bockwurst Pork Sausages, and scrambled eggs so creamy they melt in your mouth. For something more wholesome, try the Umami pasta - this dish pays tribute to our garden city by incorporating the familiar local flavour of Hay Bi Hiam (Spicy dried shrimp sambal) into this pasta dish.\r\n\r\nCoffee enthusiasts will love seven stations at the Pedder on Scotts outlet. There\u2019s a station for views into the open kitchen where the food is prepared, and a Hand Brew Bar where customers can sit and enjoy hand brewed coffees of single origin. Diners who prefer leaves to beans will love the Tea Academ\u00efcs station, where they can enjoy a selection of curated teas.
