(Feb 2019)", "The first time we stepped into The Horse's Mouth, we were, quite honestly, stopped mid-gallop. A warm, smoothly finished wood bar, Shoji-inspired light fixtures that dominate the ceiling, and eclectic touches like the bright colour displays, evoke images of autumn and summer. Lit brightly enough for you to appreciate the details, but still seductively dark enough to leave plenty to the imagination, The Horse's Mouth is ahead of the pack when it comes to setting the scene for a great night out.\nIf you're a hungry horse, then don't fret. The snack menu is feedbag full of tasty, with the nonkotsu (chicken softbone), tatami iwashi (dried sardine crackers), and eihire (stingray fins) the ideal bar food to take the edge off. Feeling like you could eat a horse? We don't recommend that, but you'll be happy to know that you can order from Uma Uma's selection of umami ramen for something more robust.\nAs for the thirsty ones, well, the menu looked all well and delicious, but when a joint tells you it's a cocktail bar, then we believe that drinks have to be bespoke. You might have some trouble remembering what exactly was in them after all is said and done, but that's the price you pay for delectable cocktails that run the gamut of sweet, sour, fruity, or just straight up strong. Let them know what you want, and there'll be no horsing around.\nIf you're wondering why, or how, a place can be this slick (or why we made so many bad puns), our advice is not to look a gift horse in the mouth. Round up your drinking buddies, saddle up, and ride on down to The Horse's Mouth. We know a champion when we see one. (May 2014)", "", "This family favourite at Clarke Quay offers a fun communal dining experience with a smoking hot \u201cpre-historic\u201d twist. This restaurant does exactly what it says on the cover: using an ancient, stone-age cooking method, your food arrives raw on the table before gradually cooking on sizzling-hot serpentinite stones from the European Alps that store heat well and, apart from giving your food to a perfect, juicy sear, keeps them warm throughout the meal.\nWith a great view of the river outside, especially from the lofty second floor dining area, part of the charm is a friendly crowd, made up of families and customers who\u2019ve been coming here since 1992. Can you blame them? The premium meats here are cooked to smoky, piping-hot perfection. Choose from beautifully marbled Kurobuta pork or high-grade Tajima Wagyu, both of which sing on the hot stones and soften to sweet, tender, melt-in-your-mouth chunks. If riverside dining is not complete without some seafood, they\u2019ve got hefty slabs of fish steaks, from salmon to cod, as well as Boston lobsters! Come sizzle away on these volcanic stones and get in touch with your pre-historic side! (Oct 2016)", "Quiet Tanglin Mall is a treasure trove of undiscovered F&B gems, and the achingly pretty House of AnLi is probably the shiniest one. An extension of a chi-chi furniture store, the interiors here are, needless to say, well-considered. Handsome wooden touches offset a gorgeous black-and-white theme, with quirky decorations adding some humour to the space. Add some coffee and gorgeous Belgian-inspired plates, and it feels like you\u2019ve walked into the pages of Kinfolk. Whether it\u2019s the baked goods at the counter, a fragrant Mariage Fr\u00e8res tea, or punchy Allpress Coffee, this is the hottest spot for a premium afternoon. There\u2019s also heartier bites like open-faced sandwiches topped with farm-fresh produce: beautiful eggs, vegetables, and meats elegantly arrayed on artisanal bread and drizzled with light dressing. Tuck into Maria\u2019s Moussaka, a cheesy, eggplant-based Belgian \u201clasagna\u201d filled with minced beef and a light bechamel sauce, or the house Carbonnades, a ragout of beef cheek, yellow spud potatoes, tender baby carrots, and a malty Trappiste beer sauce. Chase all of that with an intense chocolate tart, some coffee, and a spot of furniture shopping, some of life\u2019s great pleasures all rolled into one, perfect location. (Apr 2017)", "Swing by the House of Kebab to grab a quick yet mouthwatering shawarma sandwich made from an assortment of freshly roasted meat. Located along Arab street, the restaurant serves up authentic Middle Eastern cuisine that\u2019s delicious and affordable.\r\n\r\nStart off light with the Tabbouleh. A cold appetizer made of chopped parsley, freshly cut tomatoes and garnished with onions, mint and bulgur, this traditional salad is a nutritious way to kickstart your meal. For those who prefer a salad with fewer greens, the Tzatziki is a refreshing salad made with diced cucumbers and strained yoghurt. Tossed in a blend of garlic, salt, olive oil and lemon juice for extra zest, order one before diving into the steamy main courses. \r\n\r\nServed fresh from the grill, the Mix Grill is a combination platter that features different cuts of meat \u2014 perfect for large gatherings. Other signature meat menu options include the Signature Lamb Chop, Shish Kebab and Chicken Kabsa. Sandwiches and wraps are also available here at the House of Kebab. Pair with the Signature Drink Lemonade with Mint for a great meal. (Dec 2020)", "Offering a wide array of exquisite and mouth watering dishes, House of Seafood is a family oriented restaurant serving an extensive range of fresh and savoury seafood dishes. \r\n\r\nBest known for their award-winning Chilli Crab, dig into a wonderful myriad of savoury and sweet flavours accompanied with a lovely side of crispy and fluffy mantou buns. Another one of the restaurant\u2019s signature dishes, the Wok-Fried Cereal Prawn is a plateful of huge prawns deep fried with oats for a crunchy and savoury taste. Fried over high heat, fresh and juicy clams are coated in a fiery layer of sambal sauce, resulting in the well-loved Stir Fried Lala with Sliced Chilli dish. Other side dishes that taste equally delicious include the Steamed Scotland Bamboo Clams with Minced Garlic. Sprinkled atop the steamed clams, the chopped garlic enhances the flavour and fragrance of this dish, making it a huge hit among both the young and old. \r\n\r\nThe star of the show at House of Seafood is definitely the stunning Seafood Tower. Consisting seven layers of seafood, indulge in your favourite seafood with a steaming pot of highly addictive broth. (Nov 2020)", "Mention 180 Yio Chu Kang and your thoughts might jump to House of Seafood. Started in 2008, this restaurant has garnered plenty of fans willing to queue for their fresh seafood and mouth-watering crab dishes, and has now found a spot at The Punggol Settlement.It\u2019d be best to go in a group because you won\u2019t want to order just two dishes off the menu. Pan Fried Chicken Cutlet with Special Sauce, Steamed Marble Goby with Soya Sauce, and Saut\u00e9ed Fresh Hokkaido Scallops with Broccoli are some of the a la carte options you can have, but save some stomach space for their signature crabs. There\u2019re the ever popular options of chilli and black pepper, but for something a little richer, House of Seafood\u2019s salted egg and creamy butter versions are deliciously sinful. What was once at Yio Chu Kang is now at Punggol and the lines are still as long as ever. Who says there aren\u2019t any restaurants in the North worth traveling for? (Dec 2015)", "Nestled in Orchard Hotel since 1992, the award-winning Hua Ting Restaurant boasts an amazing repertoire of Cantonese plates.\r\n\r\nEmbark on your Hua Ting journey with the Baked Mango Chicken Tartlet. The tartlet\u2019s crust crumbles in your mouth, revealing a filling of soft, buttery chicken and mango chunks. Complement this starter with a basket of Steamed Seafood Dumpling Abalone. The thin, doughy skin breaks apart with a bite before the succulent, briny abalone greets your tastebuds.\r\n\r\nBrace your stomach for Hua Ting\u2019s signature Crispy Roasted Duck. Here, the duck fat\u2019s been skillfully rendered off, resulting in a crispy layer of caramelised skin that\u2019s accompanied by tender duck meat. If you prefer something lighter, refresh your palate with the Dong Xing Garoupa Rice. A simmering broth is poured over slices of premium fish, cooking the meat instantly. This comforting dish seals the deal with its crispy rice that adds a crunchy texture to the broth.\r\n\r\nRound off your experience at this family-friendly restaurant with the Mango Pur\u00e9e, Pomelo, Sago, and Herbal Jelly, a twist on the familiar Cantonese dessert. (Jul 2017)", "This funky Italian restaurant presents traditional Italian fare in relaxed but hip digs overlooking a lovely green patch of the Stevens Road area. Think well-made authentic pasta plates here, none of that watered-down business you tend to find in Italian joints around the city. The Bucatini All\u2019Amatriciana is a heavenly plate of tubular spaghetti tossed in a spicy, porky sauce of tomatoes, cured Guanciale (pork cheek), and tangy pecorino cheese. The Carbonara is a close cousin, made with a cheese and egg sauce instead of tomato, and prepared exactly as it is in Rome, with lashings of spicy rendered lard, black pepper, and no cream whatsoever. Grilled steaks and fish round out the menu, though honestly we think the hefty pizza and pasta plates will keep even the greediest of diners happy. (Jun 2017)", "Indocafe's grand black-and-white compound is a historic remnant of Singapore's past, so it's only fitting the cuisine boasts equal cultural significance. In an interior done up to look like a warm dining room - parquet floors, Peranakan antiques, and cosy lighting - orders are brought to your table with little fanfare, confident in their authentic flavours and contemporary touches.\nFundamental Nyonya techniques, classic recipes, and fresh spices, pounded together using the tried-and-true pestle and mortar method, result in fragrant traditional offerings like Kueh Pie Tee (crisp pastry cups filled with shredded turnip, served with prawns, crabmeat, and homemade chili dip), Ngoh Hiang (homemade five-spiced pork meat roll wrapped in soy bean curd skin and deep fried), and Organic Ayam Buah Keluak (braised organic chicken with black nut and exotic spices).\nThat's not to say that Indocafe is stuck in the past though; little tweaks to suit modern tastes are a constant feature in their menu. Feast on dishes such as the Otah Klasik (steamed 'Chawanmushi' egg custard with fish fillet, seasoned with coconut milk, and a special blend of herb and spices) and Chendol Panna Cotta, both great examples of when past and present collide.\nOnce you're done tasting a slice of Singapore's heritage, don\u2019t forget to trot over to their Arts & Cultural Central where a little coffee appreciation and afternoon performance might go a long way! (Jun 2018)", "Making the luxurious Four Seasons its home, the equally majestic Jiang-Nan Chun consistently wows diners with their exquisite, award-winning gastronomy. Head up a flight of marble stairs and you will find yourself at a regal labyrinth with opulent furnishings - think intricately carved wood, plush leather couches, and handsome carpets - fit for an emperor's palace.\nEnjoy some top-notch Cantonese fare here, including chef-crafted dim sums, double-boiled soups, and Jiang-Nan Chun's signature Peking Duck roasted in a mesquite wood-fired oven and served with caviar. This traditional technique roasts the skin to a satisfying crisp while keeping the duck meat juicy and succulent; take a little dollop of caviar with the red meat to elevate the dish with a subtle sweet-salty aftertaste.\nGorgeous double-boiled soups such as the Hot & Sour Soup with Lobster or the signature Sea Whelk, Maka, Dried Scallops & Pork Ribs Soup are not to be missed either: wholesome ingredients are boiled for more than 15 hours to make soups that are rich, sweet, and highly nutritious. Other highlights include exquisite dim sum favourites such as the Steamed Scallop Dumpling with Crab Meat & Shrimp and the Baked Flaky Pastry with Smoked Ham, along with live seafood dishes such as the impeccably fresh Live Prawns and Dragon Tiger Garoupa.\nWith a bevy of lavish eats to choose from, one visit to Jiang-Nan Chun is definitely not enough! (Sep 2017)", "Jigger & Pony set the bar \u2014 literally \u2014 for craft cocktails in 2012, when they opened their doors at Amoy Street. Vodka Sodas. Gin & Sonics. The higher level of craft we reach, the more we feel the need to strip it all back to basics. There\u2019s Whisky Highball and what\u2019s make it special is that Hokkaido super soft water (maewari) is mixed with whisky, creating a softer blend. (Sep 2018)", "", "Mention Ka-Soh to any self-respecting Singaporean and the reaction is always one of joy and enthusiasm. Ka-Soh, an institution beloved for its comforting, flavourful fish noodle soup, is a firm favourite across all generations.Available in a few variations based on the choice of the various parts of the Snakehead Fish, Ka-Soh\u2019s Signature Fish Noodle Soup is milky, tangy, and robust. The juicy white rice noodles, together with the fragrant fish broth and crunchy vegetables, make it an unforgettable combination. Other zi char favourites, such as Prawn Paste Chicken, are also available on the menu. Each piece of the chicken is marinated with a generous coating of prawn paste before being deep-fried to a rich, golden-brown colour. Eaten piping hot, this dish is highly addictive.  Another crowd-pleaser is the Fish Slices with Tossed Hor Fun and Bean Sprouts. Deceptively simple, the potent flavour of the dish comes from achieving the perfect balance between the saltiness of the fish against the crunchiness of the vegetables, as well as the softness of the hor fun noodles. Having been around for more than 40 years, and with an extensive array of traditional zi char dishes, plus its Signature Fish Noodle Soup, it is easy to see why Ka-Soh occupies a special place in every Singaporean foodie\u2019s heart. This cafe and bar along Purvis Street is decorated in a cosy and chic fashion, taking inspiration from old-school games like Snakes & Ladders and Tetris. Spot the hanging ladder against the brick wall, or the drinks\u2019 coasters made with Scrabble tiles! Choose your favourite from a selection of over 300 board games, and order up some tasty nibbles to share. The camembert brulee is perfect for two to three, where you get slices of crostini to dip into the wheel of gooey cheese, along with some roasted grapes and pears. Grilled cheese sandwich gets a quirky twist with the addition of date bacon jam, and if you\u2019re here for brunch, don\u2019t miss the spiced apple French toast with nutty maple bacon and swirls of salted caramel. Recharge your brain with a selection of locally-roasted coffees, or craft beers and cocktails if you\u2019re playing on into the night! (Oct 2018)", "Delivering amazing flavours at great value, King Army Stew is dedicated to bringing you an authentic taste of Korea in a fun, intimate and casual setting. Located in Fortune Centre, the eatery is conveniently located within walking distance from Bugis MRT station.\r\n\r\nWith four types of stew available at King Army Stew, diners will find themselves spoilt for choice. The Classic Army Stew is a brimming pot of onions, lettuce, luncheon meat, bacon, kimchi, mushrooms and more stewed in the eatery\u2019s homemade spicy paste, topped with a yummy layer of cheddar cheese. Add-ons such as chicken franks, tteokbokki and other seafood delights are also available. Crafted by their very own Korean chef, this steaming hot stew was specially modified to suit local taste buds!\r\n\r\nComplete your meal with King Army Stew\u2019s signature Kimchi and Bacon Pancake. Seafood lovers can opt for the Seafood Pancake instead. Stuffed with squid, prawn, scallop and cheese, this delicious rendition of the classic Korean delight is not to be missed out on! Those with a lighter palette will enjoy the Beef Bulgogi Stew. Peppered with fresh mushrooms, glass noodles and marinated beef bulgogi in a clean taste broth, this menu option is great for sharing. (Mar 2021)", "A heavyweight in the sushi counter-culture, Kinki Restaurant has been wowing the hip and tasteful crowds along Marina Bay for years, and the throngs of merrymakers show no signs of slowing down. Situated atop the Customs House building with knockout views of MBS, it's no surprise to learn that Kinki has some celebrity backing. However, given the edgy, underground vibe of the place, it makes sense that the celebrity in question is a fictional sumo wrestler, who defies all odds to allow his culinary alter ego to shine. His story is etched all over the restaurant and bar, from the wild floor mural by an artist of \"Miami Ink\" TV fame, to the graffiti clad walls and comic book styled menu.\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\nDespite the laidback persona of the place - with sneaker-wearing waitstaff and up-to-the-moment beats always pumping - the cuisine at Kinki Restaurant is nonetheless inventive, high-end and would make the restaurant's namesake proud. A palatable selection of mains includes the High Roller Wagyu Don - features ohmi A4 wagyu, Hokkaido uni, ikura, summer black truffle, onsen egg, Premium Unagi Claypot with homemade umami sauce and more. There's also traditional sushi and sashimi handled by masterful chefs behind the ice bar. \"Rock & Roll\" offers an interesting mix of creative maki rolls that lesser sushi restaurants are too risk-averse to try.\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\nIf there ever were a sushi bar bold enough to go for it, while still paying respects to the artistry of the cuisine, Kinki would be it. The Foie Gras and Scallop Nigiri features delicate, pan seared foie with a plump, juicy Hokkaido-bred scallop, while the Golden Age offers an expert balance of meaty fish and bright fruit. There are more filling mains and cleverly crafted cold dishes as well, a selection that is well suited for any range of hunger.\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\nOn the alfresco front, level three rooftop bar is a frequent hangout for the after-work crowd, with a plentiful selection of sake as well as the envelope-pushing cocktails you would expect from such a thrilling spot as Kinki. Long-standing favourites are the Kinki Mango Mint and Gin Berry. Their food menu also features an array of small bites such as Karaage Chicken Bao and Squid and chips.\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\nNow a well-established mainstay along the Marina Bay waterfront, rest assured there are no kinks to be worked out in Kinki Restaurant's daring and delicious concept. (Aug 2020)", "The brainchild of Chef and founder Benjamin Tilatti, Kinou is both an eclectic infusion of fond memories and robust flavours, as well as a heartfelt ode to Benjamin\u2019s mother, who ignited his passion for cooking and whose nickname is honoured in the restaurant name.No wonder that Kinou makes for the perfect place to share a meal with friends and family. The concept\u2019s Basque tapas (pintxos), designed for sharing, include several favourites like the Basque Taloa (a powerful combination of duck confit, Foie Gras, and cheese).Unabashed meat-lovers who prefer something heavier will find their wildest dreams fulfilled with the Xuleta (OP Rib), sinfully cooked in duck fat and butter, and featuring onion compote and hand-cut fries.For some smashing dessert, we wholeheartedly recommend the real and traditional Gateau Basque.Wash it all down with over 100 wines picked out by the Chef himself, and you've got yourself a treat that you will remember! (Mar 2021)", "Indonesian cuisine has much to offer - we've had those cravings for addictive sambal heat, tender rendang, not to mention the depth and savouriness that come from a masterful combination of spices - and Furama RiverFront's halal-certified Kintamani Restaurant is a fantastic place to savour it all.\nA delectable buffet spread boasts authentic bites like Gado Gado Jakarta (a traditional mix of vegetables and peanut sauce) and Mee Soto Ayam (egg noodles in clear chicken broth topped with shredded chicken), as well as mains such as Rendang Daging Sumatra (richly spiced beef braised in thick coconut gravy) and Tahu Telur Surabaya (deep-fried beancurd and egg tossed with grated vegetables and spicy sauce).\nSecond guessing your choice to go a la carte? Don't worry, that menu is equally packed with enticing delights like Udang Goreng Mentega (deep-fried buttered prawns tossed with egg yolk and curry leaves), Sate Lilit Bali (minced seafood skewered with lemongrass Balinese style), and Rojak Mangga Muda (Indonesian young mango salad) - all paired with fragrant rice, of course.\nThese traditional beauties and fusion fare are the work of talented Chef I Gusti Nyoman Kaler and his team, so if you've got a sudden desire for lovely Indonesian plates, trot down to Kintamani where their expertise will leave you with a leisurely meal or delicious takeaway. (Feb 2021)", "Kiyoshi Japanese Restaurant specialises in Inaniwa udon, a type of udon made in the Inaniwa area of Inakawa Machi, Akita prefecture. Slightly thinner than your regular udon but thicker than somen or hiyamugi noodles, this cream coloured udon is hand-stretched for that great bite.\r\n\r\nWith a main focus in providing light and wholesome dishes, try a hefty selection of chilled and warm udon, as well as Nabe Mono, with udon in a hotpot \u2014 there\u2019s also a kimchi edition! (Aug 2017)", "Kotuwa is Chef Rishi Naleendra's highly anticipated third and brand new venture. With an emphasis on a lively, modern and casual vibe that focuses on traditional Sri Lankan cuisine, Kotuwa pays homage to the 35-year-old's Sri Lankan heritage.Kotuwa, named after the Sri Lankan capital's central business district, aims to bring the sights, sounds and tastes from Sri Lankan's streets and markets to the Singapore diner. It also means \"fort\" in Sinhalese, a reminder of the ancient landmarks built by Sinhalese kings and the Portuguese, Dutch and British settlers that have influenced the country's rich history, culture and cuisine.Embodying Sri Lanka's vibrant and generous way of life, diners can expect bright, creative dishes made from quality ingredients that are as robust and flavourful as the culture and history that inspire them. From famous Sri Lankan short eats, to a myriad of curries and housemade sambols and preserves, Kotuwa looks forward to spicing-up and invigorating diners' palates, one meal at a time! (Nov 2020)", "", "La Pizzeria at the Bridge & Beacon Bar is an authentic Italian Restaurant with the guidance of Italian Chef Francesco Romano.\n\nChef Francesco bring the Romano Family culture to Singapore through his Grandmother recipes to the kitchen set up of the restaurant.\n\nWith the warm breeze rolling in from the Gulf of Naples into their rustic kitchen in Lettere, Gennaro Romano and his wife Anna worked diligently with partial skim milk to create the \u201cCaseificio Romano\u201d - a cheese house. This was in the heart of the 1925. The Mozzarella was traditionally made of buffalo milk, Gennaro introduced in his factory a combination of whole cow milk producing a \u201cFior di Latte\u201d. This mozzarella was sold and distributed from its humble origins in Lettere throughout the Naples, spanning from the Salerno to the rocky cliffs of Roma.\n\n\u200bIn 1961, Caseificio Factory changed hands, passing to Gennaro\u2019s son, Vittorio. He kept the original name of the factory and increased production. The family-run cheese factory became well known within Italy for its handmade authentic buffalo Mozzarella and Fior di Latte and up today Vittorio\u2019s son Francesco, continues the tradition from the creation, to the production, to the sales of Caseificio hand-crafted cheeses and as corporate Chef of Italian restaurant chain in Italy and Dubai.\n\nChef Francesco\u2019s passion and expertise are in each single dish of La Pizzeria at the Bridge & Beacon Bar, all made respecting the traditional recipe of his Grandmother and with the same passion, he trained all our resident Chef.\n\nSo come taste a piece of Italy right here in Singapore. These family recipes have been handed down for generations. Be our guest - you will feel right at home. Gently lit by red lanterns, its walls are decorated with graffiti-esque pop art, with neon signs providing an extra je ne sais quoi. Be sure to try their Imperial Double Boiled Soup, accompanied with premium nu er hong. Alternatively, the Pan-seared Salmon that is infused with Japanese mirin, and further seasoned with bearnaise sauce and baby romaine is also a standout.\r\n\r\nNo meal is complete without some dessert! Be sure to try Le Fusion's excellent Chendol, topped with coconut milk and Bailey's cream, for an additional pick-me-up! (Dec 2019)", "", "Meat is the name of the game at Le Rida in Bukit Timah, a cosy little eatery that specializes in mezze-style grilled meats and steaks. Riding on its mezze theme, communal dining is encouraged, and a big part of the menu is shared platters of pitas and hearty Middle-Eastern dips like hummus, Iabneh, and motabal, which whet your appetite for the main part of your meal: the grilled meats.\nA mix of Middle-Eastern skewering and French-style grills, the menu here features classics like spicy tender lamb-mince kofta kebabs served on saffron rice and crunchy greens, minced chicken kebabs flavoured with Iranian spices, and flame-grilled seafood kebabs. These rub shoulders with French classics like French onion soup, grilled foie gras in a savoury-sweet orange sauce, and other carnivorous plates like crisp-skinned duck confit, a rich fricassee of chicken with cepes mushrooms, and a selection of premium flame-grilled Angus and Wagyu beef steaks, each steak served with a classic Bordelaise sauce, pomme frites, and buttered haricot beans. At Le Rida, there\u2019s a little bit of something for different carnivorous appetites. Plus you get to jump across continents and cuisines, all at the same dinner table! (Jan 2016)", "With a sleek modern d\u00e9cor and cosy ambiance, Leopold, a 40 seater restaurant on Tanjong Pagar serves the first of its kind in Singapore, the AGS menu. AGS stands for Austrian, German and Swiss. The concept of sharing plates, a half portion of the main course plating was the idea by owner, Klaus Leopold. He wanted to give guest the opportunity to savour common cuisines of German speaking countries.\nChoose from Leopold\u2019s modern take on the beef goulash, using wagyu beef slow cooked for 3 hours, traditional food like Swiss R\u00f6sti or the Austrian Leberk\u00e4ssemmel (meat loaf bread roll sandwich) as well as German sausages and Flammkuchen.  Match your dinner from the over 50 labels of wine or try Leopold\u2019s own spirit brand, Leopold organic sloe gin or the list of own cocktail concoctions.\nServed with passion, modern yet original is the key. It\u2019s clear to see why Leopold guarantees a great time with your friends and colleagues. (Mar 2018)", "It\u2019s modern French cooking that\u2019s served at Lerouy. True to the modern ethos that permeates the entire establishment, the setting features an elegant, winding counter which curves around an open kitchen. The restaurant offers a tasting menu which evolves and changes from time to time, but which constantly features exciting creations with the chef\u2019s strong individual stamp. Diners can choose between the Petit or Grand options, with the difference being the number of courses. The only thing predictable about Lerouy is the consistently excellent cooking which never fails to impress, so do head down sometime soon and give it a go! (Oct 2020)", "", "", "A classic destination for the tradition of bistro style steaks and the ever important French fry, Les Bouchons is certain to become your next go-to steakhouse.\n\nThe look of Les Bouchons defies any whim of trendiness and sticks to the standards of bistro design: curvy backed chairs and white tablecloths simply dressed with the essential fork, steak knife, burgundy napkin, and wine glass, sit upon tiled floors both inside and out on the charming patio. The shophouse locale fits the look, transporting the restaurant to a simpler time and slowed down pace in small town France. And with the upcoming selection of to-die-for steaks and free flow fries, you'll be glad to feel the minutes slipping by at their leisure.\n\nStart with the Os A Moelle, or beef bone marrow served with crisp toasts. The meaty butter-like spread is indulgently delicious, and an ideal primer to the protein heavy meal. The mains are simply stated, and all come with sides of salad and endless frites. The Grilled Sirloin Steak with Herbs is a particular star as is \"The Real Entrecote\" from Normandy, which is best to be shared among pairs. The steaks are clearly of premium quality and cooked to rosy pink perfection with a caramelised char on the outside. The accompanying fries are of medium thickness with fluffed centers and crisped coatings, ideal for dipping into the classic sauces of mustards, bernaise, mayonnaise and horseradish.\n\nHowever, the steak haven is no one-trick pony. On the weekends, the talented kitchen pulls out all the stops with the Couscous Royal, a tempting platter of marinated and grilled lamb, chicken and Merguez sausage upon a flavored bed of couscous. Or else try the Jumbo Prawn, kissed by the grill and drizzled with olive oil to bring out the natural sweetness of the crustacean. The dish is another reminder from Les Bouchons that French cooking needs only the very basics to be done well. (Feb 2021)", "Standing at 156 meters above ground level, LeVeL33 literally rises above all breweries as the world's first microbrewery installed at the penthouse of a skyscraper. Located on the 33rd floor of Marina Bay Financial Centre, the restaurant houses 8,000 kg of state-of-the-art microbrewery equipment in a spacious restaurant featuring breath-taking panoramic views of Singapore skyline, as well as an open-air Terrace.\r\n\r\nLeVeL33 offers guests a multi-zone dining experience and ambiance, from refined privacy to social revelry.\r\n\r\nThe refined LeVeL33 Dining Room exudes a mellow ambiance suited to business lunches, dinners and/or special occasions and is specially designed to ensure more comfort and privacy.\r\n\r\nLeVeL33 Social was designed for social interaction and encourages a buoyant atmosphere for guests to relax. With sharing menu and the new Raw Bar that offers an array of seafood such as oysters, guests are able to enjoy a truly heightened dining experience. (Jul 2019)", "Named after the famous Tang-dynasty poet, the ambience at this Sheraton Towers stalwart is a feat in and of itself. Think Jade table settings, bone chopsticks, and discreet waitstaff. The dining concept here harkens back to the days of grand Emperors in China, so you can expect fresh ingredients and premium nosh in an equally opulent setting. Located centrally, the menus here cater to a variety of diners, so whether you\u2019re after a exquisite business lunch or a cosy dinner, veteran chef Chung Yiu Ming\u2019s delicious creations have got you covered.\nThe executive lunch set is a big hit with office workers, as is the dim sum menu, which features an array of delicate nibbles crafted with premium ingredients. (Apr 2018)", "Inspired by their illustrious maritime history, Lighthouse Bistro shines brightly in a little corner off Jellicoe Road. Since 2003, it has provided both members and non-members of the Singapore Maritime Officers\u2019 Union with a place to socialise and unwind. If you want to enjoy fresh and tasty seafood in a good ambience, you won\u2019t go wrong with Lighthouse Bistro.\nIf you\u2019re in a big group, pay homage to the bistro\u2019s past by having the Fishermen\u2019s Board - a platter of tiger prawns, fresh blue mussels, crispy Atlantic dory, and garlicky, spicy batavia squid. Enjoy the Milk-Battered Calamari that is topped with copious amount of chicken floss and tangy lemon tartar sauce. For mains, the Fishermen\u2019s Angel Hair is a great fusion noodle dish with a spicy sambal kick. If seafood is not your thing, fear not! Soaked in a special marinate for 24 hours, the Honey Charred Chicken emerges completely tender and succulent, definitely a crowd favourite for a reason. For a sweet finish, try Mary\u2019s Butter Cake, which is a buttery vanilla cake topped with either chocolate or vanilla ice cream, cookie crumbles, and berries.\nThe team at Lighthouse Bistro is extremely dedicated and driven to create good memories for you. Since its founding, it has undergone three major revamps to provide a refreshing experience. By providing quality at affordable prices, it is of little wonder that many of the diners are repeat customers. For those looking to experience the trinity of great food, great price, and great ambience, look no further than Lighthouse Bistro! (Nov 2016)", "Here at Chope, we are willing to do a lot for great eats. But if satisfying our Caribbean cravings means taking a long haul flight to the western hemisphere, that's where we draw the line. Thankfully, all we need is a trip to Chinatown, where buzz-worthy Lime House Caribbean Restaurant & Bar is just the place to get our Caribbean eat, drink, and party on!\n \nSet in a beautifully restored shop house, the ambiance prepares you for \"liming\", which is Caribbean lingo for chilling with friends. Given rave reviews for its authentic island cuisine - a rare find in Singapore - Lime House Caribbean is a mecca for those looking to indulge in good vibes, friendly gatherings and a Caribbean menu devised by their head chef from Barbados, Kirk Brathwaite. Having had extensive experience working at some of the most luxurious resorts in the Caribbean, he means serious business when it comes to churning out delicious fare.\n \nKirk puts his spin on classics but isn't afraid to introduce new and exciting dishes that evoke the Caribbean. Pepper Shrimp, Seafood Cakes, Calypso Fish, Blue Mountain Steak, Fire Roasted Stuffed Sweet Potato, and Tropics Cheesecake, it's an endless list of punchy flavours. With a \u201cwelcome home\u201d philosophy at the core of the Lime House Caribbean Experience, diners are also free to make themselves comfortable by sharing hearty platters of Wings, Sliders, and an assortment of other trademark Caribbean bites that are sure to become favourites.\n \nRenowned philosopher Captain Jack Sparrow once posed the existential question, \"But why is the rum gone\"? Well, we're happy to confirm that it isn't, and that Lime House Caribbean has a plentiful stash that would make any pirate jealous! That being said, you are encouraged to continue your liming on the second floor, with a classic punch in hand! (Sept 2019)", "If hotpot\u2019s your thing, Little Sheep Hotpot spot is sure to be right up your alley! Founded in the early 2000s in Inner Mongolia, this greenhorn shook up the hotpot scene in China with their innovative hotpot -- minus the dipping sauce. Their rich broth all but made up for the lack of condiments, and the recipe has stayed consistent for over eighteen years. What\u2019s so special about the broth? The savoury soup base, made with seven special spices and mutton from Inner Mongolia, retains its signature flavour even after long hours of boiling. \r\n\r\nThe Four Mushroom Soup is one of their most popular broths. Earthy and not too spicy, this base choice adds richness to all the items added. Meat-lovers are sure to enjoy the array of dishes on offer for the hotpot. The Australia Sirloin Beef Cubes are rich and buttery, and absorb the spices of the soup, enhancing the meat\u2019s flavour with a spicy kick. One of their most raved options for hotpot is the Lamb Roll, which consists of paper-thin slices of lamb rolled into small tubes. The meat cooks quickly and is thin enough to soak up all the broth\u2019s flavours. The lamb cuts are available on their own or as a combination with beef slices. (Nov 2019)", "Live Twice, the Jigger & Pony Group\u2019s newest cocktail establishment, is an intimate cocktail bar that takes inspiration from the mid-century modern era in Japan. Vintage fittings and cosy alcoves transport guests to the heart of Tokyo \u2014 notably post-war Ginza in the \u201860s.\r\n\r\nThe minimalist menu features 14 cocktails, each carefully crafted to celebrate the true character of spirits. (Feb 2021)", "In 2014, Aussie Chef Darren Farr started The Lokal, an Australian Restaurant-Bar, providing customers with homemade comfort food \u2014 including butter, sauces, pickles and meats all made on site. Our name is German for local, an influence that be explained by its proximity to Goethe-Institut Singapore and is also reflective of our diverse and worldly approach towards food that can be enjoyed by the people in Singapore. \nIn the day, he serves up healthy and hearty brunches but slowly transits into a cozy and versatile space for intimate dinners & casual cocktails sessions with comfort food by German Head Chef Max Strauch. Aside from the normal menus, both Chef Darren & Max also prepare Daily Specials with fresh seasonal produces for Brunch & Dinner, like Victorian Truffles & White Asparagus.\n\nChef Darren Farr, more prominently known by his Instagram followers as \u2018fuzzychef\u2019, used to work at Tetsuya\u2019s in Sydney, before working at various restaurants across London and Hong Kong.\n\nChef Max Strauch spent most of his childhood growing up in Jakarta (which explains how he can speak fluent Bahasa) before heading back to Germany to further his culinary journey, spending years in Cookies Cream, a popular vegetarian fine dining restaurant in Berlin. The well-travelled Chef Max also worked in Hamburg & Australia before settling into The Lokal in Singapore, showcasing his style of comfort food with great produce.\n \nSo the next time you swing by, pull out a seat at the kitchen counter and have a chat with the chefs to find out more about the food you\u2019re eating at The Lokal! (Apr 2018)", "Drawing from its underground supper club roots, Lolla fits right in on Ann Siang Hill with a petite but confident concept featuring uncompromising ingredients transformed into renowned small plates.\nIf you think modern design, communal dining, artisan ingredients and small plates could be the description of any number of popular nouveau restaurants in Singapore, you'd be right. However, Lolla has proven itself to be the cream of the crop, as evidenced by the standard wait list for a reservation to sample their fare. Here's some insider intel: book for lunch, where you can request a seat at the coveted bar (which is saved for those few well-timed walk-ins come dusk) and avoid the feeding frenzy of dinner time service. Why is the zinc-plated bar the place to be? From here, you can watch the compact kitchen create the wondrous small plates that have earned Lolla international acclaim.\nSuch plates include the Sea Urchin Pudding, a deceivingly miniature vessel of deadly-rich egg yolk custard, blackened by squid ink and topped with tangerine-coloured morsels of urchin plucked straight from the ocean. The dish is at once thick and light, the depths of umami refreshed by a spritz of the sea. The Beef Tongue Escalopes are similarly brilliant, tenderized to banish any minerally gristle and which presents a unique meaty flavour spiked by pickled sides. The Scrambled Eggs with Bottarga is a high-end play on the smoked salmon breakfast staple, the feathery eggs punctuated by shavings of fish roe. All dishes benefit from a glass of bubbly, which is intentionally the bar's specialty. It's a fitting choice since the extraordinary dining experience at Lolla isn't exactly a steal, making it ideal for special occasions.\nIn the basement, a large, democratic table-for-all accommodates the majority of diners, a design choice that loosens up the mood. The concrete and bare bulb ascetic is softened by vintage touches like antique crystal vases posted alongside family-sized cans of artisan ingredients atop the bar. The menus are simply stated and printed with Victorian comics on paper placemats. The d\u00e9cor, along with the exceptional culinary musings served, ensure that Lolla really lives up to the hype. (Jul 2014)", "", "Singapore\u2019s leading seafood restaurant and creator of the original and best black pepper crab since 1982, Long Beach Seafood invites you to enjoy a vast array of exclusive live seafood delicacies. \r\n\r\nCoated with piquant black pepper sauce and stir-fried, the Original Black Pepper Crab is a signature seafood dish that is not to be missed out on. Another all time bestseller, the Scottish Razor Clam is steamed in a light and aromatic sauce with minced garlic and vermicelli, topped off with luscious royal razor clams and a crunchy smattering of fried garlic. Other mouthwatering seafood dishes include the Air Flown Live Alaskan King Crab, Southern Australian Lobster and Dungeness Crab. \r\n\r\nFor a different dining experience, smaller groups can opt to try out the sampling menu. Specially curated to serve and satisfy diners in small portions, the food selection consists of a variety of local favourites. Sweet and spicy, the Grilled Chicken Satay skewer features a savoury peanut sauce glazed with pineapple puree and paired with cucumber and onion slices. Cooked in a delectable chilli gravy with generous bits of fresh crab meat, the famous Chilli Crab is best enjoyed with sake or beer. (Jul 2016)", "Singapore\u2019s quintessential local rooftop bar, Loof, opened its doors to happy revellers back in 2005. Named in a playful reference to the idiosyncrasies of local speech and culture, \u2018loof\u2019 is a play on the way Singaporeans pronounce \u2018roof\u2019. Awarded as Singapore's best rooftop bar, Loof serves up quality whimsy, fresh nostalgia and unbridled playfulness in an urban garden atop Odeon Towers in downtown CBD.\r\n\r\nEnjoy carefully crafted Southeast Asian inspired cocktails that are familiar yet unique. Cocktails in the limelight include Firecracker, a gin-based concoction that playfully pairs the flavours of watermelon and chilli with just the right amount of spice to pack a punch. Another must-try is Rum, Forrest, Rum, a refreshing blend of dark rum, pandan-infused Amaro Montenegro and pineapple husk-infused syrup. The Set B is a buzzy spin on the Singaporean breakfast staple of traditional kopi and kaya toast with vodka, Mr. Black coffee liqueur, kaya and espresso.\r\n\r\nIn nostalgic tribute to Loof\u2019s earlier years, signatures such as the Loof Bubble Tea and the cheeky Uncle Tee-Kee continue as mainstays on the menu. For guests seeking other speciality libations, Loof also offers a wide variety of Asian spirits, from Japanese whiskies and sake to local craft beers Sunday\u2019s Brew and Lion Brewery.\r\n\r\nThe cuisine, aptly coined \u2018Dude-Sin\u2019 (Dude-Singaporean), is a modern Singaporean riff on typical bar grub done in a style that is anything but \u2018atas\u2019. Divided into four categories: chip chip, sticks and balls, and buns, the menu features bar snacks full of local flavour from every Singaporean\u2019s favourite Chilli Crab Dip to our bold take on the notorious Ramly Burger.\r\n\r\nAfter all this time, Loof continues to offer the best view of the Raffles Hotel and her surrounding area and remains one of the hippest and funkiest places to meet old friends and make new ones. There\u2019s a palpable energy that permeates the bar, and sitting there, amidst the skyscrapers, urban gardens, and buzzing crowd of locals, expatriates and tourists, you can\u2019t help but be swept up in that pulse of the city night. Step through the glass doors for a haven of gourmet burgers, decadent lobster rolls and quality steak cuts. \r\n\r\nOne of the first concepts to introduce lobster rolls to Singapore in 2013, expect market fresh produce chargrilled to perfection in the specially imported \"Woodstone\" Charbroiler. Savour the taste of the ocean in the heart of Singapore. (Mar 2019)", "Everything about the Marmalade Pantry, from the rich sticky goodness of the name to its reputation as one of the city's favourite bistros, speaks of delicious, indulgent afternoons spent gossiping over impeccable treats and beverages. But beyond afternoon tea, this Downtown location is also perfect for a solid meal, serving up beautiful plates of modern comfort food with a distinct modern-European meets Asian sensibility in swish, modern digs.\r\n \r\nFor a start, nothing says indulgence quite like a luxury burger, and both the Truffle Beef Burger and Spicy Sriracha Burger has that in spades. Filled with juicy goodness and using 200g (USDA) meat, the Truffle Beef Burger is both tender and flavourful while the Spicy Sriracha Burger is filled with spiced chicken patty, sriracha mayo, blue cheese and parmesan fries.  For a lighter meal, the Caesar and Kale Salad and the Grilled Pear and Arugula Salad are the go-to dishes for something refreshing and healthy. (Oct 2020)", "Past the doors, a conservation shophouse in trendy Telok Ayer melts away into a bamboo-clad, softly-lit sushi bar redolent with the aromas of soy sauce, fresh seafood, and sake. Behind the bar, the diligent Chef Derrick Lau chats up some guests at the bar while delivering plate after plate of sushi made from the freshest catch of the day. There\u2019s not much of a menu here, just a few tiers of set meals, filled up by whatever the chef decides is best to serve that day. Omakase is the word, and you leave your meal in the capable hands of the chef and his direct-from-Japan supply chain.\nDepending on the season, feast on tender slices of monk fish liver, creamy cod milt, fatty tuna belly, and year-round favourites like sea bream, salmon, yellow tail, and horse mackerel. Chef Lau, a huge favourite among Japanese cuisine connoisseurs in Singapore, is well-known for his innovative and sophisticated omakase menus, so whenever you drop by, you\u2019re in for a treat. If you\u2019re not looking for a special-occasion omakase meal, there are bento-style set dinners here too, like pan fried beef, seasonal sashimi and tempura on rice, Wagyu steak, and a bountiful Bara Chirashi, a bowl of rice topped with chopped sashimi. Whatever your needs, budget, and desire for indulgence, there\u2019s something for you at MARUKYU: it\u2019ll be a meal to remember. (Nov 2016)", "An authentic Japanese restaurant serving healthy dishes in the heart of Singapore with its origin in Japan since 1962 as the whole seller of Japanese broth ingredients.\r\n\r\nDashi Master Marusaya takes great pride is offering a large selection of healthy, Dashi-based dishes. For the non-epicureans among us, natural Dashi (as opposed to chemically-composed additives) is a key seasoning developed from Katsuboshi (dried bonito) and ingredient in Japanese cooking.\r\n\r\nAs a result, the stars of the menu are those dishes which make full use of the umami taste of the natural Dashi. For example, the Dashi Katsu Toji (Pork Cutlet with Dashi Sauce) are deep-fried pork cutlets from Hokkaido which go perfectly with the thick, flavourful egg Dashi gravy, whilst the Japanese Wagyu Beef Dashi Shabu features melt-in-your-mouth slices of beef cooked in a delicately-flavoured Dashi pot. Grab a beer or cocktail to wash all that down, and soak in the funky vibes with the rest of the cool cats out on the town. Awash with the constant murmurs of lapping waters, this soothing quayside gem boasts lengthy pages of breakfast options to keep both adults and children satisfied. Plates like Mediterranean, a dish packed with delights like Halloumi cheese, freshly baked pita, and grilled sausage, Mushroom Frittata, and the classic Shakshouka, sit alongside sweeter options like Vanilla French Toast and Pancakes, and it\u2019s a picky person that won\u2019t find something to suit their fancy at Miska.\nThe rest of the immense offerings are both staggering and delicious. You\u2019ll be tempted to fill up on appetising starters and a Greek salad, at first, but as your eyes travel on (and on), the lure of mouthwatering mains like D\u00f6ner Kebab & Rice and a Kalymali Pizza topped with minced beef in spicy tomato sauce, coriander, and cheese, becomes more difficult to resist. Health buffs will also appreciate the lighter bites and preservative-free pita and wrap breads that showcase fresh products and homemade sauces to their best advantage. It can be a tad tough to find a spot that offers great food, family friendly atmosphere, and a chance to regroup from the chaos of everyday life but Miska Caf\u00e9 has hit three for three in our books! (May 2016)", "Hand-made, premium and gourmet, the dim sum delights at Mister Wu are must-tries when you\u2019re at Oxley Bizhub. A firm believer in putting heart and soul into making each piece of dim sum, the team of dedicated chefs behind the restaurant is passionate about making the best dim sum fresh to order. \r\n\r\nHandmade to perfection using the freshest ingredients, the Signature Dim Sum Set is a great set meal to start off with. Delivering on their promise to take an interesting spin on traditional dim sum dishes to woo diners, Mister Wu\u2019s Siew Mai comes topped with baby abalone and drenched in a light soya sauce. Soaking in the savoury flavour of the sauce, the pork and shrimp were extremely flavourful and delicious. Another dish with a unique twist is the Truffle Xiao Long Bao. Perfumed with hints of truffle, this exquisitely handcrafted dish draws in crowds for all the right reasons.\r\n\r\nCrispy and fluffy, the Crispy Lava Bun is deep fried to perfection and hides a sweet golden liquid that spills out perfectly when bitten into. If you\u2019re not a fan of buns, opt for the Banana Red Bean Roll instead. Nicely fried on the outside and gooey in the middle, this foolproof classic Chinese dessert will not disappoint. (Oct 2020)", "Located along the hip Duxton Road, the winsome Mitsu Sushi Bar charms diners with the best and freshest sushi in the city, thanks to its premium seafood that gets flown in from Japan five times a week. Under the deft hands of Fukuoka-native Chef Mitsuyasu Tatsuro, simple sushi ingredients are made to shine. The chef employs a \u201cone fish, three ways\u201d approach to his food, so diners can choose one fish from the daily menu and have it cooked three different ways. One notable standout is the Alaskan King Crab, cooked in styles that run the gamut from kaminabe, tempura, and sashimi to grilled & served with vinegar, simmered, or in chawanmushi. Other must-try menu items include the Soft-shell Crab Roll paired with a mildly spicy mayo. The Asari Clam Soup is another divine dish that doubles up as a refreshing palate cleanser. Then complement the fresh seafood offerings with any of the eatery\u2019s numerous sake and shochu options, such as the Nama Sake, an unfiltered and unpasteurised sake that goes down smoothly with sushi.\n\nThere\u2019s nothing quite like an omakase meal, a chef-curated meal where all you have to do is sit back and enjoy the journey. And if there\u2019s any restaurant that ranks among the best, it\u2019s Mitsu Sushi Bar. (Jan 2018)", "Dining with a view has to be one of our favorite things and you get that and much, much more when you dine at Mitsuba Japanese Restaurant. Sprinkled with keyaki booths for a more traditional experience, dining here is perfect for date night, birthday dinners, and family gatherings!\nSettled right in the heart of Clarke Quay in Central, Mitsuba Japanese Restaurant is a vibrant eatery serving authentic Japanese cuisine. Signature dishes like Temaki, Maki Mono, and Ipin Mono make it quite hard to pick a favorite so do what we do and order them all! (Apr 2015)", "Mitzo breaks the mould of Chinese dining by combining a contemporary take on Cantonese cuisine with an artisanal cocktail programme. Set in the heart of Orchard Road, Mitzo offers diners a host of exciting Cantonese cuisines with customised cocktail pairings. Whether it's a lunch venue that you are looking for or a dinner get-together with friends and family, Mitzo has just the right offerings for you.\n\nA sense of wonderment greets any diner who steps into Mitzo. The mesmerizing colours of dusk blue, lemon yellow, mint green, hint at the unique culinary journey diners will experience and remember with every single visit.\n\nMitzo's attention to your dining experience begins with an attentive host of associates who will walk you through your dining selections, take you through the list of exquisite  a la carte signatures - Black Truffle Crispy Roast Duck, Venison with Asparagus in Black Pepper Mint Sauce and the restaurant's fine selections of specialties such as piquant White Pepper Lobster, Prawn with Caviar Sesame Mayo, Crispy Roasted Pork Belly, which can be found on its set menus.\n\nMitzo's Dim-Sum Set Lunch comes highly recommended. Its 3-course set features over 10 delectable handcrafted dim sums, a double-boiled soup of the day and a dessert that is almost theatrical in its presentation. With an option for a 4-course set, diners will be spoilt for choice. The mouth-watering 4-course set allows diners a choice of dry-styled thin Noodles with Prawn Dumplings & Signature Mitzo Barbeque Pork or Porridge with Lobster Claw, Fish & Pork.\n\nMitzo stops at nothing to ensure an experience that surpasses any diner's expectations. Mitzo has a cocktail bar that is truly a sight to behold - a spellbinding aqua tank that is home to some beautiful bell-shaped jellyfish. What makes the bar even more special is the artisanal cocktails that are curated in-house by a team of mixologists who are also your perfect bartenders, affable and knowledgeable in their field. From Asian Inspirations - Empress Sour (a classic for all Whisky Sour fans) to Mitzo's creations - Total Recall (an aromatic cocktail set to awaken your senses), Mitzo Bar is a must-visit. The cocktails can be paired with your selections of the cuisines when dining.\n\nA superb Supper Menu is also available for those with a penchant for deep-fried snacks after midnight. Evergreens like Deep-fried Prawn Coated with Wasabi Mayonnaise and the decadent Fried Rice with Live Lobster Meat, Vegetables and Mushrooms in XO sauce, are available at Mitzo.\n\nJust a stone's throw away from Orchard and Somerset MRT stations, Mitzo, with its exquisite offerings of contemporary Cantonese cuisines and artisanal cocktails and promotions, is a restaurant that delights the palates and the wallets. (Sep 2018)", "Miyu is a Japanese omakase restaurant tucked away in a shophouse on Duxton Road. Helmed by executive chef Ng Kam Kwan, who\u2019s trained in the kitchen of some of Singapore\u2019s most highly-acclaimed restaurants, it\u2019s a great place to get a taste of Japan.\r\n\r\nDuring lunch, the menu is casual, offering a variety of sets that come with appetisers, soup, a main dish, and dessert. The Bara Chirashi set is a favourite among sashimi fans. For something more indulgent and tuna lovers, go for the Otoro Chirashi Don set which is the fattiest portion of the Japanese Bluefin Tuna and can literally melt in your mouth.\r\n\r\nDuring dinner, full-course omakase sets are the stars of the show, with each set having no less than seven courses. Dishes change regularly according to the season and the chef's preference, but you can look forward to fresh air-flown sashimi, sushi, donburis, cooked dishes, dessert, and more. Dinner sets are also available upon request during lunch, so die-hard omakase fans can get their fix at any time of the day. (Oct 2020)", "Helmed by acclaimed Israeli \"MasterChef\", Chef Eyal Shani, Miznon aims to impart a sense of magic in every bite with a menu that features a fresh take on Israeli street food.Miznon's menu options offer both the sweet and savoury, in pitas, and out of pitas. Upon arrival, you'll get to sample their creamy tahini dip, as well as charred peppers to give a little heat to the start of your meal.Made for the health conscious, the Falafel Burger is a wonderful combination of tomato steak, accompanied by sour cream, chilli, onion and pickles. For meat lovers, the Abu Kebab is a tasty lamb option that is cooked well and served with grilled tomato, onion, tahini, salsa and chilli. Other interesting and yummy dishes include the Folded Cheeseburger, Minute Steak, and seared Chicken Liver.Vegetarians are also treated to a wide variety of options here with options such as Baby Cauliflower Flower, Bag of Green Beans and the Run Over Potato. (Nov 2020)", "Tucked in Ngee Ann City along Orchard Road, Mizuki is a Japanese restaurant to enjoy cuisine of the highest order. Well-known for their Omakase Tempura Meal, the restaurant specialises in whipping up tasty tempura dishes. \r\n\r\nPerfect for intimate meals, the restaurant is segregated into private rooms with the option of dining at the sushi counter or the tempura counter. For the tempura experience, start with a simple plate of spinach and beancurd skin in dashi sauce before moving onto the scallop. Cooked medium rare, the wonderful texture of the scallop elevates the dish, giving it a fantastic flavour. Deep fried to perfection, the anago is a delicious mouthful of sweet and tangy flavour, enhanced by the acidity brought about by a drop of lemon juice. Wrap up your meal with a small bowl of fluffy Japanese short grain rice topped with diced tempura prawns. \r\n\r\nThe sushi set features the usual fanfare of traditional Japanese favourites such as eight different pieces of sashimi sushi, as well as a variety of handrolls. (Nov 2020)", "Located along Hong Kong Street, Mizume is an omakase restaurant in Singapore. Bringing with him over 30 years of experience in Japanese fine dining, chef and owner Lawrence Chia aims to wow diners with meticulously prepared dishes featuring seasonal ingredients.\r\n\r\nStep into the cosy and elegant 25-seater restaurant for an intimate dining experience. Featuring a wood-lined exterior and a semi-dark interior, the restaurant is great for private events or small get-togethers. Showcasing the freshest exports from Toyosu fish market three times a week, the dishes are creatively handcrafted by the chefs and made for the discerning palates. (Oct 2020)", "Nestled along Cavan Road, Mizuya is a gem waiting to be discovered by lovers of Japanese food. Omakase (chef\u2019s choice) is the menu on offer here, though you\u2019ll find affordable sets available during the busy lunch hour. \r\n\r\nBy day, tuck into a selection of donburi, from a premium Wagyu Don set complete with a sous-vide egg, to affordably-priced Chirashi or Sashimi & Unagi Don sets. \r\n\r\nCome dinner time, the restaurant transforms into an intimate space where diners indulge in an extensive tasting menu. Tuck into three kinds of appetisers, and a refreshing salmon carpaccio. Dinner then progresses to an assortment of seasonal sashimi, served on a bed of ice and beautifully garnished with edible flowers. A bowl of piping hot clear soup is a good palate-cleanser, before the chef serves up the main courses \u2014 nigiri sushi, a mini don bowl, and miso soup, ending with some sweet Japanese fruit and hot tea for dessert. Sushi fans can opt for a full Nigiri Sushi Omakase, which comes with 15 pieces of nigiri sushi and a handroll. \r\n\r\nHead chef Kenny is also an expert in pairing whisky with Japanese food, so be sure to ask him for recommendations on a delicious dram for an accompanying nightcap. (Aug 2019)", "Moghul Mahal is an institution for North Indian food lovers in Singapore. Established almost 30 years ago, when there were only a small handful of restaurants serving authentic North Indian food, Moghul Mahal has stood the test of time and needs no introduction to those in the know of the local dining scene.\nIt has steadily built up a pool of loyal patrons that have followed the restaurant and its exquisite range of fine North Indian dishes through its multiple incarnations in various locations over the past 3 decades. Using only the finest ingredients and freshly blended spices, the award winning chefs bring to life the wonderful universe of flavours that Indian food has to offer, delivering a feast for all the senses that will undoubtedly delight and satisfy you. (Jun 2018)", "Sum Yi Tai has already made a name for itself with its sensuous name and unique ambience the straitlaced would cover from. Now, they\u2019ve upped the ante with a bar in the back room of the second floor of the restaurant which is accessible only with a password that can be obtained on the website or from the servers on the first floor. From the gilded mahjong gold tiles on the tables to the cushy upholstery arranged with purposeful carelessness, everything about this bar screams ostentatious excess.\r\n\r\nThe draw here are the cocktails, each with their unique link to Mona, the elusive third wife the restaurant draws its name from. Ask, and the bartenders are sure to regale you with tales of Mona\u2019s exploits, and how each concoction got its name. Sip on the light Lady\u2019s Elixir, a mix of Remy Martin and VSOP mixed with monk fruit soda and sea salt drops for a lightly sweet flavour. Purported to have \u201cclose to zero\u201d calories, this is the perfect drink for diners watching their waistlines. \r\n\r\nFor something closer to home, try the Songstress. Served in a bottle of Pei Pa Koa, this drink is made with Bulleit Rye whiskey, angostura bitters, and a hearty dose of the sickly sweet traditional herbal medicine most Singaporeans have grown to love. (Feb 2019)", "Robertson Quay has long had a stellar reputation as a trendy dining and nightlife destination, probably partly due to its choice location along the Singapore River. As you walk along this iconic river, you can't help but sense an instant lightness in your step, a bounce in your walk, and a rumble in your belly. And if you think there's something reminiscent of the canals of Venice, why not answer that rumble with a trip to Mondo Mio?\nMondo Mio is an authentic Southern Italian restaurant which is as Italian as it gets. Freshly-made pizza and pasta make up the bulk of the menu and cheese is used generously. Still not enough cheese? The Four Cheese Pizza comes highly recommended. Fans of the thin thin-crust variety of the famous Italian pie will also enjoy the satisfying biscuit-like crunch with each bite.\nIf you're not a huge fan of either pizza or pasta, or just happen to be craving for a good chunk of meat, the premium veal shank is your answer. Braised on low fire with rosemary and thyme, the shank comes served on a bed of rich and flavourful saffron risotto made with simmered Italian Arborio rice. Just the sight of it is guaranteed to make you want to belt out a melody like a Gondola singer. (Aug 2016)", "The only restaurant in Singapore that serves Japanese demi glace curry made with as many as 14 varying vegetables and spices, Monster Curry keeps diners coming back for more.\r\n\r\nBig on size and huge on taste, the restaurant\u2019s monstrous bowls of curry rice and noodles bring joy and spice to all! Perfect for sharing, opt for the 41cm plate and spread the love of Monster Curry\u2019s smooth and fragrant curry with family and friends.\r\n\r\nAll dishes at Monster Curry are served at five different levels of spiciness. Daredevils can opt for the monster spicy or super spicy option while others can enjoy the hot sauce concoction at a normal spicy level. A popular favourite, the Flame Monster Curry consists of pork shabu shabu, tori karaage, shrimp tempura, onsens egg and cheese for a satisfying one dish meal. Other signature menu options include the Chashu Curry Ramen and Combo Curry Ramen Set.\r\n\r\nFor those who fancy pasta, a plethora of creamy and tangy pasta options are available on the menu. Opt for Seafood Fantasy and indulge in a taste of the flavours from the ocean in a single plate. (Mar 2021)", "Landing in Causeway Point, Monster Planet is Monster Curry Groups\u2019 debut of a halal-certified brand. Known for their monster-sized curries dished up at pocket-friendly prices, the iconic Japanese restaurant chain is offering its fiery dishes alongside other exclusive menu options at Monster Planet. \r\n\r\nMade with 14 varying vegetables and spices, the addictive sauce is cooked over low fire for two days, resulting in an intensely flavourful sauce. Popular signatures drenched in this fiery sauce include the Monster Curry Combo, Signature Chicken Katsu Curry, Monster Combo Curry Ramen and more. Known for their monster-sized curries dished up at pocket friendly prices, the iconic Japanese restaurant chain is offering its fiery dishes alongside other exclusive menu options at Monster Planet. \r\n\r\nMade with 14 varying vegetables and spices, the addictive sauce is cooked over low fire for two days, resulting in an intensely flavourful sauce. Popular signatures drenched in this fiery sauce include the Monster Curry Combo, Signature Chicken Katsu Curry, Monster Combo Curry Ramen and more. For those looking for a taste of something different, the burger options at Monster Planet will surely satisfy your cravings. The Lemongrass Chicken Burger is another mouthwatering option that comes highly recommended. \r\n\r\nEnd your meal on a sweet note with the restaurant\u2019s Mixed Berries Honey Toast. Our strongest belief is that less is more and simple is good.\r\nDeliver delicious food and coffee takes dedication, love, and care and this is precisely our motto for our guests at Morettino Caf\u00e8.\r\nOur coffee - you cannot go wrong - is Morettino, an Italian must, Caffe Morettino is an artisanal slow coffee produced in Sicily, in the middle of the Mediterranean, since 1920.\r\nOur fresh homemade food such as Mediterranean Aglio Olio with Prawns, Mediterranean Salad,  Beef Burger,  Paninis (sandwiches), bread, lasagna, pastas, pizzas, arancinis, cakes are freshly made. The caf\u00e8 is based on sharing a way of Italian life style in which guests are invited to be aware of what it means to eat fresh food and not massive unfresh productions.\r\nWe strongly believe in a diet based on a balance between meat, vegetables, cheeses, carbohydrates, and protein and in awareness to be part of an amazing Universe that provide us such good resources and we need to do our part as a conscious human being, paying respect and not being greedy in pretending what earth cannot produce in such big quantity without damaging the environment.\r\nIf you want to indulge in our tiramisu, you are more than welcome and we will not tell anyone your indulgence.\r\nMorettino Caf\u00e9 experience is about more than just food. A sincere effort to educate our staff on all aspects of food, coffee, and wine culture is the basis for our service philosophy. Our value-driven wine list features 100 bottles starting from $38 and under $100. Our wines, like our food, are never static and change with the seasons. Labels range from interesting newcomers to Old-World classics from small-production winemakers who put as much love and care into their wines as we put into our food.\r\nWhen you visit Morettino Caf\u00e8, we hope you are ready to share an experience that does not want to be pretentious but wants and hopes to be lived in the same way we make food, with love and passion.\r\nOur concept is to use love and balance in choosing and making our dishes, considering also a way to eat and use daily.Morettino uses a basic philosophy imported from the Sicilian culture. Our warm and charming atmosphere we hope will relax you, Chef\u2019s specials are also added to the daily menu already established.\r\nMorettino Caf\u00e8 is the perfect destination anytime you are hungry or fancy a good cuppa or simply want to relish a glass of quality wine or beer.\r\nWe are open 7 days a week.We hope you will have a great time! For seafood lovers, the Salmon Steak or Balik Sis are both great options for an affordable one meal dish. (Feb 2021)", "With its multipurpose function as a bakery, a bistro, and a bar, Nassim Hill Bakery Bistro Bar has comfortably earned a reputation as a triple threat, must-visit establishment. With its warm, friendly atmosphere and a menu that's easy to love, it's the perfect place for families and for those looking to unwind with friends at the bar after work.\nSink your teeth into an utterly decadent forkful of Rosemary Lamb with Truffle Potato Mash, and savour the balance of delicate rosemary fragrance and tender, grilled lamb chop. The truffle potato mash is an unforgettable component of the dish as well, and will linger (in all its truffle-scented glory) on your mind for days to come. You also can't miss out on the Chilli Crab Pasta, where large chunks of fresh crab meat are saut\u00e9ed in the restaurant's irresistible homemade chilli crab sauce and served on top of a bed of spaghetti. If you're looking for a refreshing drink to wash all that down, then a Summer Sangria (which serves four) wouldn't be amiss - it's always summer in Singapore after all. The place also offers up a bevy of classic and other innovative cocktails, spirits, and other drinks to tickle your fancy if you feel so inclined. You're bound to have an enjoyable, relaxing time at Nassim Hill, and that's a promise.\n (Aug 2017)", "Violet Oon's unabashed love for, and knowledge of, the Peranakan culinary delights and culture of Singapore has manifested into cookbooks, Violet Oon Singapore, and, more recently, National Kitchen at the National Gallery. Given that we've compared her to Julia Child previously, it's safe to say thatwe're fans.\nPeranakans didn't shy away from colour and were known for their intricate or opulent decorations, and you'll definitely see hints of this philosophy in National Kitchen. Decadent dark panels and mirrored walls are lit up by elegant wall sconces whilst references to the Peranakan way of life are peppered throughout the space. Rattan ceiling fans, distinctive tiles, and typical Singaporean foliage like palm leaves and orchids are just a few of the touches that make National Kitchen special.\nThe food is an excellent introduction into some of the more famous Peranakan dishes like Sambal Timun Nanas (pineapple and cucumber with chillies, onions and lightly sweet rice vinegar), Kiam Chye Ark Thng (soup of duck with salted mustard greens and a hint of spice chillies), and Buah Keluak Ayam (a stew of tangy chicken and the traditional buah keluak nuts). National Kitchen has also opened its menu's borders a little, offering other cultural favourites like Eurasian Beef Brisket Semor and Hakka Abacus Beads.\nBe warned though, while some of the dishes may be familiar and well-loved, the Peranakan options often prove to be divisive. Tuck in with an open mind though, and if you're looking for a sophisticated rendition of Peranakan food, you're in for a treat! (Jun 2018)", "", "", "", "", "Welcome to the wonderful world of Japanese beef: meat that\u2019s succulent, sweet, well-marbled, and unbelievably tender. Niku Katsumata prides itself on serving some of the finest beef produced in Japan, plated in the simplest ways to highlight the natural flavours of the meat, and paired with various complementary dishes to create a full, beef-centric meal. At its barest level, the beef here is of such high quality that it\u2019s served up as as sashimi. For cooked beef, one of the specialities here is Tataki Wagyu, a premium A4 Grade Wagyu that\u2019s lightly seared before being placed atop a bowl of rice and given the \u2018chasuke\u2019 treatment: a light, savoury bonito stock is poured over the dish, which gently coaxes even more flavour from the beef. You have the option to top this up with premium, umami-rich ingredients like caviar, foie gras, or ikura. You can also have the beef in the form of a magnificent set meal, the A4 Wagyu Beef Set, which features Japanese Pork Prosciutto, a selection of home-made pickles, a premium selection of  A4 Wagyu Beef, and a Japanese A4 Beef Curry Rice. The beef here, beautifully marbled, tender, and served very rare, is prepared by chef Tsuyoshi Katsumata in the most unusual of ways: it\u2019s cooked over a crystal plate, a method that apparently evenly distributes the heat and cooks the meat gently, ensuring it remains perfectly juicy. The incredible flavour of the beef at Niku Katsumata has to be tasted to be believed. A word of warning: you may never go back to your supermarket varieties after this! (Mar 2017)", "Indulge your seafood cravings and pay a visit to No Signboard Seafood, the popular chain famous for its White Pepper Crab and other seafood dishes. Part of what makes this particular establishment extra interesting is the story of its humble beginnings, because who doesn\u2019t love a good origin or success story? With a history dating back to the late 1970s, No Signboard Seafood began as a hawker centre seafood stall with literally no signboard and sales of three crabs a day. And look at it now \u2013 with outlets in several different locations, the establishment\u2019s story makes for a narrative that\u2019s about as satisfying as the food it serves.All this wouldn\u2019t be possible without some real quality cooking, of course \u2013 Singaporeans are a discerning lot when it comes to their food, and a chain that has stood the test of time the way No Signboard Seafood should more or less be worth its salt. Sink your teeth into a delightfully fresh, sweet hunk of crab meat when you order a crab dish (again we\u2019re plugging the White Pepper Crab), and you\u2019ll understand why this is an eatery that has endured for so long. Don\u2019t forget to try the irresistibly spicy Sambal Kang Kong, another popular must-try option. Other seafood items are definitely worth a taste too. Unpretentious and reliable, delicious and satisfying, No Signboard Seafood is definitely a place that hits all the right notes, and then some. (Dec 2019)", "", "This social experiment-meets-unique dining experience has enthralled diners with its fascinating concept: led into a restaurant that\u2019s completely shrouded in darkness, with only a blind guide to assist you; sight, one of the key elements of taste, is removed. What remains is for you to enjoy the mystery of what\u2019s on your plate, and discover a new element of taste: surprise. All the while, your blind guide helps you navigate the table and your plate, in a reversal of roles that will leave you with something to ponder beyond a delicious meal.\n\nThe food here is no afterthought, either, and features a French palette courtesy of veteran Chef, Desmond Lee. The meals change each day, but take the form of an appetizer, a main, and a dessert. In the dark, a meal may open with ethically-sourced foie gras paired with honey-sweet dried figs and a rich gorgonzola cream. A main course may take the form of a lobster tail, poached in butter and paired with a gel\u00e9e of fennel, pickled radish, and chili-infused coconut broth, or meltingly tender Kobe beef short ribs served with thyme jam, compressed tomato, and creamy mash. Even in the dark, there\u2019s room for dessert, especially sophisticated numbers like Manjari chocolate cremeux with a crumbly \u201csoil\u201d of cashew and chocolate, garnished with pink salt caramel and peanut sorbet. Strip yourself of one of your primary senses, and see what becomes intensified at this super cool dining experience! (Aug 2017)", "\"Oberstrasse\" is a common street name in German-speaking towns, and is also the street in Switzerland on which the cafe's owner met his first and only girlfriend. It's no surprise that he aims to recreate that nostalgic feeling through this quaint, warmly-lit cafe. But it isn't all just sentiment though \u2014 the food served here packs a punch too.\r\n\r\nA good selection of Western appetisers, mains, and pastas are available, with a section of the menu dedicated to Rosti. (Mar 2020)", "You wouldn\u2019t usually expect a green oasis at the heart of the city, but Open Farm Community, nestled in the verdant surroundings of Dempsey Hill, will change that perception. A revolutionary collaboration between the Spa Espirit Group, Head Chef Oliver Truesdale Jutras, Souschef Phoebe Oviedo and award-winning food garden specialists, Edible Garden City, Open Farm Community is an urban farmland, horticultural hub, and restaurant all packed into one. At the heart of it all is one simple philosophy: to provide Singaporeans with a space to reconnect with nature whilst educating the young and old about local farming and the food we eat. The sprawling outdoor space features a garden brimming with herbs and vegetable produce, as well as educational breakout spaces alongside lawn bowling lanes and table tennis tables. True to their goal of educating city dwellers about the food we eat, tours of the vegetable and fruit orchards, talks, and gardening workshops are available too. The centrepiece is the gorgeous restaurant, a building with floor-to-ceiling glass windows and a high ceiling, the perfect place to unwind and tuck into some simple and honest fare.\n\nThe kitchen here adopts a strict no-no policy towards processed ingredients, imported produced, and unsustainable farming practices. This means that ingredients used here are mostly locally-sourced and always fresh - even the pasta is made fresh in-house! The menu is also one striking example of Open Farm Community\u2019s dedication to serving honest food, with lengthy names laying out the different ingredients used in each dish. The flavours here are simple yet robust, focused around local farms and heritage, as epitomized by the Laksa Pappardelle, featuring soft shell prawn tempura, a spicy coconut based sauce and fresh laksa leaves from the garden; or the light and fresh watermelon salad, replete with lime and mint to balance the housemade ricotta from local Hay Dairies goat milk. A highlight was the Barramundi, straight from the waters off Pulau Ubin, combined with a sumptuous seaweed butter and organic dou miao, with puffed black rice crumbled over for a textural contrast.\n\nNow, whether you\u2019re looking for romantic date spot, or a place where the kids can have some fun, Open Farm Community definitely provides an unforgettable experience for all.
