(Aug 2013)", "Tandoor re-opens on Thursday, 14 January 2021 and will operate from Wednesdays to Sundays.Established in 1985, Tandoor, Singapore\u2019s most awarded Indian restaurant, takes diners on a journey with authentic North Indian dishes that pay homage to India's rich culinary heritage. Each dish in the gourmet menu is carefully handcrafted by a team of talented chefs using classic recipes and time honoured methods which date back in time across India\u2019s rich history. Ever conscious of our diners\u2019 palettes, some dishes use healthier preparation methods while retaining their original Indian heritage.\r\n\r\nContemporary yet laced with tradition, Tandoor\u2019s interior is dotted with subtle Indian motifs. Back-lit wall panels featuring Jaali (or Jali) \u2500 a latticed screen characteristic of Indian architecture \u2013 line two sides of the restaurant, while twin alabaster pillars house the traditional Indian craft of inlay mirrors.\r\n\r\nFull-length windows give diners an intimate view of the kitchen where two custom-made copper tandoors (or clay ovens) stand. From the dining hall, you will be able to see our chefs at work, from making Indian breads to preparing kebabs of tandoori meats and vegetables that are served fresh to your table, presents an inviting atmosphere where you can enjoy good food and great conversations with family, friends and clients alike. (Jan 2021)", "To find authentic Indian food, look no further than Tandoori Culture. With a branch located at Boon Tat Road in Telok Ayer, this cosy establishment offers a casual and relaxed atmosphere with excellent Indian food. Popular with Singaporean gourmets, Tandoori Culture specialises in food cooked in a traditional tandoor oven, or an oven made of clay. This method of cooking slowly extracts the rich flavours from the component ingredients, resulting in fragrant and impactful dishes sure to make your tastebuds sing.\r\n\r\nStart your meal with the Vegetable Soup, consisting of sweet corn, manchal and dal, and make your way to the entrees, which includes vegetarian and non-vegetarian options. For vegetarians, be sure to try the Punjabi Dal Tadka, consisting of yellow lentils cooked with butter and mixed with a medley of vegetables, including fried chopped onions, coriander and tomatoes. Beyond greens, try the Mutton Rogan Josh, consisting of bite-sized mutton cubes braised and blended with an eclectic mix of spices, and served in a creamy curry sauce.\r\n\r\nFinish your meal with Gulab Jamun, consisting of fried balls comprised of milk and flour, and soaked in saffron-flavoured sugar. (Jun 2018)", "", "", "", "", "", "\"Say hola to the bright and festive flavours of Spanish cuisine with Tapas Club, a sleek and sophisticated eatery that promises food so authentic you\u2019ll feel like you were whisked away to the Iberian Peninsula itself.\n\nEmbark on your evening our lunch with some cold cut platters, such as the Tabla De Embutidos. Paired with some bread and a dab of tomato puree, you will be hankering for more of these delicious morsels. For more yummy bites, the heavenly Croquetas De Setas, otherwise known as mushroom croquettes, can\u2019t be beaten.\n\nAnd what\u2019s a Spanish eatery without some paella? Gorge yourself on one of the many paellas available. Our favorite has to be the Arroz Negro, highlighting fresh cuttlefish and clams in squid ink paella. Authentic and bold Spanish fare takes center stage at Tapas Club, so swing on by the next time you\u2019re in the neighborhood. (March 2019)", "For a healthy yet hearty option in the bustling CBD, head to Tapasta Bar. This fresh concept serves pasta and grain bowls by day, and Spanish-style tapas (sharing plates) by night. There are no fixed combinations here; instead, diners put together their own bowl from an array of fresh ingredients. \r\n\r\nThe Creamy Fusilli is a good base to build your bowl around. The curly pasta is cooked al dente and bathed in a rich, aromatic sauce laced with garlic and onion. For mains to go with the pasta, try the Salmon \u2014 the fish is grilled til\u2019 fork-tender, with a crisp skin. Also good is the Roasted Chicken Thigh, with a lightly-peppered skin and succulent juicy meat. \r\n\r\nDinner is a good time to head over with friends, you can sit back and share nibbles in a leisurely fashion. Be sure to try the Cajun Mushrooms, an addictive snack of plump button mushrooms encased in a golden-brown battered skin. The Chicken Meatballs, a must-have, is a well-seasoned dish that provides satisfaction with every bite. (Jun 2019)", "", "Experience the taste of Nanyang right in the vicinity of Siglap. Owned and operated by multi-award-winning celebrity chef, chef Pung Lu Tin, the restaurant serves traditional Chinese dishes with a touch of modern creativity.\r\n\r\nA scrumptious creation by chef Pung Lu Tin is the Stewed Rice Vermicelli with Seafood and Supreme Stock in Opeh Leaf. Nicely diced into bite-sized pieces and braised in supreme chicken stock, the ingredients are tossed with prawns and scallops, enhancing the flavour of the dish. The Braised Charcoaled Tofu with Minced Pork and Dried Shrimps also pack a punch of flavours. Cooked over a hot stove to bring out the flavours of the silken tofu, the dish is topped with fried minced pork and dried shrimps.\r\n\r\nAnother mouthwatering dish is the Poached Chinese Spinach with Sea Clam and Trio Eggs. End your meal on sweet and savoury notes with the Soya Bean Milk Pudding with Mango Puree.\r\n\r\nDelicious, innovative and fresh, the food at Tasty Court by Chef Pung transforms every visit into an unforgettable dining experience. (Mar 2020)", "Owned and operated by multi-award-winning celebrity chef, chef Pung Lu Tin, the restaurant serves traditional Chinese dishes with a touch of modern creativity. Leveraging years of experience, Chef Pung Lu Tin brings his signature flair to this restaurant.\r\n\r\nMeals here are great for large groups, with multiple set options such as the Friends Gathering Set, Family Gathering Set, Local Flavours Set and more! Try the Braised Dried Seafood in Golden Chicken Broth. Each mouthful more delicious than the last, the braised seafood and rich chicken broth perfectly complement each other, bringing out the flavours of the braised prawns and scallops. \r\n\r\nA speciality dish at the restaurant, order the Jack Fruit Chilli Crab for a unique yet fun combination of flavours. (Mar 2020)", "Wrapped around the corner of River Valley Road, this shophouse restaurant looks unassuming at a glance but a closer look yields the sort of quaint charm that draws diners in. Once inside, the Swiss chalet inspiration is clear \u2013 wood panels, vintage-looking lamps, and other decorative knick-knacks give the small space cosy warmth.\nThe philosophy here is obviously less about fancy touches and more about letting the food speak for itself. None of that half-baked tourist fare though, the menu offers a rich selection of prime Continental items. Fresh Irish Oysters, Goose-Liver Terrine, Raclette Cheese with Air Dried Beef; you\u2019d never guess these sumptuous appetisers were on offer just by looking at The Tavern Restaurant\u2019s humble exterior. The mains are equally decadent, with Wagyu beef listed alongside dishes like Dingley Dell Pork Chop, Angel Hair Pasta with Half a Lobster, Sliced Veal Zurich, and Alaskan Crab-Mornay. Surprised by the incredible spread? We were too, at first. It\u2019s a good lesson in not judging a book by its cover and, really, we\u2019re only sad lessons can\u2019t be this delicious all the time! (Feb 2021)", "Don\u2019t be fooled! Despite what its name suggests, Tekong Seafood Restaurant is rooted firmly on the mainland. Based in Changi Village, this storied culinary establishment that was formerly based on Pulau Tekong has been wowing diners with its consistently fresh seafood and Chinese cuisine for over thirty-five years and counting.\nHere, freshness is practically guaranteed as the restaurant tends to use live seafood that has been recently caught by local fishermen off the Singapore coast. And there\u2019s something for everyone. For the health-conscious eaters, the Nyonya Steamed Fish is a great catch \u2013 bursting with flavour without the use of any oil. Meanwhile, the Ginger and Spring Onion Lobster is cleverly done, with the bright notes from ginger enhancing the tender lobster flesh. Vegetarians don\u2019t have to despair, as the restaurant has plenty of stellar options to pick from, whether it is the soft Thai Style Tofu, or the crunchy Fried French Beans. And of course, one must not pass on the classic tze char go-to, the fluffy and fragrant Oyster Omelette.\nOn weekends, you\u2019ll see this eating joint packed to its gills with families large and small. And thanks to its coastal views, dining at Tekong Seafood Restaurant feels like a respite from the usual city life. Now don\u2019t wait, chope a reservation for your next meal there! (Jan 2018)", "", "", "It\u2019s easy to unassumingly walk past the beer vending machine that serves as the entrance to this bustling tempura bar. But keep your eyes peeled, and you\u2019ll be rewarded with a night of good food, drinks, and plenty of fun. \r\n\r\nOwned by father-and-son duo Paul and Dragg Wong, Tempura Oji is a haven for midnight revellers looking for supper grub. And this is some fine supper nosh indeed. The pair invested in a top-grade flash-frying technology, which means the tempura that comes out from the kitchen here is wonderfully crumbed without being too greasy. \r\n\r\nTry the Supamu Tempura, which sees \u2018Made in Japan\u2019 Spam coated in a light batter and deep-fried. Enjoy this with the Pumpkin Tempura and a side of pureed radish and chopped ginger. Fancy a proper tempura meal? The Sea Bass Tempura is tender and sweet, and is a good complement to the Tempura Moriawase, a selection of deep-fried King Tiger Prawns and mixed vegetables such as onion and eggplant. \r\n\r\nWash it down with some Japanese craft beers, or signature cocktails like The Blind Pig, featuring Japanese label Roku Gin stirred with homemade beetroot marmalade and pressed apples. (Oct 2019)", "Pared down to the basics, it\u2019s all about clean flavours and classic Japanese fare done right. TEN means \u201cheaven\u201d or \u201ccelebration\u201d in Japanese and in the case of TEN Sushi, this can\u2019t be more true: the cosy enclave is little more than a year old but has made its own splash with Sushi Master Marusaya at its helm. So whether you are looking for a mouthwatering array of fresh fish air-flown from Japan, impeccable hand-rolls, or just a comfy bowl of Don, TEN Sushi has got you more than covered. \nThe Salmon Tartar provides an enticing sneak peek into the exhilarating epicurean journey ahead. A generous portion of salmon cubes is masterfully drizzled with a tangy spicy sauce that does not mask the salmon\u2019s delightful creaminess, while the runny goodness of a perfectly poached onsen egg elevates the entire appetizer. Jumping right into mains, the sushi steals the show with its sheer freshness. Don\u2019t believe us? Try the delicate 3 Kinds of Blue Fin Tuna Sushi for yourself. The rolls don\u2019t disappoint either - the Fisherman Inside-Out-Roll, for instance, features 10 types of fresh fish, totally changing the game for your usual hand roll. \nAnother highlight: the wide selection of sake, whiskey, and beers imported from Japan, so be sure to ask your friendly staff to recommend the perfect accomplice to a great meal! (Apr 2018)", "The pet project of owner-operator, this restaurant specialises in Wagyu Beef Yakiniku, and is one of the hidden gems of Singapore\u2019s thriving Japanese restaurant scene. From his humble beginnings in Japan as a dishwasher to a manager of a yakiniku chain, he has come a long way, and the expertise he gained reflects in his menu of beloved Japanese classics. \r\n\r\nThere is a range of barbecue meats on offer at this restaurant, although the main draw is the wagyu meat. The wagyu here is Kagoshima and Hokkaido wagyu, which is one of the most exquisite cuts of beef available in Japan. The Salmon Belly, Sea Bream, and Tuna are also popular sashimi options. \r\nThe crisp Ebi-Fry is a Japanese staple, and perfect for sharing. The Soft-Shell Crab is another popular dish. A whole crab battered and deep-fried, this dish is good to share but can also be enjoyed by one hungry diner. (Oct 2018)", "Clean, light flavours and precise cooking that highlights the very best of an ingredients natural flavours: that is the heart and soul of Teochew cooking. At Teochew Restaurant Huat Kee, this informs every dish, from its humblest items, like seasonal vegetables, to its more exquisite ones, like precious ocean bounty.\nAn award-winning restaurant that has been passed down for three generations of Teochew chefs, Huat Kee is known and loved for its preservation of heritage Teochew flavours, but also its confidence in working with ingredients from far-flung places like Chile and South Africa. Enter the abalone, one of the signature ingredients at this restaurant, and some say done to perfection here. Served braised with sea cucumber, it may not taste like much, but it\u2019s days in the making, and when eaten, is pillowy, soft, and bursting with briny goodness. There\u2019s also Teochew-style duck, braised and served sliced on a platter with stewed pork belly, marinated eggs, tofu, and a lashing of sweet, herbal gravy. Steamed Pomfret, a Teochew hallmark, and one of the restaurant\u2019s signatures, arrives shiny and pearlescent on the table, strewn with fine aromatic garnishes, and a light poaching liquor. The meat gives way in firm but perfectly tender chunks. For truly festive occasions, a whole, glistening, crisp-skinned suckling pig is available, too, and the meal is best rounded off with some signature Yam Paste, cooked with lard to perfection and topped with stewed pumpkin and gingko nuts.\n A mix of humble fare prepared to perfection, and premium ingredients prepared with masterful simplicity: Teochew Restaurant Huat Kee is a heritage restaurant, of the best in Asia, and available at your doorstep. (Jul 2017)", "There\u2019s something about Mary teppanyaki at Teppan Bar Q. Take a seat in front of the counters, behind which skilled chefs wield their spatulas with aplomb, and prepare for a meal that\u2019s part performance part gastronomic guilty pleasure. It doesn\u2019t matter that you\u2019re rubbing shoulders with veritable strangers in the intimate space; in a strange way, the hubbub creates a bubble of privacy in which you can fully enjoy flavours.\nAs the grill fires up, start by scooping up their signature Potato Salad and Roasted Hakata Mentai before moving on to more unctuous plates. Sample Mix Seafood, Tiger Prawn with Balsamic Sauce, and Foie Gras with Japanese Radish, or meats such as the Duck with Spring Onion and Angus steak. Teppan Tapas are perfect for lighter bites like Squid with Pesto and Sauteed Mushrooms with Garlic whilst fans of okonomiyaki or omelettes will benefit from the Hakata Tonpei Yaki menu. This isn\u2019t a restaurant aiming for sterile food and reverent silence so if you\u2019re after a convivial atmosphere and fuss-free selections of grilled gems, you\u2019re definitely on the right track! (May 2016)", "With a kitchen helmed by lauded Chef Masayasu Yonemura, diners can rest assured that they are in good hands. His eponymous Kyoto restaurant was awarded One Michelin Star, and he is one of the most revered Japanese chefs in the world. This cosy spot in The Forum is his first foray outside of Japan, and was born out of his fascination with the traditional Japanese Teppan grill, and a desire to showcase the best of Eastern and Western cuisine.\r\n\r\nStart with the Mushroom Croquette with Beef Stew Sauce. The richness of the mushroom and the tenderness of the beef make for a hearty combination. Crisp on the outside and tender on the inside, these little bites are the perfect for whetting your appetite. There are a range of meaty mains here - the Wagyu Hamburg Steak is cooked on the teppan grill and has a signature smoky flavour that seeps into the meat and gives it a unique flavour. Seafood enthusiasts will love the Clam and Lobster Bouillabaisse. Made with Dashi stock instead of fish broth, this dish is a rich comfort food perfect for a cold day. (March 2019)", "", "Riding the wave of the Omakase craze in Singapore is this elegant restaurant in Tanjong Pagar. Established in a refurbished shophouse and seating less than 50, this intimate eatery serves up fresh sukiyaki, sashimi, and sushi made with fresh ingredients sourced directly from Japan.\n\nHowever, the true highlight of this spot is that it is the perfect place to indulge in some Omakase dishes that can be tailor-made according to your preferences. Diners can give celebrated Japanese chef Kenji Okumura guidance on their desired ingredients and flavours, and in a \u201creversed\u201d Omakase experience, the chef will do his best to incorporate them in a bespoke menu. With ingredients sourced directly from Japan, and with all new ingredients chosen specifically by Chef Okumura, diners can rest assured that they will be in good hands at this restaurant. \n\nThe Omakase menu makes use of ingredients from various regions of Japan, such as Iseshima oysters, Ise Ebi and Akamoku seaweed from the Mie Prefecture, Unagi from Shimanto and other fresh produce imported directly. Having satisfied personalities such as Gorbachev, Wen Jiabao, and the Japanese Emperor himself with his Omakase creations, diners are sure to enjoy the creations of Chef Okumura. (Nov 2018)", "Tucked away in Tras Street, Singapore\u2019s Japanese enclave, Teppan Works is a cosy spot that offers diners a taste of Osaka. The Japanese city is well-known for its popular okonomiyaki dishes, and you\u2019ll find this a mainstay on the menu at Teppan Works. Try the Signature Cheese Okonomiyaki, made from your choice of sharp gorgonzola, a light buffalo mozzarella, creamy camembert, or a rich raclette. The cheese is then cooked into the Japanese savoury pancake, with a crack of black pepper and a dash of fiery chilli oil. For something a little meatier, the Special Okonomiyaki is a must-try. The pancake here is stuffed with juicy slices of pork belly and beef tendon, mixed with potato and a fried egg for an indulgent treat.\r\n\r\nOtherwise, order a slab of the Wagyu Ribeye for sharing \u2014 the beef is cooked simply over the grill, then served with a dash of salt and pepper to bring out the rich, buttery flavours of the cut. For dessert, save space for the restaurant\u2019s signature Warabi Mochi. Made with fine kinako (roasted soy bean) powder and black sugar syrup, these fluffy little pillows are the perfect sweet treat to end a delicious meal. (Apr 2019)", "Tess Bar & Kitchen is the always-bustling, perennially fun filled spot you might have seen on Seah Street near Raffles Hotel. And with drinks from an award-winning mixologist, matched with trendy fare from a culinary heavy-hitter, it's easy to obsess over Tess.\nLike any it-girl, or it-restaurant for that matter, Tess has a distinctive style, swagger and can back it all up with bona fide coolness. That confidence comes from tatted-up head chef Martin Wong, with L'Atelier de Jo\u00ebl Robuchon kitchen cred and whose expertise in fine dining and playful personality comes through in a variety of small, medium and large plates, which vary in fanciness, but all aim to satisfy.\nBehind the bar, you can find the shaken-up creations of Steve Leong, the well-known finalist of Diageo Reserve World Class' Singapore 2013. That means that the cocktails are as fine as the dining at Tess, whether you go with old world classics or newfangled tipples. He's not alone in dreaming up drinks, however, as Tess plays host to the city's up and comers in the bar scene, in what turns out to be an open mic night of sorts, that the regular patrons, and there are a lot of them, love.\nSettle into the hip, glowy space that's configured for optimal hanging out. From the menu, the Duet Scallop & Aburi Tartare shows off Tess' fancier side, with scorched meaty scallops played against a refreshing chopped tartare. Also from the small plates, the Crispy Pork Belly is simplistic in its flavour, served with a fusion dip, forming a savoury, finger-licking good dish. From the Medium Plates, the Tess Wagyu Cubes & Bone Marrow is a surefire winner, with pan seared cuts of beef glazed with veal jus and marrow, just in case you needed more of a meat hit.\nIt's not all about the carnivores, though, as a selection of cheeses and even Vegan mains (a rare sight at Singapore fine dining restaurants, let alone a bar) can satisfy meatless diners. From that section, the Bohemian Vegetables Love is a colourful tangle of grilled zucchini, capsicum, aubergine and a piquant red pepper coulis. Finally, from the limited selection of dessert, the Chocolate Fondant with Blueberry Compote shows that the kitchen keeps careful measure of foodie trends, with savoury elements of spicy apple crumble accenting the luscious classic cake.\nIn the end, it's not just the good looks and impressive resume at Tess that will have you coming back for more, but the rotating food and drinks menu of creative selections. In fact, you are sure to learn what other fans already know: when it comes to Tess, just say yes. (Dec 2014)", "", "Seafood lovers, rejoice! With a table to table deshelling service, free-flow snow crab legs, and a variety of fresh seafood from an affiliated nursery brought in daily, this restaurant is a must-visit for anyone who enjoys the treasures of the sea. Or get a plate of the Ginger Signature Wings, aromatic deep fried chicken wings marinated with fragrant ginger spices. If you\u2019re feeling nostalgic, a plateful of Pineapple Rice, perfectly-cooked rice steeped in pineapple, spices, and herbs for a mild, gentle warmth, and lots of savoury-sweet goodness. It\u2019s the perfect foil to all those rich sauces and flavour. This is some of the most authentic Thai food in the heart of town! (July 2018)", "", "", "Slow down and appreciate the beauty of tradition here at The Blue Ginger. Tucked away in a beautifully restored three-storey shophouse along Tanjong Pagar, the Peranakan restaurant provides a conducive and friendly space for conversation accompanied by hearty food that will satisfy more than your belly. \r\n\r\nDive into conversation and the unique Pernakan culture with the restaurant\u2019s extensive menu. Prompted by the fond memories of hearty feasts, the menu features a long list of starters, soups, meat, seafood and more. The Nonya Fish Head Curry is a staple. Simmered in a traditional home style curry, the red snapper dish is garnished with lady\u2019s fingers and eggplant. \r\n\r\nA great centrepiece for any occasion, the fish head curry has a subtle taste of coconut milk that adds to the richness of the broth, bringing out the flavour of the fish. Order a Beef Rendang to go with the fish. Perfectly complementing the spiciness of the fish head curry, the tender beef cubes are prepared in rich coconut milk spiced with ginger, lemongrass, lime leaves and a dash of curry powder for a fiery kick. \r\n\r\nOther signature dishes here include the Curry Vegetables, Ayam Goreng Kunyit, Sambal Bendy and Durian Chendol. (Nov 2020)", "Raise your shot glasses and experience a night you won\u2019t forget at Chupitos Bar. Bringing the game of shots to a whole new level, Singapore\u2019s only specialised shooters bar is located right smack in the heart of the city.\r\n\r\nHave it your way with over 130 power-packed shots that may include candy, fire, tricks, and maybe even some naughty props. Happening Tuesday to Sunday from 3:30pm - 8:00pm for $6nett and 8:00pm til closing for $10nett, enjoy a round of selected shooters, beers, house pours and highballs at great prices. Don\u2019t fret if you\u2019re late to the party. Go hard or go home the whole night long with a multitude of sweet, savoury and fruity flavours. For bar bites, try the Truffle Fries, Sweet Potato Fries, Crispy Wings and more, and pair up your shots with an array of snacks for a night to remember. (Aug 2020)", "Launched in September 2019, The Elephant Room is Singapore\u2019s first culture forward cocktail bar inspired by the city\u2019s vibrant ethnic enclave of Little India. Named after the sub-continent\u2019s national heritage animal, The Elephant Room tells stories of real life figures and experiences through modern tipples concocted with a culinary flair. Helmed by Head Bartender and Co-Owner Yugnes Susela, The Elephant Room is located in a cosy yet visually striking second floor space of a shophouse on the fringes of Keong Saik Road. \r\n\r\nThe bar is marking their eventful first year with a new menu of tipples and nibbles. Driven to strike conversations between The Elephant Room and the district\u2019s colourful residents, Yugnes and his team make weekly visits to Little India for more than just supplies. Delving deeper into its colourful past, they seek to uncover and translate its century\u2019s worth of stories, from its European influences to cattle trading, into their menus. Their menu combines premium ingredients to dish out delicious recipes at affordable prices. (Jun 2020)", "", "Named after Chef Simone\u2019s beloved grandmother, Trattoria Nonna Lina is an utterly charming Italian bistro tucked away on Cantonment Road that spins up homestyle cooking that is sure to please everyone in the family. \n\nYou won\u2019t miss the brightly painted facade of this eatery as this conservation shophouse is painted in the bold colours of the Italian flag, ensuring this building stands out from the rest of the block. Inside, the decor draws inspiration from the sleepy seaside town of Porto Santo Stefano, where life is simple and the fishermen bring in the freshest Mediterranean catch every evening. Rustic and comforting, Trattoria Nonna Lina\u2019s food showcases the best of traditional Tuscan cuisine. Start with the Bruschette di Nonna Lina, made with uber-fresh chopped tomatoes and a hint of basil sitting on slices of bread. \n\nNext, get a Pappardelle della Vigna, featuring Italian sausages and a creamy sauce made using blue cheese. It may be simple, but it packs quite a punch! For a taste of coastal Tuscany, try the Cacciucco, a thick stew of various seafood cooked in homemade tomato broth. Last but not least, the majestic Bistecca Fiorentina is perfect for hungry meat-lovers.\n\nCome for the top-notch Tuscan-styled nosh, but stay for an evening of long conversations with friends with a bottle of wine or two. (Jul 2018)", "", "True Blue Cuisine started in late 2003 in a pre-war shophouse in the Peranakan enclave of Katong.  The restaurant\u2019s aim is to serve the best authentic Peranakan cuisine to Singapore and the world.  It was set up jointly with Baba Benjamin\u2019s mother Bibik Daisy Seah, a well respected Peranakan chef.\n\nTrue Blue Cuisine is the place for a good Peranakan feat - drawing locals and food lovers from all over the world.  Legendary dishes are their Ngoh Hiang (Minced Chicken and Prawn meat rolls wrapped in Beancurd skin), Jantong Pisang salad (Banana Blossoms with Cucumber), Ayam Buah Keluak (Chicken stewed with Indonesian black nuts), Beef Rendang (Beef simmered in a coconut sauce/dry curry) and Kari Kepala Ikan (Whole fish head curry).\nTrue Blue Cuisine is situated beside the Peranakan museum at 49 Armenian Street, and it compliments the museum and brings to life an all-round experience of the rich Peranakan culture.\n(Dec 2017)", "TSUBAKI BY SHUNSUI is a Kyoto Cuisine Restaurant.Chef Kenta Yamauchi introduces varieties of Omakase courses featuring Kyoto ingredients. (Mar 2021)", "", "A culinary powerhouse, TungLok has built its stellar reputation on creating Chinese meals that define perfection. With TungLok Seafood, the restaurant empire turns its focus to creating a seafood bonanza for diners, as it welcomes hungry eaters from all corners of Singapore with its consistently delicious locally-inspired seafood. \n\nTake a swim in the culinary ocean starting with the TungLok Seafood Platter. An ultimate crustacean dream, this impressive platter is practically overflowing with cuts of bluefin tuna, salmon, fresh oysters drizzled with chilli sauce, poached prawns, and braised baby abalone. The Fish Maw Broth with Four Treasures is a soup that\u2019s sure to garner the approval of your health-conscious mother or grandmother, as it is packed with rich proteins and nutrients that will boost your immune system. Other perennial favourites include the super-shiok Black Pepper Crab. Saut\u00e9ed with a homemade concoction of black pepper and fresh peppercorns, this highly-acclaimed crab dish is so fingerlicking good you\u2019ll be coming back for more. \n\nWith a seating capacity of 300, TungLok Seafood at The Arena Country Club is a fitting venue for large parties such as wedding anniversaries or birthday celebrations. So don\u2019t waste your time and energy trawling through an ocean of mediocre seafood restaurants. TungLok Seafood will be your perfect culinary catch \u2013 that\u2019s our promise! (Jul 2017)", "", "Tunglok Signatures has long been synonymous with excellent traditional Chinese cuisine, the go-to place for family celebrations and birthdays. Regardless of which outlet you visit in Singapore, you can be assured that each exquisite morsel on your plate has been carefully planned by a team of chefs who really understand the nuances of Chinese cooking and are willing to take risks as they push the boundaries for a better dining experience. Indeed, Tunglok has a way of taking the most basic of Chinese dishes and ramping up its flavour and style quotient. \n\nTake the Tung Lok Flaming Fortune Chicken for instance. The wedding banquet staple, roast chicken, has been updated in spectacular style. It arrives at your table wreathed in flame, and if that's not enough spectacle, its taste doesn\u2019t disappoint with its plump and juicy flesh. Another poultry dish, the Roast Irish Duck, is made using only the best Irish Duck from Silver Hill Farm. If you ever thought the Irish were only known for four-leaf clovers and leprechauns, you might want to add duck to your list. The flesh of the bird is so juicy and flavourful that you wonder what magic happens in the farm and in the Tunglok Signatures kitchen. (Aug 2016)", "", "", "", "As complex as Peking London Duck may sound - London duck from Ireland's Silver Hill Farm served in traditional Peking style - there's nothing complicated about our feelings for this delicacy from TungLok XiHe. Specially bred and aged to produce dense and porous skin along with tender flesh, the duck is cured with a secret mix of spices and filled with a special marinade before hung to roast in a traditional oven.\n\nThe end result? Sheer perfection. We could spend forever tucking into endless wraps of juicy duck breast or creating our very own delectable bundles of joy using steaming slivers of duck thigh and a slew of incredible condiments. Our real favourite, however, is the skin and TungLok's version delivers both creativity and classic flavours. Crispy skin is highlighted with a unique blueberry sauce and Popping Rocks dip, bringing true meaning to the jingle: once you pop you just can't stop. If you can tear yourself away from the duck party in your mouth, the rest of the menu is nothing to sneeze at either. There's Wok-Fried Crab with Homemade Spicy Sauce, Mrs Zhang's Braised Lion's Head Meatball, Hot and Sour Soup with Fresh Shrimp, and more Chinese delicacies that score full marks. All their effort paid off in spades, we say! (Jun 2020)", "Having been in business for over a century, and having recently received a Bib Gourmand, you\u2019d think the people at Miyagawa would know their stuff, and you\u2019d be absolutely right. With 20 outlets in Japan, this is the first overseas outpost of the beloved unagi franchise. Famed for their expert grilling techniques and secret in-house sauces, this unagi restaurant is a must-visit for diners who love fine Japanese dining.\n\nThe Unagi here is served in three different styles, namely: Hitsumabushi - where the eel is placed over a bed of rice and served with three condiments, Seiro Mushi, which is served with Hokkaido rice, egg, and a sweet sauce, and Mamushi Donburi, which is served with Japanese yam, mentaiko, kinshi eggs and onsen egg. The latter two dishes are unique to the Singaporean incarnation of the restaurant, while the former is a signature dish available at all outlets. The unagi for all three dishes is marinated in a spice mixture made with ingredients directly imported from Tokyo before being steamed, then subsequently grilled - just as they do at all outlets across Japan.\n\nWhether you\u2019re an unagi connoisseur or just a fan of seafood, the wallet-friendly prices, intimate dining environment, and exquisite dishes here will surely entice you to visit more than once! Made for sharing and family style enjoyment, Uncle Leong Seafood should be on every seafood fan's must-try list! (Mar 2015)", "We never thought this day would come; forget the oyster bar and welcome the age of the sea urchin! One of the most delicious seafood treasures in existence, sea urchin has firmly established itself as one of the foodie world's favourite indulgences, and here at Uni Gallery, the offerings are sublimely self-explanatory.You can opt to bliss out on these creamy orange globules of umami as you would oysters: fresh out of the shell with the barest lashings of seasoning. The restaurant offers premium grade uni sourced from all over the world, including varieties like Canadian Aka Uni, or more exquisite Japanese varieties like Higashizawa Shiro Uni and the Mercedes-Benz of urchins, Hadate Shiro Uni. All three varieties come together in a little treat called The Uni Bomb, which you chase with a shot of sake. For added indulgence, the Uni Oyster Shot combines uni with a freshly shucked oyster in a single, oceany mouthful.To make your uni go a little further, have it as one of a selection of sashimi atop a bowl of rice in the restaurant's hefty Bara Chirashi. But perhaps the most classic and delicious way to serve it up is in the hearty Ikura Uni Chirashi, which features mounds of salty salmon roe and uni atop rice, just mouthful after mouthful of pure, umami magic. The meat is Ozaki wagyu beef \u2013 a big deal since there\u2019s only one farm in Japan that sells wagyu under this name \u2013 and finding a restaurant serving the same Ozaki beef is incredibly rare.If you\u2019re looking for quality dishes that revolve around premium beef and done in Japanese style, book early for Ushidoki \u2013 especially since they claim to serve the whole cow in one course. (Dec 2020)", "Uya \u56db\u4ee3\u76ee\u83ca\u5ddd may have opened its doors at Wheelock Place just recently, but it has served discerning diners for more than four generations back in Japan. What it does best is the exquisite, perfectly grilled traditional unagi and Uya \u56db\u4ee3\u76ee\u83ca\u5ddd aims to offer up its authentic rendition of the Japanese delicacy at affordable prices. The eels are carefully selected and this commitment to quality and freshness shows from the crispy, fluffy, and creamy unagi. In fact, the tare, or sauce, is made using Uya\u2019s highly treasured secret recipe that has been passed down through the generations. The eel is delivered live from Japan and stored behind the kitchen before they are prepared and grilled daily. \n\nThe main star here\u2019s definitely the Hitsumabushi served with condiments, broth, soup, and pickles. The best way to savour the different flavours is simply to divide the unagi rice into four portions and enjoy it with some condiments, with the dashi broth and condiments provided, on its own, or any way you like! Different flavours come through with every quarter, making for a delightful culinary experience that\u2019s truly exciting. No part of the eel goes to waste, so don\u2019t forget to try the Kimoyaki (grilled liver) and the Hone Senbei (Bone Crackers) - they taste as delicious as they sound intimidating. Don\u2019t pass up on this gem even if you don\u2019t enjoy unagi. Dishes such as the Rare Wagyu Rice Bowl, the Sashimi Moriawase, and Oyster Tempura will also give you plenty reason to return! Serving traditional Nyonya dishes, Violet Oon and her family personally invite you to experience the unique flavours of Peranakan cuisine in a beautiful black and white setting.Given that Ms. Oon is an expert on all things Nyonya, you can't go wrong by exploring the \"Nyonya Favourites\" on the menu. However, the western offerings, inspired by her experiences travelling abroad as Singapore's food ambassador, deserve some consideration. Her Shepherd's Pie is a cult favourite, while dishes like Chilli Crab Pizza, and Brioche French Toast with Gula Melaka Banana Sauce present an interesting Nyonya twist.Whether you decide to dine al fresco, or choose to be within the confines of the updated Peranakan decor, don't be surprised if Ms. Oon stops by and introduces herself, or even goes so far as to bring up a chair and chat with you for a bit! (Mar 2020)", "Infused with local inspiration, Viva Loca serves up delectable Western, Mexican and Spanish cuisines prepared with local flair. Boasting both indoor and alfresco seating, drop by Viva Loca today to enjoy lip smacking tapas, oysters, ribs, pasta, pizza alongside the restaurant\u2019s wide range of beer, liquor, wine, cocktails and mocktails.\r\n\r\nFeast on half a dozen of Freshly Shucked Oysters. Drizzled in mignonette sauce, the plateful of fresh catch from the ocean is juicy and succulent. Pair this refreshing appetiser with a plate of Calamari Salad. Made of mesclun, golden calamari strips and topped off with a homemade Thai sweet cilantro dressing, this delectable mix of vegetables and squid is great for those on the lookout for a nutritious yet yummy meal.\r\n\r\nFor those looking to satisfy their carnivorous cravings, the Wurst Platter is the perfect combination of pork, veal and smoked cheese bratwurst, set to delight and satisfy. The Smoked Beef Burger is also a great option that is served with a generous portion of shoestring fries. Local delights menu options include the Shrimp Fried Rice, Crabmeat Fried Rice and Chicken Fried Rice. (Mar 2016)", "We're suckers for unexpected bursts of inspiration and Wan He Lou's award-winning Lobster Porridge certainly qualifies. Catching a lobster during one of his typical leisurely diving trips off an isolated island, the lack of other ingredients forced Chef Lau Siaw Dee to throw together a quick meal using only rice, seawater, and the aforementioned crustacean. Surprise, surprise! The salty combination worked so well, it became an instant hit once Chef Lau brought it back home \u2013 after much refinement of course.\r\nToday's iteration is a Teochew-style porridge, whose loose grains float in a yellow broth that's been richly flavoured with lobster roe, accompanied by a bevy of fresh lobsters sitting under a blanket of fresh spring onions. It's both comforting and decadent without being too much on the palate. There's also plenty more on the menu that can round out your meal, from poultry dishes like Seven Spice Pork Choplets to local staples like Braised Yee Fu Noodles and Sambal Fried Rice.\r\nFor mouth-watering Chinese food that's packed with plenty of local flavour and an exceptional bowl of lobster porridge, only one place comes to mind, and this is it. The Black Pepper Crab offers the familiar earthy spice we are so fond of, while the Sambal Kangkong is crisp, spicy, and best enjoyed with a bowl of Jasmine rice. The Claypot Curry Chicken is a crowd favourite - and for good reason. The Wok Master\u2019s curry grave is aromatic and spicy, and coats every piece of tender chicken and potato. (Sep 2018)", "A fuss-free alternative to the traditional Wok Master restaurant, this casual eatery at Mapletree Business City known as Wok Master Express is a local Chinese restaurant dishing up tasty and affordable fare. From all-time classics such as Sambal Kang Kong to hot favourites such as Salted Egg Pork Ribs, all dishes here at Wok Master Express go through a blazing fire in the wok to achieve that essential \u2018Wok Hei\u201d flavour that everyone loves.\r\n\r\nDig into a hearty breakfast of juicy Prawn Dumplings, crunchy Fried Spring Roll and more with the eatery\u2019s wide variety of dim sum delights. Set options such as Laksa Set, Mee Siam and Ipoh Hor Fun are also available on the extensive menu. Meat lovers can look forward to the signature Crispy Pork Belly Rice. Perfectly sliced, the succulent pieces of tender pork belly are set atop a bed of soft, fluffy grains of short rice for a delicious dining experience. Alternatively, opt for the Curry Chicken with Rice for a fiery rendition of chunky potatoes, chicken wings and flavourful coconut milk. A mainstay in the Wok Master Express kitchen, the two claypot dishes are the star of the menu. Retaining the nostalgic flavour of the past, this tasty mix of chicken with spring onions rewards with a burst of flavours and is a great dish for sharing with family and friends. Made with eggs, crispy potato, truffle jus, and potato mousseline. The mixture of textures in this dish give it a unique mouthfeel that you\u2019ll want to savour. The light eggs and hearty potatoes make for an unlikely but delicious combination. Continuing with the unique dish trend, try the Dashi Risotto. Served with earthy garlic chips and creamy aioli, the buttery taste of the pork will leave you craving for more long after the last bite. (April 2019)", "", "This pet cafe serves up wonderful and tasty meals for both pets and owners alike. \r\nSpaciously designed to make it a perfect venue for playdates, bring your feline or canine and dine together at Wooftopia. \r\n\r\nOrder the Wooftopia Chicken Burger. Loaded with fresh tomatoes, romaine, caramelized onions, the cafe\u2019s signature double patty grilled burger oozes a smokey barbeque sauce. Served with shoestring fries and a side salad, the Cheese Burger and Fish & Chips are also crowd favorites. Bangers & Mash is also a good choice. Presented on a bed of chunky mashed potatoes, sausages are drizzled with the cafe\u2019s special black pepper sauce for an extra kick of flavor. \r\n\r\nThe pet\u2019s menu is also extensive, with sweet treats such as the Fruity Pancakes and even local favorites such as Chicken Rice and Nasi Lemak. A replica of Singapore\u2019s beloved Hainanese chicken rice, boiled chicken is served with brown rice, cucumber and goji berry paste as chili. All pet dishes also come with a free dessert known as the Puppuccino! \r\n\r\nAn ideal place for bonding sessions with your furry creatures, head down to Wooftopia for good food and company. (Mar 2020)", "If you are in search for an experimental, avant garde take on steak, Wooloomooloo is not the place for you. Instead, Wooloomooloo is among the best classic refineries of steakdom in this hemisphere, with a name from Down Under, and years of experience from the namesake Hong Kong restaurant group. Including everything that has made steakhouses its own genre - premium cuts, elegant d\u00e9cor and classic trimmings - Wooloomooloo is set to \"steak\" its claim as one of the premier houses in Singapore.\nFrom the 3rd floor of the Raffles City Shopping Center, Wooloomooloo boasts a picturesque view of Stamford Road, St. Andrew's Cathedral, and for Formula One enthusiasts, Turn 9 of the only night race in the world. There is much to be proud of, with an expansive lounge and dining area flanked by handsome leather seating and stacked wood touches that have become iconic. Aboriginal dot paintings pay homage to the Aussie title while an impressive meat case and open kitchen pay homage to the other source of the restaurant's greatness, its remarkable steaks.\nWith more offerings than it has O's, the range is well-varied and precisely prepared - think jumbo prawn cocktails, a mammoth Australian Black Angus Tomahawk, a highly sought after USDA prime rib eye, and a gorgeous bread and butter pudding if there ever was one. Take our word for it, when it comes to steak, go classic. Go Wooloomooloo. (Jun 2016)", "", "Nestled in the heart of Ang Mo Kio, Workbench Bistro aims to satisfy with its industrial decor and its crowd-pleasing menu. Small and cosy, this place is ideal for evening waffle dates, or for just sitting with a cold drink in one hand, watching one of the oldest neighborhoods in Singapore go by.\nThe hipster cafe trend has resulted in several must-have items on every self-respecting local cafe menu. A salted egg dish or two, a crab dish of some kind, truffle fries, craft beer. In this aspect, Workbench Bistro does not disappoint. It has not two, but four salted egg dishes on offer -- Salted Egg Chicken Pasta, Salted Egg Chicken Burger, Salted Egg Wings, and Salted Egg Wedges. The salted egg sauce is delightfully savory, and pairs well with the meats it comes with. There are two crab dishes, Crab Meat Linguine and Crab Cake Burger, that come chock full of fresh crab meat. If you come in a group, a must-order for sharing is the Signature Truffle Fries, which has that unmistakable aroma of truffle that is both appetizing and addictive. With the variety of craft beers available, and fluffy waffles for dessert, Workbench Bistro will undoubtedly make any cafe hopper very satisfied. (Sep 2016)", "Founded by Jacky Yu, nicknamed \u2018Hong Kong\u2019s Jamie Oliver\u2019, Xi Yan Shaw rides on his years of food experience as a food critic and cooking instructor. His impressive resume includes representing China at the food expo event, Bocuse D\u2019or, alongside greats like Pierre Hermes and being selected by Phaidon to appear as one of the world\u2019s top ten master chefs in a publication that also highlights Gordon Ramsay and Alain Duccase.Working off the fundamentals of Chinese cooking as created by Chef Yu, Xi Yan\u2019s modern Chinese cuisine employs only the freshest ingredients which are then transformed into comforting fare. (Mar 2016)", "", "If you ask us, we can\u2019t think of a meal that\u2019s more comforting than a bubbling cauldron of fiery-hot soup. And when that craving strikes, there\u2019s one name that soars above its competition \u2013 Xiao Long Kan Hotpot \u5c0f\u9f99\u574e\u8001\u706b\u9505. Hailing from Chengdu, Xiao Long Kan Hotpot is the brainchild of F&B veteran Lao Wu. Better known as Old Man Wu, this bright entrepreneur wanted to create an eating space centred around providing the best ingredients and flavours for diners. And what happens next is history, as this burgeoning empire succeeded beyond all expectations and has new restaurants popping up all over the continent.\r\n\r\nLocated in Bedok, Xiao Long Kan Hotpot is a place where you\u2019ll be treated like a member of the imperial dynasty. From the warm and attentive service to the rich and opulent decor showcasing Chinese lanterns, wooden lattice panels, and gorgeous wall-sized paintings, get ready to be whisked away from the humdrum of everyday life and into a dining experience like no other. Load up on a variety of top-quality ingredients to go alongside your spicy hotpot. We love the tender Beef Slices or the Lady Finger Wrapped Pork. The freshly made Tofu is another go-to pick that complements the spice-laden soup perfectly.\r\n\r\nAn ever-growing chain, Xiao Long Kan Hotpot has made a splash among local hotpot aficionados for its deeply satisfying and lip-smacking fare. (Mar 2021)", "Xiao Ya Tou, or XYT, is hard to miss. Its distinctive red lanterns, plastic chairs, and loud decor just call out to you as you walk past, not unlike the pervy men in the past who used to line this very street leering at the ladies of the night who used to operate around the area.\nXYT\u2019s food, too, is loud, bold and in-your-face. Start your meal with the all-time classic, Braised Duck. At XYT, the meat of the duck is tender, yet provides enough of a bite to allow you to savour the juice of the sinews. To share, you will not regret ordering a Lu Rou Fan (braised meat on rice), which, at XYT, uses minced wagyu instead of the normal pork. The ubiquitous street food is thus upgraded to an almost unrecognisable form, but it is an evolution that we daresay is worth the calories. As the sun sets on Duxton Hill and lights from other eating establishments flicker on around you, sit back and reminisce about the days of old Duxton as you enjoy the retro charm with a cocktail or two from the XYT bar. (Mar 2020)", "", "Roll up your sleeves, ladies and gentlemen, because it\u2019s time to get down and dirty at this popular gem of a yakiniku restaurant. It\u2019s pretty much a given that red meat-lovers will have the time of their lives at Yakiniku Oh, which offers a luscious spread of Wagyu beef cuts that can be grilled to tender perfection over charcoal fires.\r\nAdmire the exquisite marbling that comes with beef of superb quality, and watch as it slowly cooks over your gridiron; the fact that the restaurant uses charcoal fires gives an exquisite charred facet to the taste of the meat. What truly sets Yakiniku Oh apart from other similar restaurants, however, is the fact that it imports the entire cattle \u2013 this allows the restaurant to offer up a selection of rare cuts, each more flavoursome and succulent than the last. Don\u2019t forget to reserve your favourites, though, because some parts are limited in quantity and liable to be snapped up early! To get to the meat of the matter (pun shamelessly intended), it\u2019s a rare person who won\u2019t enjoy a visit to this restaurant \u2013 so what\u2019re you waiting for? The beef is incredibly tender and melts in the mouth with Maze Gohan (a mix of sushi rice and Yakizen special sauce) at the bottom. (Jan 2021)", "Yan Ting is one of the city\u2019s most ethereal Cantonese restaurants, tucked away in the regal St. Regis hotel. It\u2019s a favourite amongst discerning diners looking for a quiet and discreet location for a luxurious and refined dimsum brunch, or more elaborate Cantonese feasts for special occasions. Expect the height of fine Chinese cuisine, shot through with the balance and richness of pure Cantonese cuisine. Nothing says special occasion quite like a Braised Whole Abalone in Superior Oyster Sauce, an entire lobe of the meaty treasure in an umami broth, paired with crunchy seasonal greens. A similar, less wallet-busting dish is the Braised Sea Supreme Cucumber with Corn Broth, a lovely blend of savoury and sweet flavours with the incomparable texture of high quality sea cucumber. \n\nCantonese cuisine is nothing without a soup centrepiece, and here there\u2019s a stunning Double-boiled Sea Whelk Consomm\u00e9 with Garlic, served in a teapot for some extra theatre with the deep oceaney flavours. Meat dishes here come with a similarly high-end flourish. Think Pan-Fried Chicken with Morel in Superior Soy Sauce, a humble poultry dish given a dramatic gourmet kick with the addition of rare, earthy morels. Moving further along this French direction, two great cuisines meet in the form of a Pan-Seared A9 Wagyu Beef Fillet with Mushroom Sauce. If it\u2019s dimsum and traditional Cantonese roasts you\u2019re after, lunch and brunch on the weekends is the best time to hit up this joint, with its popular buffet options. Either way, this is a meal that will stick around in your belly and mind with its commitment to fine ingredients, lovingly and innovatively prepared. (Jan 2018)", "Yantra has established itself as the premier fine-dining Indian restaurant in Singapore, having won numerous accolades such as Singapore Tatler Best Restaurants in 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012 and the Best Restaurant Concept Award (Asian) in 2011 by Epicurean Star Award. Now in celebration of its 8th anniversary, it seems fitting that Yantra has collaborated with world-renowned Chef Hemant Oberoi, who has cooked for the likes of world leaders and celebrities such as Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton, Margaret Thatcher, Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie.\nThis is not your typical North India - the dishes are inspired by flavours from all over India, but with a contemporary twist. One stellar example, the Chicken Tikka Fondue, is the perfect marriage between chicken tikka marinated in spices and yogurt, and a tantalizing cheese fondue. From the Seafood Rassa to the Thepla Tacos, the dishes are also telling of Yantra\u2019s unyielding conviction of using the freshest ingredients and spices hand-picked and flown in from India.\nYantra also turns fine dining up a notch with an interior that conveys an effortless sophistication and elegance, a clever reflection of its food. The extended bar which boasts of an imaginative range of specialty cocktails like the Tandoor Mojito and intriguing whiskies from Scotland\u2019s finest whisky producing regions is also majorly impressive. Enough said, we\u2019re sold on this unparalleled dining experience! (Jun 2016)", "Located along Chin Swee Road, Yanxi Palace Steamboat is a humble Chinese restaurant that serves up a number of delicious soup bases double-boiled from scratch. With the likes of authentic Mala Soup, Tomato Soup, Pepper Pork Stomach, Chicken Soup and more, you\u2019ll be spoilt for choice needing to make repeated trips back!\r\n\r\nA huge hit among the ladies is the Imperial Elixir Youth Soup. Rich in collagen and nourishing for both your skin and health, this tasty and nutritious soup base is the perfect choice for a delicious meal. Another must-try soup is the restaurant\u2019s signature Buddha-Jumps-Over-The-Wall. Brewed using the finest selection of ingredients and herbs such as ginseng and cordyceps, this tasty soup base comes highly recommended to nourish your health. If you\u2019re looking for something to soothe your stomach, try the Yanxi Treasure Pearl Soup \u2014 boiled for 8 hours with different types of rice, try this take on comfort food instead. \r\n\r\nTo supplement your soup bases, a variety of crowd-favourite steamboat options are available too. Choices include wagyu beef, prawn balls, flower crabs and black pork, to name a few. For seafood lovers, opt for the Seafood Platter that is filled with a variety of huge and juicy scallops and mussels, fresh from the ocean. To end off the meal, balance out the richness of the soup bases by indulging in the restaurant\u2019s refreshing ice jellies. (Dec 2020)", "", "Opened by veteran Chinese Muslim chef Yassin Ng, this restaurant brings together everything Singaporeans love under one roof - seafood, spice, and the kampung spirit. Having worked in a medley of hawker kitchens - first as a waiter and then as a chef - gave Chef Ng the necessary expertise to craft halal versions of hawker classics. The menu at Yassin Kampung features a range of famous local dishes such as Chilli Crab and Fish Head Curry, and some with a contemporary twist - like the Buttermilk Salted Egg Yolk Chicken. There are sets available for groups of up to 10 people in a communal dining style - everyone gets a bowl of rice and a range of main dishes. \n\nThe Chilli Crab here is a must-try. Served piping hot, this dish consists of tender crab meat in a rich, spicy gravy and served with deep fried buns. Use the buns to mop up your plate, or enjoy them on their own - the subtle sweetness of the buns cleanse the palate for the following dishes.The Grilled Tiger Prawn is another crowd favourite. Whole prawns are grilled in-shell with oil and spices to tender perfection. The flesh of the prawn is buttery and perfect with a serve of Jasmine rice. (Aug 2018)", "Located in Marina Square, level 2 Dining Edition, Yechun Xiao Jiang Nan is a Chinese restaurant that specialises in Huai Yang / Jiang Nan cuisine. Offering multiple deals a week, the restaurant serves a wide selection of appetizers, mains and dim sum dishes as well. \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\nStart your meal with the Yechun Steamed Pork Dumpling or dim sum of your choice from a wide selection of Dumplings and Buns (including the award-winning 3-diced bun which was created for the Qing Emperor). For something with a hint of spice, opt for the Poached Sliced Beef in Sze Chuan Style, where thinly sliced beef pieces are cooked in the restaurant\u2019s famous sweet and spicy broth. For those looking for a healthier option, Yechun Xiao Jiang Nan offers a fragrant Tonic Herbal Claypot Chicken and Pig Stomach Soup, a herbal concoction that will surely comfort the senses and improve your immunity. The Wok-Fried Four Season Vegetables are also great for those looking for a tasty plate of greens.   Yangzhou Fried Rice is an award-winning main that please all nationalities.\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\nDesserts at Yechun Xiao Jiang Nan are also healthy, with vegetarian options that cater to your non-meat eating friends. Order the Pan Fried Red Bean Pancake or the White Fungus Soup with Red Dates for a sweet end to a scrumptious meal. (Feb 2020)", "", "The food here follows the clean eating philosophy adopted at The Garcha Group, which means you won\u2019t find any additives or artificial flavourings in chef Sebastian Goh\u2019s food. \r\n\r\nA cold starter of organic vine-ripened tomatoes, for instance, are served with their skins thoughtfully removed as the red skins are believed to contain inflammatory properties. The tomatoes are then soaked in a house-made plum and herbal juice, rendering them sweet and refreshing. \r\n\r\nRoast duck is a popular mainstay of Chinese restaurants, and the one at Yellow Pot is first marinated for two days in a fermented beancurd paste, then roasted over hickory wood so the meat is aromatic and tender with a glistening layer of crispy skin. Vegetables are not an afterthought here, too. Try the sweet and sour eggplant, where the aubergine is braised and coated with a delicious housemade sauce of hot bean paste, honey, vinegar, and Nanyang soya sauce brewed by a local company. (Sep 2020)", "Located within Duxton Reserve Hotel, Yellow Pot is well known for delivering traditional Chinese flavours with a modernised twist that favours responsibly sourced ingredients. Promising an immersive gastronomic experience like no other, come down to witness the restaurant\u2019s rich culinary philosophy, warm hospitality and traditional favourites in a breathtaking setting.\r\nClad in a striking palette of black, gold and yellow, the 50-seat restaurant lives up to its name with cheeky embellishments of a smattering of yellow pots of various sizes and configurations. (Jun 2018)", "A well-known and much-loved destination for Dim Sum, Yum Cha in Chinatown satisfies grandpa, tiny tykes and everyone in between with classic Cantonese cuisine.\nThere's a reason why Yum Cha always seems to be alive with hungry patrons, and that has a lot to do with their dim sum. The classics are certainly excellent, but Yum Cha also excels in trendier items like Malay Cake from Hong Kong, and Crispy Red Bean with Banana, which they challenge their kitchens to introduce to the menu every now and then. All are solid in taste with recipes very similar to those you grew up with, tossing you back into a haze of tasty nostalgia (or perhaps that's just a food coma).\nThe setting is apt for the retro dishes, with round marble tables and basic wooden chairs that recall traditional Chinese dining. Yum Cha has much more up their chefs' sleeves than just dim sum, however. Take part in the \"Tapino\" dining style, gathered around the hotpot. The rich broth and communal atmosphere truly give the place a feeling of home.\nAt the original Chinatown outlet, delight in the hi-tea a la carte buffet with over 60 items to choose from. At only $23.80++ for adults and $16.80++ for kids, it's a value that can't be beat and will have everyone saying \"yum\"(cha)! (Jun 2017)", "", "Taking orders and pleasing palates from an unusually hip, modern space in Katong, Zaffron Kitchen keeps more than its looks up-to-date with Indian flavours that encompass every dialect of the varied cuisine. From classic Hindustani tandoori to flaky Malay roti, Zaffron speaks the universal language of savoury Indian cuisine fluently.Zaffron Kitchen in Katong takes on the look preferred by many fresh-faced gastropubs and open dining concepts lately, but it's a novel makeunder for an Indian restaurant. A smattering of various seating arrangements from communal high tops to rustic wood bistro tables makes the space feel social. The dining area is grounded by floors made of modern concrete and vintage Perankan tiles, peppered with the common hue of deep saffron orange, and lit up by non-traditional fixtures. There's a children's area that encourages play, and the vibe in general is fluid and open.\r\nThe menu takes a similarly light and easygoing approach to Indian fare. A genre of cooking typically known for rich, hearty and spicy flavours, Indian cuisine is smartly organized into weekend only specialties of South Indian Dosai and Roti Prata, anytime snacks like crispy Bhel Puri and Samosa, and perennial North Indian classics of clay oven roasted Tandoori dishes and curries. The categories make the encyclopedic cuisine feel more accessible to those naan novices who are less familiar with Indian fare.\r\nHowever those curry connoisseurs will be equally impressed with the complex, spot-on flavours of the offerings. The Fish Tikka here is especially scrumptious, made with salmon for a more unique texture that stands up to the marinade brilliantly. The Tandoori Malay Chicken Tikka, though it carries a similar name, has a distinctly different interplay between the medley of spices and the tender morsels of chicken. On the weekends, the Keema Dosai is a unique treat that must be tried. For the uninitiated, the familiar paper-thin, sourdough crepe is crisped fresh to order and filled with spiced minced ground meat. It's a killer, homestyle combination that you don't often see, which is a common theme at Zaffron Kitchen. Indian cuisine done so consistently well with modern approachability is certainly a rare sight - and taste - indeed. (Jul 2019)", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "Basque Kitchen reopens at iconic Fullerton Waterboat House \r\n\r\nNew home opens a fresh chapter for the Michelin one-star restaurant by Chef-Patron Aitor Jeronimo Orive \r\n\r\nApril 2021, Singapore - Where ships entering the harbour of Singapore came for fresh water, now gastronomes flock to for a fresh new dining experience. Introducing Basque Kitchen \u2014 back after a brief hiatus \u2014 in its new home at the historic Fullerton Waterboat House.  \r\n\r\nThe second home marks the beginning of a new chapter for Basque Kitchen. Established in October 2018 as Singapore\u2019s first Basque-centric restaurant celebrating the country\u2019s indigenous culture and produce, Basque Kitchen was awarded its first Michelin Star in the 2019 edition of Michelin Guide Singapore.  \r\n\r\nIn the new location, Chef-Patron Aitor Jeronimo Orive \u2014 alumni of the Michelin-starred kitchens of The Fat Duck in London, Mugaritz in San Sebasti\u00e1n and Neura in Bilbao \u2014 and his team continue to stay true to the produce-driven culinary philosophy that their customers love, executed with even greater finesse while remaining approachable. The Basque gastronomic experience is also more immersive, with a pintxos bar and lounge welcoming diners to unwind over a flute of cuvee champagne created especially for the restaurant, and to tease the tastebuds with the diverse range of light bites. In the semi-open kitchen, a duo of handsome Josper grills, custom-designed for the restaurant, anchor the space, offering diners a glimpse of the deliciousness to come. Within the 38-seat main dining hall of the new Basque Kitchen, a private dining room that seats eight makes a perfect venue for small, discreet gatherings.  \r\n\r\nBasque Kitchen will also host the exclusive members-only space for American Express Centurion and Platinum Card Members, called Platinum at Basque Kitchen. Comprising 18 seats at the dining hall and 18 seats at the pintxos bar, the dedicated space boasts the finest views of the Fullerton waterfront. Centurion and Platinum Card Members will also enjoy priority reservations, and a suite of complimentary experiences including valet service and welcome drinks.\r\n\r\nAn Immersive Experience \r\n\r\nPremier design agency Grey Matters, the same behind the likes of Cloudstreet, Tippling Club, and W Maldives, draws on the elements of Earth, Water, Fire, Air \u2014 also considered the four cornerstones of Basque cooking \u2014 to create a space that marries rusticism with modern sophistication. Think the juxtaposition of charcoal stained oak floorboards against plush velvet banquettes; the cool of gleaming embossed metal detailing balanced by the buttery softness of cream-hued leather; rippled glass creating a dance of light as water does; contoured lines all around, reminiscent of the coast of the Basque country, facing the Bay of Biscay. Dressed in a harmonious palette of charcoal greys, warm orange and oaky tones and given accents of gold and copper, it\u2019s a space that is as invitingly comfortable as an old friend\u2019s home as it is elegantly refined and fitting of special occasions.  \r\n\r\nThe pinxtos bar and lounge that seats 33 persons sets the tone for enjoyment. From the a la carte menu comes exquisite offerings such as artisanal Sanfilippo anchovies \u2014 perfected over 125 years by five generations of a Cantabrian family and exclusively available in Singapore at Basque Kitchen \u2014 served simply with tomatoes atop crisp curasao flatbread; a classic dish of goose barnacle slivers served with tender nuggets of sous vide abalone, piparras olives, piquillo peppers; and a moreish wagyu burger with amera tomato, pickled cucumber, caramelised onions and epoisses cheese. Apart from the authentic light bites served on bar plates made by Catalan tableware design studio Luesma & Vega, patrons can also indulge in oysters served four ways, or caviar by the tin before moving on to the main meal.  \r\n\r\nIn the dining room, a tasting menu is offered exclusively for lunch and dinner (from $158++ for lunch to $248++ for dinner). Crafted using painstakingly sourced Basque produce, complimented by premium seasonal ingredients from Japan \u2014 such as deep sea fish, uni and scallops, the menus also showcase house-aged beef. In the aging fridge \u2014 two to three times bigger than before \u2014 prime cuts such as Australian and Japanese wagyu are meticulously dry-aged for a minimum of 45 days. Following the style in the Basque country, the team also sources for beef from mature livestock about eight years of age \u2014 that which presents intensely deep and complex flavours and textures. \r\n\r\nCharcoal-grilled items anchor the tasting menus: such as Charcoal grilled blackspot bream and razor clam dressed in a typically Basque Donostiarra sauce made from the classic San Sebasti\u00e1n style pil pil; and a charcoal grilled old beef loin, its rich flavours amplified by a smoked garlic mousseline and a drizzle of truffle jus. Accompanying these are inspired items such as a jelly of tomato essence served with a tomato sorbet and Japanese fruit and micro tomatoes, and a sea anemone served with bomba rice and sea succulents, finished with a fragrant chive aioli \u2014 further demonstrating the breadth and depth of Chef Aitor\u2019s evolved and elevated repertoire.  \r\n\r\nComplementing the food is an expanded beverage list personally selected by General Manager Vincent Jaureguiberry. The industry veteran who has passed through the doors of Pierre Gagnaire in France and Saint Pierre Restaurant in Singapore looks beyond prized vintages and awards to find the true merit in good wines. He sees wines as expressions of the people behind each bottle, and takes the effort to meet the winemakers. As such, Basque Kitchen\u2019s list of over 600 wines is a unique collection comprising of fine and rare wines from both prestigious houses and small producers. Each bottle also represents a moment in Vincent\u2019s wine journey \u2014 and that of the restaurant\u2019s wine service team.  \r\n\r\nSome highlights from the collection include a vintage juice made from an apple variety native to the Basque country, commissioned by the restaurant, a terroir-driven French Basque natural cider from Domaine Bordatto, exclusive to Basque Kitchen; and an exclusive vintage collection from Basque winery Artadi. Of note is also the Jean Louis Vergnon Champagne \u201cConversation\u201d, a blanc de blanc produced especially for Basque Kitchen in the renowned Cote des Blanc, homeland of the oldest and most mineral Chardonnay. Patrons can also look forward to weekly vineyard highlights, with wines offered by the glass, to be introduced at a later stage.  \r\n\r\nOn the list is also an extensive range of sherries, from crisp Finos to nectar-like Pedro Ximenez. Connoisseurs will take delight in exquisite drops such as those from celebrated Andalusian sherry maker Bodegas P\u00e9rez Barquero. The Solera Fundacional 1905 and Solera Cincuentenario 1955 from the 116 year-old bodega are considered guardians of a classical, extraordinary style, and at Basque Kitchen sherry enthusiasts will have the opportunity to sample the Amontillado 1955 and Oloroso 1955 from the Solera Cincuentenario series of the house, amongst other noble selections. \r\n\r\n\u201cBasque Kitchen by Aitor is a celebration of Basque heritage, but it is also a celebration of the hearts and minds of our team,\u201d shares Chef Aitor. \u201cEvery dish is a loving tribute to my own grandmothers; and every bottle marks a personal moment in the wine journey of our sommeliers. We hope not just to intrigue you with an immersive gastronomic experience, but also touch your heart with every drop and morsel presented.\u201d (Apr 2021)", "", "", "An epicurean adventure awaits with fresh fruit martinis, freshly shucked oysters by the bar and music from the city's hottest crooner, Rafi Ali with The Vibes. The Italian menu features comfort from the shores of the Latin peninsula with an emphasis on pastas, panini sandwiches and skinny pizzas. Sleek and smart during the week we roll up our sleeves and loosen our ties on the weekends with spit roasts and ice-cold beer as we take in the breezy afternoons on our sun-kissed terrace. Get ready for The Beacon, get ready for the finer things in life. (Mar 2021)", "", "", "", "", "It\u2019s easy to mistake Birds of a Feather for yet another pretty cafe. The space is filled with natural light from two air-well openings, and hand-crafted art pieces and copper pipes are a chic finish to the walls here. \n\nBut the dishes here are far from the typical Eggs Benedict or pancake stack. Instead, the food is a delicious fusion of Western with Sichuan influences. Take the Yuxiang (fish fragrance). The sauce is traditionally made by frying doubanjiang, garlic and ginger with pickled chilli, served with meaty eggplants. At Birds of a Feather, the same dish comes with an extra layer of mozzarella cheese, and a generous sprinkle of mantou crumbs. \nIf you\u2019re a big fan of spicy food, items like the Fortune Skewers are a must-order. This crowd favourite has gotten a new twist, and now comes with a fiery Sichuan red oil. Birds of a Feather specially pick their spices from Chengdu\u2019s spice market, and these are laboriously  fried with chillies to create this house-made oil. \n\nNot all Sichuan dishes are numbingly spicy, either. The Sichuan Oxtail Soup is a light, clear broth, akin to the familiar pig\u2019s trotters soup. Chinese herbs and fresh leek infuse this comforting soup with plenty of flavour. \n\nJust looking for a relaxed night out, with drinks and some simple grub? The street food-inspired selection is the perfect bar snack. Definitely order the Charcoal Grilled Pork Bits. Inspired by barbecued pork belly skewers sold along the streets, Birds of a Feather does a luxe version with Duroc pork belly, crispy rice crackers, charred green chilli, and Japanese sweet potato. Loved for spinning up authentic German meals and ice-cold beers, Brotzeit can often be seem packed with the food-loving, beer-guzzling crowd at all hours of the day.\r\n \r\nThere\u2019s nothing more German than huge swirling hunks of sausage. So there\u2019s little surprise to see Brotzeit featuring a wide array of such sausages, the showstopper being the Thuringer Pork Sausage, which comes with a generous heaping of mashed potatoes, sauerkraut, and sweet onion sauce. But the Sausage Platter, another fan fave, serves all the top hits from the kitchen, from grilled pork, spicy chicken, to the garlic pork sausages. \r\n \r\nWant something other than sausages? Featuring generous chunks of tender beef in a herb-tinged soup, this soup is perfect on a rainy night. And the Crispy Oven Roasted Pork Knuckle is another must-try. A Brotzeit staple, this pork shank is oven-roasted until it achieves its fork-tender perfection with a crispy layer of crackling skin to boot. And wash your meal down with a beer or two, and you have all the ingredients for what is just about to be your next perfect meal. Cocktails and other beverages are also available.\r\nFans of the former Cheek by Jowl can expect to enjoy the same level of casual but attentive service that the restaurant was known for, in a more convivial setting that features cosy booth seats and an open kitchen. (Jan 2021)", "", "", "", "Chuan Hung\u2019s name is beautifully straightforward belying the respect, thought and care that was put into it, much like its offerings. Chuan Hung or \u2018Sichuan Alley\u2019 focuses wholeheartedly on one particular Sichuan ingredient known as Mian Yang rice noodles. At Chuan Hung, these noodles are served the way they have always been for millennia: with a choice of different broths, and a variety of toppings such as braised beef and pig intestines.\r\nChuan Hung\u2019s rice noodles are, admittedly, a little more distinctive: they are specially sourced from one particular artisan who lives in a village deep in Sichuan. Research for months into about 50 different Sichuan noodle shops led the Chuan Hung team to understand that only one particular shop sold the exact type and style of Mian Yang noodles that they wanted to present to Singaporeans \u2013 but it took close to a year and dozens of personal trips to the shop in sincere appeal before the owners finally softened and agreed to speak to them. It took even longer to research and try the different noodles the artisan made: every detail was examined, down to the gauge of the noodles in millimetres.The noodles now served in Chuan Hung are customised for the noodle house, and found nowhere else in Singapore or South East Asia. The noodles may be ordered with the clear or red soups as well as the uniquely Sichuan mix of red and clear. In addition, Chuan Hung also offers a third broth option: a deceptively clear soup that is piquantly infused with Sichuan vine pepper, and a dry-tossed version. Those with bigger appetites can feel free to order \u201cadd-ons\u201d as extra toppings for the noodles, and a curated selection of small plates \u2013 archetypal Sichuan sides such as Fried Crispy Pig Intestines and Braised Eggplant \u2013 as accompaniment.\r\nThe interiors of Chuan Hung is deserving of attention from the diner as well. Located in a side alley just off the far busier main street in much the same way that noodle shops in China have been set up for years, Chuan Hung is a little haven of gently coloured wood, bamboo furnishings and warm lighting. The small space of half a dozen tables \u2013 bustling when full, and tranquil when quiet \u2013 is inspired by the aforementioned noodle shops though elevated with thoughtful design details to ensure comfort for the guest even at the busiest of times. (Jul 2019)", "", "", "", "", "", "Whenever you dine at The CIA Top Table restaurant, you are helping to support the future of the food service and hospitality industry. As an independent, not-for-profit college, The CIA directs its resources right back into our core mission \u2013 to provide the best professional culinary education to thousands of students each year in our degree, professional development, and food enthusiast programs. \r\n\r\nThe students who have prepared and served your meal today are fulfilling their degree requirements at The CIA. We encourage you to engage them in conversation, ask them about their education experience, and provide any useful feedback that can help them improve their performance and your overall dining experience. (Jul 2019)", "A veteran of Indian dining since the 80s, it doesn\u2019t get much better than this. Founded by a couple in 1988 with the aim of bringing the best of North Indian cuisine to Singapore, Delhi\u2019s Restaurant has grown from strength to strength and now operates in two locations in Little India - on Serangoon and Race Course Road. If the posh saffron and wood interior isn\u2019t enough to entice you in, the smells from the kitchen certainly will. Think spicy masala and freshly cooked naan. With friendly servers and an excellent array of dishes, it\u2019s easy to see why the pioneering Indian eatery has built up a loyal following over the last three decades. \r\n\r\nThe Romali Roti is a must-try. Translated to mean \u201chandkerchief bread\u201d this unique dish is made in an overturned wok to give it its delicate texture. The roti is paper-thin and soaks up the flavour of any curry that it is dipped into, making it the perfect accompaniment to the many curries on offer here. The Fish Curry is a great option for diners who are tired of the diluted versions offered at other restaurants. The curry is robust and spicy, and is best enjoyed with some steamed rice or naan bread to soak up all the flavour.
